title: The History and Structure of the English Language
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of the changes in English phonology, morphology, syntax, spelling, and vocabulary, from the earliest times to the present. Along the way we also explore such topics as attitudes toward language, the impact of political and economic changes, literacy, attitudes toward grammar, the rise of American English, language and social class, and language and gender. No previous knowledge of linguistics, Anglo Saxon, or Middle English is required.

title: The History and Structure of the English Language

title: The History and Structure of the English Language
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the changes and continuities of various aspects of the English language, including its phonology, morphology, syntax, and vocabulary, from its beginnings to the present day. Ancillary topics include language and gender, language and society, pidgins and creoles, and language acquisition. No previous knowledge of linguistics, Anglo Saxon, or Middle English is required.

title: The History and Structure of the English Language
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the changes in the English language from the earliest centuries to the present. It explores such topics as the impact of political and economic changes, literacy, attitudes toward grammar, the interactions of social class and gender, and American English. Knowing more about the language gives critical and creative writers more command over the medium of their craft; it also sharpens one's perceptions as a reader.

title: Introductions to Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Representations of Women
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Old English grammar and literature using texts by or about women. The task of translating is supplemented by readings on the legal, political, religious, and literary roles of women in Anglo-Saxon society. Open to freshmen.

title: Early Bible Translations
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Large portions of the Latin Bible were translated into Old English in the centuries before 1066. Some efforts, like that of Aelfric (10th century), were cautious and painstakingly literal because of the anxiety associated with any departure from the Latin text. Others, however, moved with great interpretative freedom, especially those that exploited the conventions of Old English poetry, so that Moses, for example, leads his people across a desert that looks much like the forests of northern Europe, and Satan is a rebel warrior chieftan (somewhat resembling Milton's Satan).

title: Introduction to the Bible in the Humanities and the Arts
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A practical survey of the Authorized ("King James") Version of the Bible (1611). This course is not a course on "the Bible as literature" but rather on the Bible for literature. Students will read most of the Bible and some Apocrypha, and learn how to identify and understand Biblical concepts and images in literature and art, for example, how to "read" a cathedral. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts C.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Historicizing the Past
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How did the Anglo-Saxons interpret their past? How do we in turn interpret their culture? An introduction to the basic grammar of Old English will move hand in hand with translations, at first simple but progressively more challenging, which come from various historical texts. Secondary readings provide an opportunity to consider how we today appropriate the medieval past.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Historicizing the Past

title: Introduction to Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Representations of Women
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Inaugurates a new approach to the teaching of Old English, which will, as always, introduce students to grammar and translation, but the readings are organized around a topic that changes each year. This semester, texts include accounts of Eve, Judith, Juliana, The Wife's Lament, The Husband's Message, and some riddles, charms, and wills. Supplementary readings include historical, cultural, and literary criticism.

title: Introduction to Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Representations of Women
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Old English: Introduction to Anglo-Saxon Language and Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: At the end of fifth century, tribes from the north coast of Germany and the Netherlands invaded the island of Britain. The language they spoke and wrote is the earliest form of one of the most influential and widely-spoken languages in the world today: English. In this class, we will learn to read the earliest records of English by studying the grammar, vocabulary, and poetics of the Anglo-Saxons; we will also learn the history of the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms of England along the way (origins to 1066). By the end of the semester, your new facility in Old English will enable you to read and understand some of the most beautiful poems ever written.

title: Introduction to Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Interpretations of the Past
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Old English literature using texts that reflect the Anglo-Saxons' interpretation of history as well as some that reveal 20th-century interpretations of the Anglo-Saxons' past. Begins with the fundamentals of Old English grammar, syntax, and vocabulary. Texts include Bede's Account of Caedmon, The Battle of Maldon, The Ruin, and excerpts from the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle.

title: Old English: Introduction to Anglo-Saxon Language and Literature

title: Introduction to Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Heroic Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the Anglo-Saxon language in the context of the history of English. Cultural survey of England before 1066. Special emphasis on the heroic ethic and its supporting institutions and on poems such as Beowulf. First half of a sequence with English 103a.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: The Millennium
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How did the Anglo-Saxons view the advent of the year 1000? How are their responses to it (or indifference) reflected in their literature? The semester will begin with an introduction to the basics of Old English grammar and will later expand to include more thematically driven topics. All of the selections for translation - chronicles, homilies, poems - will have some bearing on the millennium. Comparisons with current anxieties about the year 2000 will be aided by a site on the world wide web.

title: Anglo-Saxon Literature and Culture: Literature from the time of King Alfred
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In 9th-century England King Alfred instituted an unprecedented program of writing in Old English, in effect creating a literary tradition where none existed before. This course will introduce students to Alfred's life and times, along with readings from Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, Bede's History of the English People, riddles, The Seafarer, and other Old English lyrics. Fulfills the College language requirement and the English Department's Foreign Literature requirement if its continuation English 103 is also completed.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Literature from the Time of King Alfred
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In 9th-century England King Alfred instituted an unprecedented program of writing in Old English, in effect creating a literary tradition where none existed before. title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Heroic Poetry and Heroic Legend
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the language and culture of England before 1066, with special attention to heroic poetry and its narrative and social foundations. By the end of the term we will have read a handful of the noblest poems in the English language, among them The Wanderer and The Seafarer and gained some insight into the so-called "heroic code" and its verbal products. Note: Fulfills the College language requirement and the English Department's Foreign Literature requirement if its continuation English 103 is also completed.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Poetry and Belief
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the language and culture of England before 1066, with special attention to religion and its expression in poetry. By the end of the term we will have read, in the original, a handful of the greatest short poems in the English language, among them The Wanderer and The Seafarer and gained some insight into an unfamiliar Christianity. Note: Fulfills the College language requirement and the English Department's Foreign Literature requirement if its continuation English 103 is also completed.

classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Introduction to Old English: Biblical Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Large portions of the Latin Bible were translated into Old English in the centuries before 1066. Some efforts, like that of Aelfric (10th century), were cautious and painstakingly literal because of the anxiety associated with any departure from the Latin text. Others, moved with interpretative freedom, especially those that exploited the conventions of Old English poetry, so that Moses, for example, leads his people across a desert that resembles the forests of northern Europe, and Satan is a rebel warrior chieftain.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A basic introduction to Old English, with special attention to literary landscapes and seascapes. After an overview of Old English grammar, we will translate excerpts that describe the lushness of paradise, the terrors of hell, the desolateness of Roman ruins, and the icy loneliness of the sea. We will also consider what these representations of the landscape can teach us about how the Anglo-Saxons connected with the natural world.

title: Introduction to Old English: The Literature of Spiritual Warfare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the deeply religious, yet turbulent culture of Anglo-Saxon England, where the tension between new Christian belief and deeply engrained warrior culture produced works of provocative prose and astonishing poetry. We will first learn the fundamentals of Old English, which requires study as a foreign language. As we gain facility with the language, we will translate biblical narratives, sermons, and religious poems: some of them cautiously literal in their treatment of scripture, others fascinatingly hybrid. Ultimately, we will gain a sense of the development of English prose, and read some of the greatest poems in the English language. Students who complete both English 102 and 103 with honors grades will fulfill the College language requirement and the English Department's Foreign Literature requirement.

title: Introduction to Old English: Heroes, Heaven, and Hell
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Satan, cast as a defiant warchief, exults in his heavenly rebellion; Christ is presented as a triumphant hero as he assumes his place on the cross; Grendel’s mere serves as the template for a vision of hell. Such examples underscore the close relationship between the heroic and biblical literary traditions of Anglo-Saxon England, which this course seeks to explore. First and foremost however, this course is an introduction to the language and literature of Old English, the vernacular language used in England from the fifth century until around 1100. Although many of its linguistic features are recognizable in Modern English, Old English must be learned as a foreign language. The semester will begin with an introduction to Old English grammar, along with translations of basic readings. Following instruction in basic grammatical features during the first half of the course, readings will grow progressively more challenging. The selection of readings brings us to the second goal of the course: an exploration of the ways in which the heroic ethos influenced the presentation of Christian and Biblical topics in Old English prose and poetry. Daily instruction by Joseph Shack.

title: Introduction to Old English: Riddles, Dreams, Wonders
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong:
In this course, you will learn to read English as it was written a thousand years ago, beginning with a grammatical overview and ultimately translating a wide array of the earliest English literature, from riddles and dream guides to monastic sign language and travel narratives. Throughout, we will examine varying assumptions about knowledge and knowledge production, literature and literary theory then and now, focusing in particular on texts that instruct their readers in how to read them—from magical incantations to manuals on how to predict the future. 

 

Note: Students who complete both English 102 and 103 with honors grades will fulfill the College language requirement and the English Department’s Foreign Literature requirement.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: King Alfred
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In 9th-century England, King Alfred instituted an unprecedented program of writing in Old English, in effect creating a literary tradition where none existed before. This course will introduce students to Alfred's life and times, along with readings from the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, Bede's History of the English People, riddles, The Seafarer, and other Old English lyrics.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: King Alfred
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In 9th-century England, King Alfred instituted an unprecedented program of writing in Old English, in effect creating a literary tradition where none existed before. title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Elegiac and Sapiential Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A continuation of English 102a,b. Study of the Anglo-Saxon language in the context of the history of English; cultural survey of England before 1066. Special emphasis on the elegies, poems such as "The Wanderer" and "The Seafarer," and on the "wisdom" strain in early English literature. English 102b or permission of instructor.

title: Beowulf, Seamus Heaney, and Translation
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Seamus Heaney's recent translation of Beowulf has provoked a renewed interest in the poem among a wider audience and, among medievalists, in his principles of translation. Students will undertake their own translation of parts of Beowulf, which will form a basis of comparison with Heaney's as well as other translations. We will also consider Heaney's Beowulf in the context of his other poems. A series of critical essays on Heaney and on Beowulf will address topics concerning the poem and translations. A prior semester of Old English or its equivalent is required.

title: Anglo-Saxon Literature and Culture: The Old English Epic
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Along with close translations of Judth, Exodus, and parts of Beowulf and Genesis, examines the cultural background, the manuscript tradition, and the reception of these poems. A continuation of English 102b. One prior semester of Old English.

title: Beowulf, Seamus Heaney, and Translation
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Seamus Heaney's recent translation of Beowulf has provoked a renewed interest in the poem among a wider audience and, among medievalists, in his principles of translation. A prior semester of Old English or its equivalent is required.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Heroic Poetry and Its Social Contexts
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Beowulf and the shorter heroic poems (e.g., Deor, Widsith, Finnsburg Fragment, Waldere) are read, along with some related elegiac verse, partly in the original and partly in translation. A study of aspects of Anglo-Saxon, Continental, and Scandinavian cultural history and related literatures (especially Old Norse) places the heroic poetry in relation to social institutions such as the court, the church, and especially the warband or comitatus. Some attention paid to gender as an aspect of the social context, especially in the all-male warband.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Heroic Poetry and Its Social Contexts
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Beowulf and Seamus Heaney
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Translations of excerpts from Beowulf will proceed in parallel with careful reading of Heaney's verse translation. Questions concerning translation theory will emerge from the comparison of in-class efforts with Heaney's and other versions. What is the relation between translation and interpretation? How does Heaney's Beowulf compare with the body of poetry he has produced over the decades? The course begins with a review of grammar.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Poetry and Poetics
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A continuation of English 102, with special emphasis on how poetry of the period works (poetics), styles, genres, the roles of the poet, social settings of poetry, and on individual poems. Traditional figures and tropes will be illuminated in comparative perspective, and some attention will be given to the modern reception of Old English and related verse.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Beowulf and Elegy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Tolkien thought Beowulf as much "elegy'' as "epic,'' and current readers treat the poem as a cultural elegy for a passed or passing world. Close reading of about one-half of the poem in the original, the rest in the Heaney translation, leading to criticism and scholarship on Beowulf and elegy in Old English and related literatures. Builds on English 102e, continuing the language study and cultural survey with focus on the central poetic monuments of Anglo-Saxon England.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Before Love
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What we call ``courtly love'' started off as a literary convention in the high Middle Ages, one which has since influenced western culture in profound ways. But how was love imagined and conducted in the earlier Middle Ages? How was it represented in literature? Readings will explore a variety of emotional attachments between people, not only heterosexual relations. Translations from Old English poetry will form the basis of weekly discussions, supplemented by secondary readings.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language and Culture: Before Love
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Some time around the twelfth century, Europeans began to fall in love_or so literary and cultural histories tell us. But what was love like before love? How were passionate attachments represented in literature? Building on the grammatical knowledge acquired in English 102, we translate various Old English texts concerning erotic relations. Secondary reading is supplemented by other medieval texts in translation. The sequence of Eng 102 and 103 can fulfill either the college's foreign language requirement or the English Department's Honors foreign literature requirement. Honors grade in English 102 or the equivalent.

title: Old English: Working with Manuscripts
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: The task of translation will be supplemented by consistent attention to the manuscript contexts of Old English literature. The texts will include selections from the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, Genesis, the Exeter Book Riddles, Beowulf, and others. The course will guide students through basic principles of manuscript study and will culminate in a collaborative edition of an Old English text.

title: Old English: Beowulf and its Contexts
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: We will translate some of the most fascinating sections of Beowulf—from monster-slaying and heroic feats to pagan burials and betrayals—in order to learn what makes it an exceptional poem. We will also combine language study with literary criticism to consider different aspects of Beowulf each week: the artistry of poetic language, the use of Germanic legend, or the sophistication of the meter, for example.

title: Anglo-Saxon Literature and Culture: The Lyric
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the earliest English lyrics, including riddles, meditative poems, and elegies such as "The Seafarer" and "The Wanderer."

title: Advanced Old English: Anglo-Saxons at Home
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course deepens our sense of Anglo-Saxon culture through texts that bring its everyday, nitty-gritty details to life. We will encounter, for example, strange medical remedies as well as bawdy riddles; the domestic comforts of Beowulf's mead-hall as well as its epic battles. After a rapid review of skills taught in 102, we will translate progressively more challenging passages; transcribe from Old English manuscripts; and read John Gardner's Grendel, discussing the uses of engaging with an era that remains opaque in many ways. Class will culminate in the production of creative, yet linguistically faithful, translations of selected Old English poems. Students who complete both English 102 and 103 with honors grades will fulfill the College language requirement and the English Department's Foreign Literature requirement. Honors grade in English 102 or the equivalent.

title: Heroic Poetry Secular and Religious
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Epic, romance, and saga: orality and literary history
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Genre will be the tool of a (para)literary history of the major oral and oral derived narrative forms of Early Medieval Europe, but genre and orality/literacy must also be analyzed. Reading (in English translation) includes: Hildebrandslied and other herioc lays, Beowulf, selected chansons de geste, including Roland, the Nibelungenlied (in selections), Waltharius, romances and sagas on the Tristan theme, and among Icelandic sagas Njals saga and Laxdoela saga. Concluding with the oral epic today: the Karakalpak Edige.

title: Major British Writers I
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the study of British literature from the Middle Ages through the 18th century. Emphasis on lyric and narrative poetry; four plays are also read. Two lectures and one section meeting per week. Required of English concentrators. Open to freshmen.

title: Major British Writers I
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the first eight hundred years of English literature through the reading of major works from the Anglo Saxon beginnings to Paradise Lost. Authors include the Beowulf poet (in translation), the Sir Gawain and the Green Knight poet, Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, Kyd, Webster, Jonson, Donne, Herbert, Marvell, and Milton. Open to freshmen. Two lectures and one section meeting per week. Required of English concentrators. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Major British Writers I
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A chance to read profound works from three of the richest periods of English Writing: Anglo-Saxon literature (unrivalled in the Europe of its time for power and sophistication); the late fourteenth-century (where Chaucer's not the only exceptionally rewarding oeuvre); and from Spenser to Milton, including Shakespeare en route. Students will be encouraged both to immerse themselves in great works and to generate their own understanding of literary history. Open to freshmen. Two lectures and one section meeting per week. Required of English concentrators. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Major British Writers I
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the study of British literature from the Middle Ages through the 18th century. Emphasis on lyric and narrative poetry; plays, novels, and essays are also read. Two lectures and one section meeting per week. Required of English concentrators. Open to freshmen. Counts as Literature and Arts A credit. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core arearequirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: An Introductory Humanities Colloquium
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The course is designed for students interested in concentrating in a Humanities discipline. We cover major works of literature and ideas from Homer's Odyssey to Joyce's Ulysses. Many of the texts have thematic connections; we hope that all of them will stimulate interest in the kinds of issues addressed in humanistic studies. Ninety-minute lecture-discussion, plus one-hour section led by the instructors. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding or the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Medieval Fanfiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Fanfiction is a surprisingly powerful tool for examining medieval literature. It sheds light on the dynamics of rereading and reception that characterize medieval texts, which in turn deepen our own understanding of creative originality. In this class we will read some twentieth- and twenty-first century fanfiction with medievalist themes alongside medieval literary texts that rewrite, reimagine, or let their authors star in pre-existing stories. This medieval ‘fanfiction’ will include Arthurian romances, ‘sequels’ to the Aeneid and the Canterbury Tales, and Christian spiritual texts in which devout men and women imagined themselves as ‘Mary Sues’ in scenes from the Gospels.

title: Epic: From Homer to Star Wars
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course studies epic literature through six significant works in the genre: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Vergil's Aeneid, Milton's Paradise Lost, George Eliot's Middlemarch, and George Lucas' Star Wars. We will examine these works in terms of their formal conventions, thematic interests, and historical contexts, as well as attending to the interactions between texts in the epic tradition, the shift from narrative poetry to novel and film, and the manifestations of epic in the modern world.

title: Introduction to Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of medieval literature from ca. 800 to 1500, which will introduce students to various genres (lyric, epic, chronicle, saints' lives, fabliaux, romance, dream visions, drama, and others) across the centuries. Early and dialectical works will be read in translation. (Chaucer's Canterbury Tales will not be included, though some of his minor works will.) No previous knowledge of Old or Middle English is required.

title: Epic: From Homer to Star Wars
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to epic poetry and to the most significant works in the genre: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Vergil's Aeneid, Dante's Inferno, and Milton's Paradise Lost. The course examines epic poems in relation to their own historical contexts as well as the interplay between texts in the epic tradition, the shift from epic to novel, and the manifestations of epic narrative in the modern world. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding.

title: Chaucer and the Invention of Middle English Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Many ethically challenging, politically daring texts written in the period 1330-1400 invented a literary space of extraordinary freedom. Such texts establish the very possibility of writing literature of high ambition in English; they create a space for women authors, for religious reform, and for a literature of profound psychic range and historical depth. Chaucer, who does all these things, forms the centre, but romances, Langland, and Julian of Norwich each make decisive contributions.

title: Chaucer: Troilus and Criseyde, and The Dream Poems
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Chaucer: The Canterbury Tales
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: One of the most astonishing, vibrant, multivalent texts in the English language, Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales contains characters high and low telling stories of edification and pleasure, in poetry and prose, on topics bawdy and pious. We will read this work in its entirety, while also looking at some of Chaucer's shorter poems and the historical and cultural milieu in which he wrote. Expected to be given in 2014-15.

title: Women and Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will explore women in medieval literature, whether as writers, readers, or characters. We shall look at works that are pro- and antifeminist, and especially at the range of more complex engagements that women had with medieval secular and religious culture. We shall start with late classical views of women and then read such works as Eloise's letters, Marie de France's plays, Christine de Pisan's City of Ladies, some of Chaucer's tales, Julian of Norwich's Revelations, Margery Kempe's Book, and others. Readings are in translation and accessible Middle English (no previous knowledge required).

title: Repetition and Revenge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The dynamic of repetition is the dynamic of revenge: the ghost, the clue, the trace, the compulsion to repeat. Drawing on selected works of Freud and contemporary literary theory, examines Elizabethan and Jacobean revenge tragedies and the plays of Shakespeare together with relevant modern works of drama, fiction history, film, and video.

title: Medieval Drama: History and Performance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Half lecture, half workshop, this course will approach medieval drama in terms of performance. We will spend the first part of the semester familiarizing ourselves with Middle English Drama and its performance history; the second half of the course will involve enactments of scenes from cycle and morality plays and will culminate in an informal production of a morality play. Texts will include Mankind, Castle of Perseverence, Everyman, and several plays from the York, Towneley, Chester and Coventry cycles.

title: Great Books from the Middle Ages to the Modern Age
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In this course we will read exactly ten world-historical books written in English, as background for understanding the British and American empires, colonialism, and today's transnational, global literature.

title: Medieval Drama: History and Performance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Half lecture, half workshop, this course will approach medieval drama in terms of performance. We will spend the first part of the semester familiarizing ourselves with Middle English Drama and its performance history; the second half of the course will involve enactments of scenes from cycle and morality plays and will culminate in an informal production of a morality play. Texts will include Mankind, Castle of Perseverence, Everyman, and several plays from the York, Towneley, Chester and Coventry cycles.

title: The Comic Imagination from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to various forms of comic literature, including beast fables, fabliaux, satires, and plays. Attention to the literary merits of these works and their cultural background. Chaucer, Dunbar, Rabelais, Shakespeare, and others. Knowledge of Middle English not required.

title: Medieval Drama: History and Performance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Half lecture, half workshop, this course will approach medieval drama in terms of performance. We will spend the first part of the semester familiarizing ourselves with Middle English Drama and its performance history; the second half of the course will involve enactments of scenes from cycle and morality plays and will culminate in an informal production of a morality play. title: Marvelous Journeys in Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of late medieval literature concerned with travel and encounters with the fantastic, bizarre, or supernatural. Texts may include Bede's Ecclesiastical History of England, The Vision of Tundale, Mandeville's Travels, Piers Plowman, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Chaucer's House of Fame, and Malory's Death of Arthur.

title: Marvelous Journeys in Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of late medieval literature concerned with travel and encounters with the fantastic, bizarre, or supernatural. Texts may include Bede's Ecclesiastical History of England, The Vision of Tundale, Mandeville's Travels, Piers Plowman, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Chaucer's House of Fame, and Malory's Death of Arthur.

title: Spencer
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Magic, Carnival, Sacrament, and Other Theatrical Illusions: European Renaissance Drama and Spectacle
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Spectacle, make-believe, and other forms of alternative reality in the European Renaissance. Explores theatre as magical and spiritual practice; carnival, charivari, and everyday cross-dressing; beggary, prostitution, and other street improvisations; court masque, imperial pageant, and public torture as disciplinary technique; sacrament, conversion, and other forms of illusionism and self-transformation. Texts include films, visual images, theatrical documents, festival books, commedia dell'arte scenarios, and plays by Shakespeare's greatest near-contemporaries (Machiavelli, Lope de Vega, Sor Juana, Moliére, etc.).

title: Ritual and Religion in Medieval English Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores ritual performance, religious symbolism, and imagery in literature of late medieval England. Special attention given to veneration of saints, Eucharistic practices, prayers and spells, and Purgatory. Primary texts may include Malory's Death of Arthur, Castle of Perseverance, Croxton Play of the Sacrament, Digby Mary Magdalene, Julian of Norwich's Showings, Chaucer's Prioress's Tale, and a variety of saints' lives.

title: Magic, Carnival, Sacrament, and Other Theatrical Illusions: European Renaissance Drama and Spectacle
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Spectacle, make-believe, and other forms of alternative reality in the European Renaissance. Explores theatre as magical and spiritual practice; carnival, charivari, and everyday cross-dressing; beggary, prostitution, and other street improvisations; court masque, imperial pageant, and public torture as disciplinary technique; sacrament, conversion, and other forms of illusionism and self-transformation. Texts include films, visual images, theatrical documents, festival books, commedia dell'arte scenarios, and plays by Shakespeare's greatest near-contemporaries (Machiavelli, Lope de Vega, Sor Juana, Moliére, etc.).

title: American Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introductory survey of landmarks of 19th and 20th century American fiction (novels and short stories) from The Scarlet Letter, Moby Dick, and Huckleberry Finn through the works of James and Faulkner.

title: American Literature: Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive study of major poets (Walt Whitman, Emily Dickinson, Robert Frost, T.S. Eliot, Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams) with some reference also to their precursors, contemporaries, and successors.

title: American Literature: Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive study of major poets (Walt Whitman, Emily Dickinson, Robert Frost, T.S. Eliot, Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams) with some reference also to their precursors, contemporaries, and successors.

title: American Literature: Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive study of major poets (Walt Whitman, Emily Dickinson, Robert Frost, T.S. Eliot, Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams) with some reference also to their precursors, contemporaries, and successors.

title: American Literature and Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the works of figures including Franklin, Jefferson, Emerson, Thoreau, Lincoln, Jane Addams, Du Bois, William James; and of genres including autobiography, natural history, the political essay, travel narrative. Attention to the symbolic dimensions of representations of land and landscape, the nation, revolution, immigration, mechanization, urbanization, and social reform.

title: Introduction to Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A selection from Shakespeare's plays - comedies, tragedies, histories, and romances - giving an overview of his development as a dramatist and engaging in intensive reading of some of the most important plays, notably Hamlet and King Lear. Emphasis will be divided between questions concerning performance and the literary qualities that make Shakespeare the most celebrated author ever.

title: Introduction to Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A selection from Shakespeare's plays - comedies, tragedies, histories, and romances - giving an overview of his development as a dramatist and engaging in intensive reading of some of the most important plays, notably Hamlet and King Lear. Emphasis will be divided between questions concerning performance and the literary qualities that make Shakespeare the most celebrated author ever. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

subject: ENGLISH

title: Adam and Eve
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Jointly taught by HAA and English, our course focuses on the story of Adam and Eve. We will study points of contact with Mesopotamian myths; rivalry with Greek and Latin stories of Prometheus and Pandora; and interpretations by rabbis and monks, mystic visionaries and heretics. Above all, examining some of the greatest achievements of European art and literature--from Dürer, Michelangelo and Rembrandt to Milton's Paradise Lost-we will compare the possibilities of the verbal and visual arts in portraying human being.

title: Adam and Eve
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Jointly taught by HAA and English, our course focuses on the story of Adam and Eve. We will study points of contact with Mesopotamian myths; rivalry with Greek and Latin stories of Prometheus and Pandora; and interpretations by rabbis and monks, mystic visionaries and heretics. Above all, examining some of the greatest achievements of European art and literature--from Dürer, Michelangelo and Rembrandt to Milton's Paradise Lost-we will compare the possibilities of the verbal and visual arts in portraying human being.

title: Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This is an advanced survey course in Shakespeare.

title: Shakespeare and Music
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Shakespeare in Music. The music of Shakespeare's own patternings of text, and the Shakespearean aspects of musical composition. Codes for interpreting dramatic music, both in Shakespear's time and in the ages of Purcell, Berlioz, Verdi, Wagner and Britten.

title: The Literature of Science in the English Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in the literature of science during the 16th and 17th centuries, including Gilbert's On Magnetism, Bacon's Novum Organum and New Atlantis, Thomas Browne's Religio Medici and Pseudodoxia Epidemica, Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, selections from the Cambridge Platonists, selections from the controversy between Thomas Hobbes and Robert Boyle, Thomas Sprat's History of the Royal Society, William Harvey's The Circulation of the Blood, and selections from Isaac Newton's writings. The focus of the course will be on the relation between writing and science in the context of the emergence of scientific discourse. Areas of inquiry include questions about the nature of bodies, the distinction between matter and spirit, magic and science, the status of poetry and rhetoric in science, the political and social investments of scientific writing.

title: The Literature of Science in the English Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in the literature of science during the 16th and 17th centuries, including Gilbert's On Magnetism, Bacon's Novum Organum and New Atlantis, Thomas Browne's Religio Medici and Pseudodoxia Epidemica, Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, selections from the Cambridge Platonists, selections from the controversy between Thomas Hobbes and Robert Boyle, Thomas Sprat's History of the Royal Society, William Harvey's The Circulation of the Blood, and selections from Isaac Newton's writings. The focus of the course will be on the relation between writing and science in the context of the emergence of scientific discourse. Areas of inquiry include questions about the nature of bodies, the distinction between matter and spirit, magic and science, the status of poetry and rhetoric in science, the political and social investments of scientific writing.

title: Shakespeare After Hamlet
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Written at the midpoint of Shakespeare's career (1600-01), Hamlet marks the culmination of an experiment in representing the inner life with remarkable human sympathy. Hamlet also marks the beginning, in the comedies as much as in the famous tragedies, Othello, King Lear, and Macbeth, of a new and disturbing interest in the human mysteries of sadism, power, eroticism and loss. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding or the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Shakespearean Playwriting
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores Shakespeare at work, transforming his sources, shaping his plots and characters, writing and revising his scripts. The goal is to understand the making and remaking of the plays for live performance in the theaters of Elizabethan and Jacobean England. In addition to critical assignments, students are given source materials for lost Shakespeare plays and are asked to invent scenes he might, if he was a contemporary, have written.

title: Shakespeare and Cultural Difference
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the representation of otherness in Shakespeare, those who do not fit the normative expectations of Elizabethan and Jacobean culture: Othello, Shylock, the shrew Kate, the "crook-back" Richard of Gloucester, the bastard Edmund - all those who put a strain on notions of who "belongs" in a well-ordered world. Special attention to the relation between such figures and the development of the public theater.

title: Shakespeare and Cultural Difference
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the representation of otherness in Shakespeare, those who do not fit the normative expectations of Elizabethan and Jacobean culture: Othello, Shylock, the shrew Kate, the deformed Richard of Gloucester, the bastard Edmund - all those who put a strain on notions of who "belongs" in a well-ordered world. Special attention to the relation between such figures and the development of the public theater.

title: Shakespeare After Hamlet
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Written at the midpoint of Shakespeare's career (1600-01), Hamlet marks the culmination of an experiment in representing the inner life with remarkable human sympathy. Hamlet also marks the beginning, in the comedies as much as in the famous tragedies, Othello, King Lear, and Macbeth, of a new and disturbing interest in the human mysteries of sadism, power, eroticism and loss.

title: Love and Its Alterations in the Renaissance Imagination
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Love is not love which alters when it alteration finds," wrote Shakespeare. Perhaps. Even so, the concept and the imagery of love underwent many alterations in Renaissance literature due to genre, to changing circumstances, and to changing morals. Looking back on the poetry of love in the Renaissance, it appears less like Shakespeare's image of unaltering constancy than it does like Spenser's allegorical tapestries showing the Olympian gods changed by lust into a thousand forms

title: Shakespeare and the Path among the Passions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A set of the major plays (Hamlet, Macbeth, The Merchant of Venice, King Lear, Romeo and Juliet, A Winter's Tale, The Tempest) seen within the traditional philosophy of the passions (anger, fear, grief, wonder) and distinct from modern categories of inner life such as the emotions, moods, and feelings, or the modern category of irony. Readings include Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, and Hume.

title: Tragedy after Hamlet
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The 17th century marks a high point of English tragedy. We will set a few of Shakespeare's plays amid the best tragedies written from Kyd to Addison. These ask a common set of questions. What was the grandeur of the ancients? What is virtue? Does suffering generate insight? Why revenge? Attention to generic conventions, performance, and changing ideas of the spirit of tragedy. Authors include Shakespeare, Jonson, Webster, Beaumont and Fletcher, Middleton, Milton, Dryden.

title: Shakespeare and the Path among the Passions

title: English Renaissance Poetry and Prose
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a general survey of the literary achievements of 16th-century England. Of particular interest will be the innovative representation of a range of spaces: the fantastic universes of More's Utopia and Spenser's Faerie Queene; the exotic lands described by Elizabethan travellers; the inner worlds of longing and despair evoked by the period's great lyric poets. We will also pay attention to the actual spaces in which these works were created: the courts of Henry VIII and Elizabeth I, the city with its plagues, rebellions, and religious controversies, the countryside with its enclosures, risings, and hunger, and the colonial outposts.

title: English Renaissance Poetry and Prose
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a general survey of the literary achievements of 16th-century England. Of particular interest will be the innovative representation of a range of spaces: the fantastic universes of More's Utopia and Spenser's Faerie Queene; the exotic lands described by Elizabethan travellers; the inner worlds of longing and despair evoked by the period's great lyric poets. We will also pay attention to the actual spaces in which these works were created: the courts of Henry VIII and Elizabeth I, the city with its plagues, rebellions, and religious controversies, the countryside with its enclosures, risings, and hunger, and the colonial outposts.

title: Shakespeare: The Early Plays
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: The early comedies, tragedies, and histories, considered in the context of the origins of the English stage and the conventions of Elizabethan drama. Particular attention paid to Shakespeare's development as a dramatist, and to poetic expression, thematic design, stagecraft, and character portrayal in plays.

title: Shakespeare's History Plays
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Shakespeare's history plays dealing with both the classical world and with England. These include Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, Coriolanus, King John, Richard II, Henry IV, parts 1 and 2, Henry V, and Richard III. Attention given to sources, to theories of politics current in classical, medieval, and Renaissance Europe (especially Renaissance England), and to the contemporary context of each of the plays. The weight of the course falls on the plays themselves, their structure, their language, their depictions of power, religion, honor and dishonor, individual and society.

title: Shakespeare's History Plays
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Shakespeare's history plays dealing with both the classical world and with England. These include Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, Coriolanus, King John, Richard II, Henry IV, parts 1 and 2, Henry V, and Richard III. title: Shakespeare: The Early Plays
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Shakespeare and Myth
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A consideration of myth criticism and theory (early modern, modern, and postmodern) together with some of the plays (and perhaps also the poetry) of Shakespeare.

title: Ideal Commonwealths of the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in the ideal commonwealths of the Renaissance, including More's Utopia, Shakespeare's The Tempest, Bacon's New Atlantis, selections from Hobbes's Leviathan, selections from Harrington's Oceana, concluding with Mandeville's Fable of the Bees. Some additional readings in political theory of the period, both monarchical and republican, as well as recent work on the emergence of the idea of ^'^'society''. In this course we will address two large questions, one historical, the other literary: (1) why so many ideal commonwealths were written during the early modern period; and (2) what it means to compose political theory in a narrative form.

title: Magic in Medieval and Renaissance Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the ways in which "magic" functions in early English literature. Readings include literary texts traditionally understood as containing magical elements - Beowulf, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Malory's Morte Darthur, Spenser's Faerie Queene, Marlowe's Faustus, Shakespeare's The Tempest - as well as saints' lives from the Golden Legend, miracle plays, and 16th-century court cases that depend on supernatural intervention.

title: 16th-Century Lyric Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An elucidation of 16th-century English lyric in a Continental context. Poets include Petrarch, Wyatt, Philip Sidney, Shakespeare, Spenser, and several lesser figures; the continuous issue is generic experimentation from several distinctive standpoints, but the course recognizes related questions of gender, politics, and culture. Appropriate for graduate level work. Graduate section offered.

title: Shakespearean Conjuring
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In the context of a general survey of Shakespeare's theatrical career, and selected readings in other Elizabethan and Jacobean texts, this course will pay particular attention to the surprisingly frequent scenes depicting conjuring, spirit possession, exorcism, ghostly apparition, and magic. We will examine the historical contexts for these scenes, with selected readings in Early Modern theology, psychology, and medicine, and attempt to get a sense of the fierce controversies in the period over the status of the spirit world. We will also explore the extent to which Shakespeare regarded his own art as a kind of conjuring.

title: Shakespearean Conjuring
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Shakespearean Tragedy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: We will read the succession of tragedies from the early Titus Andronicus and Romeo and Juliet to the late Antony and Cleopatra and Coriolanus, with particular attention to the astonishing sequence of Hamlet, Othello, King Lear, and Macbeth. Part of the course will involve screening and discussion of film, as well as glimpses of modern adaptations. Readings will include theories of tragedy, as well as Shakespearean sources and modern criticism.

title: Shakespearean Tragedy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Exploration of Shakespeare's restless experiments in the varieties of tragedy, from Titus Andronicus to Coriolanus, with particular attention to the astonishing sequence of Hamlet, Othello, King Lear, and Macbeth. Attention to classical and medieval precedents, to such modern theorists as Hegel, Nietzsche, and Benjamin, and to contemporary attempts on stage and in film to revivify Shakespeare's vision.

title: Shakespearean Tragedy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will read the succession of tragedies from the early Titus Andronicus and Romeo and Juliet to the late Antony and Cleopatra and Coriolanus, with particular attention to the astonishing sequence of Hamlet, Othello, King Lear, and Macbeth. Readings will include theories of tragedy, as well as Shakespearean sources and modern criticism. When taken for credit, this course fulfills the departmental Shakespeares Common Ground course requirement. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Shakespearean Tragedy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive reading of the full range of Shakespeare's tragedies from early experiments through masterworks like Hamlet, Lear, Othello, and beyond, with some attention also to their classical and medieval prototypes and to their modern reception/imitation as well as to their unique achievements as expressions of their moment. We shall also consider such broad and critical issus as ``What is tragedy?'', ``What differentiates texts written for performance?'', and ``Why has Shakespeare's work, particularly the tragedies, been so influential?''.

title: Shakespearean Genres
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We'll read major plays from each of the genres in which Shakespeare worked, comparing them with examples from other Renaissance playwrights in hopes of determining to what extent Shakespeare typifies and to what extent he defies generic convention. Readings to include A Midsummer Night's Dream, The Merchant of Venice, Othello, Hamlet, The Winter's Tale, and The Tempest. This course, when taken for a grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Shakespearean Genres
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Over the course of the semester we'll read a broad selection of Shakespeare's plays, taken from every point in his career and from each major genre in which he worked: comedy (A Midsummer Night's Dream, Twelfth Night, Much Ado about Nothing), tragedy (Romeo and Juliet, Othello, Hamlet, Antony and Cleopatra), history (Richard II, Henry IV, Henry V) and ``romance'' (The Winter's Tale, The Tempest, Cymbeline).

title: Early Modern Prose Fictions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of proto-novels and other prose fictions from More's Utopia to Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress in the context of Renaissance and modern theories of prose fiction. Charts a critically unarticulated episode in English literature, with some attention to issues of epistemology, politics, and religion. Includes major Continental contemporaries such as Lazarillo de Tormes, the Heptaméron, Gargantua, and Don Quixote. Graduate section offered.

title: Early Modern Prose Fictions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of proto-novels and other prose fictions from More's Utopia to Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress in the context of Renaissance and modern theories of prose fiction. Charts a critically unarticulated episode in English literature, with some attention to issues of epistemology, politics, and religion. Includes comparative readings in major Continental contemporaries such as Lazarillo de Tormes, the Heptaméron, Gargantua, and Don Quixote. Appropriate for graduate level work. Graduate section offered.

title: Renaissance Drama
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of English drama (1590-1630) and its cultural context. Plays by Marlowe, Jonson, Shakespeare, and Webster, and less familiar writers (Elizabeth Cary, Beaumont and Fletcher, and John Ford). Topics include genre and its social/political implications; gender, disguise, and metamorphosis; sexuality, the state, and the family; conditions and conventions of writing, performance, and printing.

title: Shakespeare and Modern Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Beginning with the premise that Shakespeare makes "modernity," and that modernity makes "Shakespeare," the course considers works that interact with the era of Freud and Marx, Brecht and Beckett, film, contemporary politics, and American popular culture. Readings include Hamlet, King Lear, Macbeth, Coriolanus, Henry V, Othello and The Merchant of Venice--plays that have had a major impact upon notions of character, personality, anomie, gender, sexuality, dissociation, "leadership," and other ideas by which modernity/post-modernity measures identity, selfhood and success.

title: Renaissance Drama: Literature, Economics, and Religion
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: To examine how in Shakespeare's lifetime a secular, commercial aesthetic grew out of and replaced drama's earlier role as an illustration of Christian truths. We'll explore the relationship of religious conviction to financial settlements of all sorts: the final pay-back of a just God's revenge, the moral status of debt, the economic contract regulating guilt, punishment and forgiveness. Readings drawn from Shakespeare, Jonson, Marlowe, the York Mystery cycle, plus Everyman and Mankind.

title: Renaissance Drama: Literature, Economics, and Religion
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: To examine how in Shakespeare's lifetime a secular, commercial aesthetic grew out of and replaced drama's earlier role as an illustration of Christian truths. We'll explore the relationship of religious conviction to financial settlements of all sorts: the final pay-back of a just God's revenge, the moral status of debt, the economic contract regulating guilt, punishment and forgiveness. Readings drawn from Shakespeare, Jonson, Marlowe, the York Mystery cycle, plus Everyman and Mankind.

title: Renaissance Drama: Literature, Economics, and Religion
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We'll read primarily plays by Shakespeare and two contemporaries, Jonson and Marlowe, that focus on the relationship of religious conviction to financial settlements of all sorts: the final payback of a just God's revenge, the moral status of debt, the economic contract regulating guilt, punishment and forgiveness. Readings to include Everyman, The Jew of Malta, Volpone, Bartholemew Fair, The Devil is an Ass, The Merchant of Venice, King Lear, The Comedy of Errors, Measure for Measure. Supplemental readings from the New Testament, Nietzsche, and Marx.

title: The Drama of Shakespeare's Contemporaries
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: To focus on the sort of drama against which Shakespeare's plays competed and by which they were influenced, with particular attention to the period's sub-genres: revenge, tragedy, city comedy, and tragi-comedy. Authors may include Beaumont, Dekker, Kyd, Fletcher, Jonson, Marlowe, Marston, Middleton, Webster. Also included will be a few plays by Shakespeare that seem especially meaningful in this context (Romeo and Juliet, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Richard II, Hamlet).

title: The Metaphysical Poets
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the lives and works of John Donne, Ben Johnson, George Herbert, Andrew Marvell and others, as well as the major critical writing that helped shape the idea of a "metaphysical" style in English verse.

subject: ENGLISH

title: Shakespeare and Identity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Hamlet, Iago, Cleopatra, Prospero: Shakespeare's most beguiling creations are consummate performers, able to engender illusions, enchant other people, and conceal their own motives. What can they teach us about the creation, evolution, or loss of identity? What does it mean to be a person, or to know another person? This course surveys some of Shakespeare's greatest artistic achievements, including Twelfth Night, Macbeth, King Lear, Antony and Cleopatra, The Tempest, the sonnets, and others. This course, when taken for letter grade, meets the Department of English Shakespeares Common Ground requirement.

title: Shakespeare and Identity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Hamlet, Iago, Cleopatra, Prospero: Shakespeare's most beguiling creations are consummate performers, able to engender illusions, enchant other people, and conceal their own motives. What can they teach us about the creation, evolution, or loss of identity? What does it mean to be a person, or to know another person? This course surveys some of Shakespeare's greatest artistic achievements, including Twelfth Night, Macbeth, King Lear, Antony and Cleopatra, The Tempest, the sonnets, and others. This course, when taken for letter grade, meets the Department of English Shakespeares Common Ground requirement.

title: Shakespeare's Rome
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates Shakespeare's lifelong engagement with the literature, politics, and culture of ancient Rome. It will give careful attention to the three "Roman Plays" - Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, and Coriolanus - but will also consider the larger role of classical antiquity in Shakespeare's development and achievement as a dramatist.

title: Shakespeare, and Co.
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in a range of plays written for and performed by the acting company with which Shakespeare was associated. Central issues: the (counter)cultural function of the Renaissance theatre; the economics of the playhouse; the relation of performance and printed texts; the place of Shakespeare, then and now. Includes As You Like It, The Maid's Tragedy, The Merchant of Venice, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Pericles, The Revenger's Tragedy.

title: Shakespearean Tragedy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings of Shakespeare's tragedies, with particular attention to cultural contexts.

title: Imaginary Journeys
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A course about global mobility, encounter, and exchange at the time that Harvard College was founded in 1636. Using the interactive resources of computer technology and drawing upon faculty experts from many disciplines, we follow imaginary voyages of three ships that leave England in 1633. Sites include London's Globe Theatre, Benin, Barbados, Brazil, and Mexico. (Formerly Humanities 27.)

title: Renaissance Narrative in Poetry and Prose
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A course on narrative fiction in the age of Shakespeare. We read mostly erotic narrative poems, including Shakespeare's ``Venus and Adonis,'' Marlowe's ``Hero and Leander,'' and Spenser's ``Legend of Chastity,'' the third book of The Faerie Queene. Some brief examples of the early novel will also be read. We consider Renaissance anxieties about fiction_is it lying_and the emergence of the concept of literature.

title: A Silk Road Course: Travel and Transformation on the High Seas: An Imaginary Journey in the Early 1
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A course about global mobility, encounter, and exchange at the time that Harvard College was founded in 1636. Using the interactive resources of computer technology and drawing upon faculty experts from many disciplines, we follow imaginary voyages of three ships that leave England in 1633. Sites include London's Globe Theatre, Benin, Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Indonesia, Morocco, Istanbul, Venice, Virginia, and Cambridge, Massachusetts. Topics include the slave trade, reconnaissance, colonization, conversion, geography, navigation, and literary culture. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts C. title: The Plays of Christopher Marlowe
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in the dramatic oeuvre of Marlowe, in the context of the many biographical, social, religious, and political questions raised by his life and work. We will be reading Marlowe as a deliberately ^'^'controversial'' or ^'^'heterodox'' writer, whose work seems designed at once to please and to provoke his contemporaries. Readings will include Tamburlaine, Parts One and Two, Doctor Faustus, The Jew of Malta, Edward II, Dido Queen of Carthage, The Massacre at Paris, in addition to critical essays on the plays.

title: The Plays of Christopher Marlowe
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in the dramatic oeuvre of Marlowe, in the context of the many biographical, social, religious, and political questions raised by his life and work. We will be reading Marlowe as a deliberately ^'^'controversial'' or ^'^'heterodox'' writer, whose work seems designed at once to please and to provoke his contemporaries. Readings will include Tamburlaine, Parts One and Two, Doctor Faustus, The Jew of Malta, Edward II, Dido Queen of Carthage, The Massacre at Paris, in addition to critical essays on the plays.

title: Fictions of Kin and Kind in the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The literature of kinship, with special attention to the incest taboo, the human-animal distinction, and the politics of nationhood. Readings include modern theorists as well as Elizabeth Tudor, Marguerite of Navarre, Rabelais, Cervantes, Luther, Montaigne, Webster, James I, and Shakespeare.

title: Theater, Dream, Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course considers theories of dream and theater from Shakespeare's time to the modern era. We will also read three Shakespearean dream plays - A Midsummer Night's Dream, Macbeth, and The Winter's Tale - in immediate conjunction with the ART fall season of productions based on those plays. We will ask how concepts like source, adaptation, translation, and performance function in theater as well as in dream, and examine how such concepts apply to Shakespeare. When taken for credit, this course fulfills the departmental Shakespeares Common Ground Course requirement. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding, or the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Theater, Dream, Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course considers theories of dream and theater from Shakespeare's time to the modern era. We will also read three Shakespearean dream plays - A Midsummer Night's Dream, Macbeth, and The Winter's Tale - in immediate conjunction with the ART fall season of productions based on those plays. We will ask how concepts like source, adaptation, translation, and performance function in theater as well as in dream, and examine how such concepts apply to Shakespeare. When taken for credit, this course fulfills the departmental Shakespeares Common Ground Course requirement. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding, or the Core area requirement for Literature and Arts A.

title: Some Uses of Renaissance Pastoral
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Shepherds, shepherdesses and other topics of the pastoral mode are everywhere in Early Modern literature, sometimes imagining Golden Age ideality but often figuring (according to contemporaries) persons and events too dangerous to treat directly. We examine the place and uses of pastoral in a number of genres: songs, eclogues, funeral elegy, romance, landscape poems, country-house poems, prose romance (Sidney's Arcadia), epic (Spenser's Faerie Queene VI; Milton's Eden) and drama (Shakespeare's As You Like It).

title: Some Uses of Renaissance Pastoral
subject: ENGLISH

title: Shakespeare in Slow Motion: Conference Course
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close reading of four or five plays by Shakespeare. Participants will be expected to familiarize themselves with the critical, historical, and editorial questions provoked by these plays, and to read some ancillary criticism and theory, but the seminar will focus on an intensive ("slow reading") attention to the text, including, but not limited to, questions of imagery, symbolism, allegorization, philology, nuance, gesture, and affect. Preference given to undergraduates who have taken a previous course in Shakespeare. Open to all graduate students in English and Comparative Literature without prerequisite.

title: Economy of Literature in the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Interrelations among political economy, literature, and the arts in 16th-century England. Special attention to the printer's press and moneyer's mint, language and money as systems of representation and exchange, revenge drama and commerce, and economic and sexual production and reproduction. Texts by Shakespeare, Montaigne, Bacon, King James, Queen Elizabeth, and others. Contemporary theoretical and historical views.

subject: ENGLISH

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

subject: ENGLISH

title: 17th-Century Poetry and Prose
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines a wide range of poets and prose writers, men and women, in a cultural milieu (1600-1660) extraordinarily rich in literary achievement and intellectual ferment. Primary attention to four major poets Donne, Jonson, Herbert, and Marvell and to the development of genres (love poetry, religious meditation, essay, others) for analyzing the literary self.

title: John Milton: An Introduction to his Life and to Paradise Lost
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course is an introduction to the work of John Milton, including Paradise Lost, Paradise Regained, and Samson Agonistes, as well as the major prose on questions of religion, politics, and censorship.

courseDescriptionLong: Examines most of the English poetry of John Milton, and his most important prose tracts. Paradise Lost receives extended treatment. Graduate section offered.

title: Milton

title: Milton
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A comprehensive study of Milton's works and their milieu. Included are his lyric poems and masque, his polemic tracts on marriage and divorce, a free press, and republican government written during the Puritan Revolution, his epics, and the tragedy Samson Agonistes. Paradise Lost will receive extended treatment.

courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Milton's life and poetry, with emphasis on his epic poem, Paradise Lost. Milton will be studied in relation to the events of his day, in particular, the English revolution, but also in relation to later English poets, especially the romantics.
