title: Deconstruction and Feminism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the intersection of deconstructive and feminist critical theories. How does deconstruction contribute to our understanding of feminism and how might feminist theory offer critical revisions of deconstruction? Examines Derrida's work on sexual difference and then explores diverse responses by a number of critics, including Culler, Fuss, Jardine, Johnson, Kamuf, Kofman, Spivak, and others.

title: Introduction to Advanced Literary Study
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Meta-issues in literary criticism, with readings in critical, philosophical, and literary texts. The course provides an overview of the theoretical and methodological aspects of what we do when we talk about literature. The goal is not to learn what others have said but to help students orient themselves in the field of literary study. Designed for sophomores interested in concentrating in English or other literature-based fields, but all students are welcome.

title: Introduction to Advanced Literary Study

title: The English Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the English novel from its birth to its prime, with readings in one history of the ^'^'rise'' of the novel and various accounts of its characteristic forms and concerns. Authors will include Defoe, Fielding, Austen, Brontë, Dickens, Hardy, Forster, and Woolf.

title: The English Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of the English novel from its origins to the early twentieth century, with an emphasis on different critical accounts of its ``rise'' and form. Novels by Defoe, Behn, Richardson, Austen, Brontë, Dickens, Eliot, Conrad, Woolf.

subject: ENGLISH

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close reading and translation of the poem in the original Old English. At the same time, questions of literary structure, themes, rhetoric, and the cultural, historical, mythical, and religious backgrounds are considered. English 200a or equivalent.

classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intended for those who have taken English 200a or who have an adequate reading knowledge of Old English poetry. The entire poem read in the original; emphasis on close study and accurate translation of the text, though questions of literary structure, religious tone, heroic sources, and historical relations are also considered.

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A careful reading of Beowulf in Old English. In addition to in-class translation, the course will explore sources, the question of date and authorship, the oral traditional background, poetics, and other topics of current interest. One semester of Old English or the equivalent.

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intended for those who have taken English 200a or who have an adequate reading knowledge of Old English poetry. The entire poem read in the original; emphasis on close study and accurate translation of the text, though questions of literary structure, religious tone, heroic sources, and historical relations are also considered.

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close reading and translation of the poem in the original Old English. At the same time, questions of literary structure, themes, rhetoric, and the cultural, historical, mythical, and religious backgrounds are considered.

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A careful reading of Beowulf in Old English. In addition to in-class translation, the course will explore sources, the question of date and authorship, the oral traditional background, poetics, and other topics of current interest. One semester of Old English or the equivalent.

title: Beowulf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Beowulf

title: How to Read an Old English Poem: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Moving through a number of poems set for translation, we will examine the act of reading for the earliest readers of vernacular English. Topics will include metrical scansion, verse syntax, principles of editing, and cognitive theory. One semester of Old English or its equivalent.

title: How to Read an Old English Poem: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Advanced Topics in Old English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: For students who have a reading knowledge of Old English, this seminar will build upon that competence and offer new directions to pursue. While translation will be a mainstay of each week's meeting, the specific shape of the syllabus will depend on student preference. Potential topics include paleography, manuscript study, meter, verse syntax, and alliterative prose; students are encouraged to come with their own topics to pursue.

title: Studies in Frisian Language and Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The Frisian language, the closest linguistic relative of English, is attested from early medieval runic inscriptions onward, though manuscripts survive from about 1200 onward; its "Old" period extends down to ca. 1550. Significant cultural connections existed between Frisia and England from the earliest period. The Old Frisian language is introduced and culturally and linguistically significant Frisian texts are studied.

title: Images, Idolatry and Iconoclasm, 1350-1600: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Images find a very direct way into the depths of the psyche; they provoke bothlove and fear. Through literary texts, we examine the function of images from the fourteenth to the sixteenth centuries, in both erotic and religious traditions.

title: Introduction to Runology
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The native writing system known as runes is usually studied by linguists for its contribution to the early history of Old English, Old Norse, and the other Germanic languages. But the texts and monuments have as well great cultural interest for historians of art, society and literature. The course will survey the field with special emphasis on non-linguistic matters. Previous training of one semester of Old English or another Germanic language at the ^'^'old'' level.

title: Introduction to Runology
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The native writing system known as runes is usually studied by linguists for its contribution to the early history of Old English, Old Norse, and the other Germanic languages. title: Beowulf and its Contexts: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The contexts include the literary-historical (for example, sources and analogues; genre; oral tradition), the codicological (including the contribution of recent paleography to dating the poem), the metrical (including poetics generally), and the philological (language, text, specific cruces). Plenty of room will be saved for interpretation of several kinds (which might include religion, myth, politics, the poem's value to audiences of various periods). A third hour of basic translation to be arranged for interested students. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Early Women Writers: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the vexed but persistent fact of premodern female authorship in twelve poets, sibyls, visionaries, martyrs, institution-builders, and women of letters from Hildegard (d.1179) to Behn (d.1689), read in their literary, intellectual, and cultural contexts.

title: Early English Women Writers - Julian of Norwich and Margery Kempe: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive study of two visionary writers and their context. Besides A Revelation of Love and The Book of Margery Kempe, we will read other contemporary works, including The Scale of Perfection and The Cloud of Unknowing.

title: Early English Women Writers - Julian of Norwich and Margery Kempe: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive study of two visionary writers and their context. Besides A Revelation of Love and The Book of Margery Kempe, we will read other contemporary works, including The Scale of Perfection and The Cloud of Unknowing.

title: Heroic poetry and its afterlife in saga: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: After an introductory tour of the heroic (and heroic-elegiac) poetry in Old English, Old Norse, and Old High German, we will read selections from the Icelandic saga literature with the problem of continuity in mind.

title: Elegy in Old English and Old Norse: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Compares various manifestations of "elegy,'' especially in the Early Medieval period. Interest in Medieval Latin or the Celtic literatures is welcome, but the focus is on early Germanic. Philology, literary criticism, poetics, and genre theory, along with literary history, are the disciplines implicit in the seminar's central project, but students of Old English and Old Norse can also explore their fields more generally. Students need not have a reading knowledge of both Old English and Old Norse, and some reading can be done in translation.

title: Heroic poetry and its afterlife in saga: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

subject: ENGLISH

title: Elegy, Medieval and Modern: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How useful and valid is the label "elegy"? Medieval texts in Old and Middle English, medieval Latin, Norse, Irish, and Welsh will be combined with a "modern" component, including English classics (e.g., Lycidas) and folk poetry. Open to qualified undergraduates with instructor approval. Readings in translation or in the original.

title: Elegy, Medieval and Modern: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How useful and valid is the label "elegy"? Open to qualified undergraduates with instructor approval. Readings in translation or in the original.

title: Community and Agency in Middle English Literature: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates late-medieval literature's fascination with religious, political, and social communities, and the portrayal of individual agents within, against, or as representatives of those communities. Authors include Chaucer, Langland, the Gawain-Poet, Mandeville, and Margery Kempe.

title: Adam and Eve: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores representations of Adam and Eve's Fall 1400-1700, with an emphasis on differing constraints and possibilities of the verbal and visual arts. Texts include bible and bible commentaries, medieval mystery plays, and 17th century poetry, especially Milton. Artists include Bosch and Dürer. Co-taught with Joseph Koerner.

title: Old English Heroic Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A detailed study of all the poetry usually called "heroic" in the Anglo-Saxon language, including Widsith, Deor, Beowulf, Finnsburg, and Waldhere fragments, and the remains of heroic eulogy. History, tribal geography, legend formation and development, and philology of the old English texts are among the subjects considered. English 200b or permission of instructor.

subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: Problems in the poetics, style, sources, and interpretation of Anglo-Saxon verse. English 200b or permission of instructor.

classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Moments of great historical and cultural change in literate societies are always accompanied by the isolation of exemplary figures whose suffering, exemplary, and memorialised lives (and deaths) bear the marks of that change.

title: Early Middle English: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Post-Conquest literature in England witnessed the formation of new linguistic and national identities. At times retrospective and nostalgic, at times innovative, it was a period of ambivalence on many levels. We will read through a variety of genres, with facing page translations for the more difficult texts, but always with attention to the language. Texts include Lawman’s Brut, The Owl and the Nightingale, various lyrics, the South English Legendary, Sir Orfeo, Dame Sirith, and others.

subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: Concentrates on early Middle English and some of the more difficult later texts. English 115a or 115b or an equivalent course in Chaucer.

title: Queer/Medieval
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: The / in this course title can suggest a slippage or interchangeability; opposition and polarization; or (in fanfiction tagging conventions) erotic or romantic friction between two entities. This course functions as an introduction to queer theory as an intellectual tool with which to read texts far removed from the political, cultural, and social discourses from which queer theory emerged. We will ask: what can queer theory offer readers of medieval literature  in its explorations of gender, sexuality, power, narrative, trauma, and time? We will read a range of foundational and cutting-edge queer theorists including but not limited to Judith Butler, José Esteban Muñoz, Lee Edelman, Eve Sedgwick, and Carolyn Dinshaw, alongside texts from the European Middle Ages (roughly 500-1500), in Middle English or in translation. These texts may include Aelred of Rievaulx’s Rule of Life for a Recluse, Thomas of Monmouth’s The Life and Miracles of William of Norwich, The Book of Margery Kempe, the poems of Baudri of Bourgeuil, the letters of Abelard and Heloise, and more.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A study of medieval literary canon-formation through history, from Chaucer's self-canonization to the early modern and modern search for alternative origins to the English literary tradition from the ballad to The Book of Margery Kempe.

title: Chaucer: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Concentrates on a computer-assisted analysis of Chaucer's language and style. English 115a and 115b or their equivalents; a reading knowledge of French; an elementary acquaintance with computers is helpful.

title: The Making of the Early English Canon 1350-1950: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of medieval literary canon-formation through history, from Chaucer's self-canonization to the early modern and modern search for alternative origins to the English literary tradition from the ballad to The Book of Margery Kempe.

title: Chaucer and Gower: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Emphasis is on computer-assisted studies of language and style, as they relate to major critical issues.

title: Alliterative Poetry in Middle English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study, in historical and literary context, of the 14th-century poems of the non-Chaucerian tradition, including Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Piers Plowman, Pearl, and the Morte Arthure.

title: Alliterative Poetry in Middle English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study, in historical and literary context, of the 14th-century poems of the non-Chaucerian tradition, including Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Piers Plowman, Pearl, and the Morte Arthure.

title: Alliterative Poetry in Middle English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Alliterative Poetry in Middle English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study, in historical and literary context, of the 14th-century poems of the non-Chaucerian tradition, including Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Piers Plowman, Pearl, and the Morte Arthure.

title: Late Medieval English Literature and Public Culture: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We explore works that transcend the familiar opposition of elite-popular, clerical-lay, male-female, and appeal to a general national audience: the many rather than the few. We take Middle English works such as Piers Plowman, Mandeville's Travels, and the Book of Margery Kempe and compare them with other contemporary discourses and practices such as the art in English parish churches and the civic institutions of London.

title: Late Medieval English Literature and Public Culture: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We explore works that transcend the familiar opposition of elite-popular, clerical-lay, male-female, and appeal to a general national audience: the many rather than the few. We take Middle English works such as Piers Plowman, Mandeville's Travels, and the Book of Margery Kempe and compare them with other contemporary discourses and practices such as the art in English parish churches and the civic institutions of London.

title: Spenser and the Fictional Narratives of the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of prose fiction and fictional poetic narrative in the 16th and, more briefly, the 17th centuries. Readings from Apuleius, More, Gascoigne, Sidney, Deloney, Nashe, Greene; some attention to the novella in English story collections (and to representative continental novellas); a coda on Margaret Cavendish and Aphra Behn.

title: Spenser and the Fictional Narratives of the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of prose fiction and fictional poetic narrative in the 16th and, more briefly, the 17th centuries. Readings from Apuleius, More, Gascoigne, Sidney, Deloney, Nashe, Greene; some attention to the novella in English story collections (and to representative continental novellas); a coda on Margaret Cavendish and Aphra Behn.

title: Spenser and Milton's Continental Sources: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will read (in translation) Italian epic poems by Boiardo, Ariosto, and Tasso. We will also read Camoens' Portugese epic, The Lusiads. Participants must know The Faerie Queene and Paradise Lost.

title: Poetry and Belief: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the use of vernacular poetry as a vehicle for religious thought 1200-1500, with forays into later periods. How does poetry think, feel, convey, incarnate belief, devotion, skepticism? Is didactic poetry still poetry or only 'verse' and what would be the difference? Texts: French and English lyrics; Grosseteste's Chateau d'amour; Pearl, Cleanness, Patience; Langland's Piers Plowman; Hoccleve's Series.

title: Poetry and Belief: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the use of vernacular poetry as a vehicle for religious thought 1200-1500, with forays into later periods. How does poetry think, feel, convey, incarnate belief, devotion, skepticism? Is didactic poetry still poetry or only 'verse' and what would be the difference? Texts: French and English lyrics; Grosseteste's Chateau d'amour; Pearl, Cleanness, Patience; Langland's Piers Plowman; Hoccleve's Series.

title: Chaucer: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar concentrates on The Legend of Good Women. English 115a and English 115b, or their equivalents.

title: English Poetry 1590-1674: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course follows English poetry the first installment of Spenser's Faerie Queene to the second edition of Paradise Lost. Donne, Jonson, Herrick, Crashaw, Herbert, Marvell will be read. The English Spenserians--Browne, Drummond, Giles and Phineas Fletcher--will be observed, as will Denham, Wither, and Davenant. How should we characterize such a period historically?

title: English Poetry 1590-1674: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course follows English poetry the first installment of Spenser's Faerie Queene to the second edition of Paradise Lost. Donne, Jonson, Herrick, Crashaw, Herbert, Marvell will be read. The English Spenserians--Browne, Drummond, Giles and Phineas Fletcher--will be observed, as will Denham, Wither, and Davenant. How should we characterize such a period historically?

title: Late Medieval and Early Tudor Literature: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An attempt to make some sense of the period in the history of English literature which is at once most neglected, amorphous, and creative. Special attention given to Malory and the development of romance, the morality plays and mystery plays, and the beginnings of renewed European influence. Wyatt and Surrey as well as the Scots poets.

title: Shakespeare at Work: The Playwright and His Sources: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigation of Shakespeare's cunning relation to his sources, in the context of a larger question: what counts as a source?

title: Shakespeare at Work: The Playwright and His Sources: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigation of Shakespeare's cunning relation to his sources, in the context of a larger question: what counts as a source?

title: Medieval Art and Literature: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Literature and painting may render the same subject matter, adhere to similar structural and formal principles, experiment in related ways with representation, and seek to promote the same view of the world. Examines parallels that may usefully be drawn, concentrating on medieval English literature and related art.

title: Medieval Art and Literature: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the study of relationships between art and literature in the Middle Ages: how painting and poetry render the same subjects, operate according to comparable formal and structural principles, experiment in similar ways with representation, serve a common cause. Literary parallels drawn from late medieval English writing (especially Chaucer) and from non-English works in translation.

title: Institutionalization of Memory: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Medieval and Renaissance memory systems: textual, administrative, oral, religious. Hamlet is a central text. Also considers aspects of the subject before and after its principal time frame: e.g., memory in classical antiquity or in modern times (such as the "Holocaust Memorial Museum").

title: Cultural Mobility in Early Modern England
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will be taught in conjunction with a general education course (English 127: Travel and Transformation on the High Seas). It will concern itself with global mobility, encounter, and exchange in the late 16th and early 17th centuries. Topics include the slave trade, reconnaissance,colonization, conversion, navigation, and geography, as these are reflected and refracted in literary culture. The central literary works will include four Shakespeare plays, along with texts by Spenser, Ralegh, Jonson, Donne, Milton, and Behn. The theoretical focus will be the emerging field of "mobility studies." And the seminar will have a sustained pedagogical interest: how is it possible, it will ask, to use recent perspectives on cultural discourses and on the cognitive role of the imagination to generate new and inventive undergraduate courses?

title: Cultural Mobility in Early Modern England

title: Shakespeare's Creative Development (Graduate Seminar in General Education): Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How can Shakespeare be taught to undergraduates as a developing artist, solving problems from one play to the next? The seminar will design and develop a General Education course on these themes for undergraduates

title: Shakespeare's Creative Development (Graduate Seminar in General Education): Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How can Shakespeare be taught to undergraduates as a developing artist, solving problems from one play to the next? The seminar will design and develop a General Education course on these themes for undergraduates

title: Shakespeare's Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Topics: The song-within-a-play; Shakespearean narrative verse, comic and tragic; sonnets in the plays; sonnets in a sequence; sonnets standing alone. Eros as dissonance; the aesthetics of the eye; the deceptiveness of representation; dilation and delay; antithetical models of life. Prosody of the songs, sonnets, and narratives. Shakespearean figuration.

title: Shakespeare's Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Topics: The song-within-a-play; Shakespearean narrative verse, comic and tragic; sonnets in the plays; sonnets in a sequence; sonnets standing alone. Eros as dissonance; the aesthetics of the eye; the deceptiveness of representation; dilation and delay; antithetical models of life. Prosody of the songs, sonnets, and narratives. Shakespearean figuration.

title: Repetition and Revenge: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The dynamic of repetition is the dynamic of revenge: the ghost, the clue, the trace, the compulsion to repeat. Drawing on selected works of Freud and contemporary literary theory, this course examines Elizabethan and Jacobean revenge tragedies and the plays of Shakespeare together with relevant modern works of drama, fiction, history, film, and video.

title: Repetition and Revenge: Graduate Seminar

title: The Secularization of English Drama (900-1642): Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: To cover three main areas: philosophies of secularization (Dialectic of Enlightenment, Legitimacy of the Modern Age); current scholarly debates over the secularization of English drama; and play texts themselves, from medieval to Renaissance.

title: The Secularization of English Drama (900-1642): Graduate Seminar

title: Renaissance Life Studies: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A graduate level seminar of Renaissance life studies.

title: Renaissance Life Studies: Graduate Seminar

title: Renaissance Life Studies: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What is an author? Examination of the biographies of Early Modern writers and the uses we can make of these lives in literary and cultural interpretation. Writers may include More, Spenser, Marlowe, Shakespeare, Donne, among others.

title: Renaissance Life Studies: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What is an author? Examination of the biographies of Early Modern writers and the uses we can make of these lives in literary and cultural interpretation. Writers may include More, Spenser, Marlowe, Shakespeare, Donne, among others.

title: Lifelikeness: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This central topos of Renaissance art and literary theory refers to many different discourses (rhetoric/agency, ingenium/style, phenomenology, natural philosophy, gender/fetishism, theology, etc.). The seminar will focus on strategies of 'animation' in art and literature.

title: Economics of Exchange in Shakespeare's Comedies
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Lifelikeness: Graduate Seminar

title: Shakespeare's Sonnets: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the Sonnets of Shakespeare as experimental poetry. Topics: similarity and difference (in tropes, structures, registers of language); strategies of thematic management (reductive, expansive, parodic, etc.); aspectual and sequential poetry; the sonnet tradition in Europe and England; the construction of personae; musicality.

title: Shakespeare's Sonnets: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the Sonnets of Shakespeare as experimental poetry. Topics: similarity and difference (in tropes, structures, registers of language); strategies of thematic management (reductive, expansive, parodic, etc.); aspectual and sequential poetry; the sonnet tradition in Europe and England; the construction of personae; musicality.

title: Reading Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close readings of Hamlet, Measure for Measure, and The Merchant of Venice with special attention to sources and influences, the history of criticism, and contemporary perspectives. Problems in the theory of literary and economic representation and exchange are one main focus.

title: The New Historicism: The Example of Shakespeare: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The aim is at once to explore, to criticize, and to practice the new historicism in relation to Shakespeare. The purpose is not to arrive at a definitive body of methodological precepts, but to consider the institutional and individual practices that have led to distinctive recent work on history, ideology, representation, and textuality.

title: Shakespearean  Transformations
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: We will investigate both Shakespeare's relation to his sources and the transformation of his plays over the subsequent centuries and in different cultures.

title: Shakespearean Transformations
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: We will investigate both Shakespeare's relation to his sources and the transformation of his plays over the subsequent centuries and in different cultures.

title: Unfamiliar Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: What could be unfamiliar about Shakespeare, the dramatist whose works, are benchmark of literary quality and human wisdom, an author whose name is synonymous with “greatness” and whose words are quoted, and misquoted,  every day? This seminar will approach the idea of “unfamiliar Shakespeare” in three ways: 1) by looking at plays that are not part of the usual classroom canon, like the Henry VI plays, King John, Timon of Athens and Henry VIII, as well as poems like “Venus and Adonis,” “The Rape of Lucrece,”  and “The Phoenix and the Turtle.”; 2) concurrently, by considering theoretical concepts (“defamiliarization,” “the uncanny,” “différance,” “the alienation effect,” etc.) in their relationship to Shakespeare; and 3) by discussing trends in recent production, like cross-casting, temporal displacement and immersive theater.

title: Shakespeare and Myth: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A consideration of myth criticism and theory (early modern, modern, postmodern) together with Shakespeare's plays.

title: Shakespeare and Myth: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A consideration of myth criticism and theory (early modern, modern, postmodern) together with Shakespeare's plays.

title: Heroes: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: ^'^'Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.'' This ambivalent dictum, is the starting point for an examination of the cultural fantasy of ^'^'greatness'' and its self-fulfilling prophecy, the ^'^'tragic fall.'' Explores the complex relationship of heroes to memory, nostalgia, the overestimation of the object, and the ^'^'fall.''

title: Problems in Shakespearean Interpretation: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Issues and contexts in the contemporary theory and criticism of Shakespeare. A detailed consideration of several major plays. Special attention to questions opened by materialism, deconstruction, psychoanalysis, new historicism, feminism and gender studies, book history, theories of performance, cultural studies, and other ways of reading and interpreting.

title: Problems in Shakespearean Interpretation: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Issues and contexts in the contemporary theory and criticism of Shakespeare. A detailed consideration of several major plays. Special attention to questions opened by new historicism, materialism, deconstruction, psychoanalysis, feminism and gender studies, cultural studies, and other ways of reading and interpreting.

title: Shakespearean Criticism and Theory: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Problems in Shakespearean Interpretation: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Issues and contexts in the contemporary theory and criticism of Shakespeare. A detailed consideration of several major plays, including Hamlet, Macbeth, and The Tempest. Special attention to questions opened by feminism, new historicism, materialism, deconstructionism, psychoanalysis, cultural studies, and other poststructuralist ways of reading and interpreting.

title: The Hamlet Complex
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Hamlet is the most canonical work by English literature's most canonical writer. What is it about this play that has made it the focus of so much critical and cultural attention? The seminar will consider readings of Hamlet (and Hamlet) from Freud to feminism, from humanism to postculturalism and deconstruction, together with selected films, dramatic adaptations and related poetry and fiction, in an attempt to pluck out the heart of the play's mystery.

title: The Hamlet Complex

title: The Hamlet Complex
subject: ENGLISH

title: Magic Theater: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A consideration of Renaissance drama and 20th century literary and cultural theory in the context of early modern, modern, and postmodern theories of magic: alchemy, astrology, ghosts and fairies, letters and characters, magic words, and the power of language to undermine, reify, transform, embody, and entrap.

title: Texts, Fragments, and Reconstructions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores the history and theory of fragments from antiquity to the present day, with a focus on the literature of the early modern period (1350-1700). The central question will be how writers and readers of different historical moments respond to incomplete or unfinished works, and how those responses inform current approaches to restoration, conservation, and the preservation of the past, from ancient shreds of papyrus to modern digital archives. We will examine the status of the unfinished in literature vis-a-vis other art forms and trace discussions of remnants and pieces through authors and artists such as Sappho, Ovid, Michelangelo, Spenser, Coleridge, Pound, Auden, and de Kooning.

title: Early Modern Curiosity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores uses of, and attitudes towards, curiosity in early modern texts and images. Demonized throughout the Middle Ages, curiosity was legitimized through a process sometimes thought coterminous with modernity. Category of both production and consumption, curiosity shaped practices and institutions of science, religion, philosophy, and the arts. Will examine frictions and collaboration between curiosity in the said and the seen.

title: Shakespeare and Authority: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Though written for a state-censored theater, Shakespeare's plays boldly explore the nature and limits of authority. Special focus on the tragedies, supplemented by readings in both Renaissance (Filmer, Hobbes, etc.) and contemporary (Schmitt, Agamben, etc.) political theory.

title: Contextualizing Renaissance Women's Writing: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Seeks appropriate contexts - historical, theoretical, political, generic, biographical, and especially related literary and subliterary texts - to help assess the cultural and literary significance of newly or rediscovered writings by Early Modern women. Writers include Queen Elizabeth, the Countess of Pembroke, Lucy Countess of Bedford, Clifford, Lanyer, Cary, Speght, Wroth, Douglas, Philips, the Duchess of Newcastle.

subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: Seminar considers the emergence and development of several kinds of narrative (poetry and prose) in the English Renaissance, in the light of Renaissance genre theory, contemporary theories of narrative, and classical and Continental models. Primary attention given to: Sidney's Old and New Arcadia, Spenser's Faerie Queene, Wroth's Urania, Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress.

title: Fictions of Kin and Kind: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The literature and rhetoric of kinship. Special attention to the incest taboo, orphanhood, the human-animal distinction, and social fictions of nationhood. Readings include texts by modern theorists of language as well as by Sophocles, Marguerite of Navarre, Elizabeth Tudor, Cervantes, Shakespeare, Racine, Schiller, Goethe, Melville, and Nabokov.

title: Fictions of Kin and Kind in the Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Moving from theories of kinship as unknowable, hence ambiguously fictive, weconsider the ideas of nationhood, friendship, human-animal kind, adoption,orphanhood, incest, universal siblinghood, and marriage. Shakespeare,Marguerite of Navarre, Elizabeth I, Rabelais, Cardoso, Cervantes, Sperone,Webster, Luther, Sanchez, and Montaigne.

title: Shakespeare and New Historicism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will begin by reading current critiques of new historicist methodology and assess these critiques in relation to interpretations of Shakespeare. Students will select a play or plays and interpret them in relation to other Elizabethan or Jacobean discursive practices.

title: Edmund Spenser: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Spenser’s poetry, concentrating on The Faerie Queene. We will examine questions concerning the theory of allegory, the nature of romance, the place of thinking in poetry, and the tension in Spenser’s work, present, because of him, in almost all subsequent English poetry, between personal expression, social structure, and cosmic order.

title: Spenser: Graduate Seminar

classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Spenser's poetry, concentrating on The Faerie Queene. We discuss such problems as the theory of allegory and the question of poetic thinking.

title: Reading "Material" in Early Modern England
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Returns to early editions of familiar Renaissance texts, reading these as "material artifacts'' and resituating textual production and reception historically. Also retheorizes important issues for literary study generally; textual property, materiality, originality, multiple versions, modern editing (and its politics), theories of the author, the work, the corpus. Treats several genres.

title: Reading "Material" in Early Modern England: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Returns to early editions of familiar Renaissance texts, reading these as "material artifacts" and resituating textual production and reception historically. Also retheorizes important issues for literary study generally: textual property, materiality, originality, multiple versions, modern editing (and its politics), theories of the author, the work, the corpus. Treats several genres.

title: 20th Century Drama: Theory & Texts: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Major 20th-century texts, approached through close analysis of the texts themselves, and readings in their theoretical and literary-historical contexts. Plays by Beckett, Churchill, Kane, Kushner, O'Neill, Parks, Pinter, Shaw, Stoppard, Wilde, and Yeats.

title: Divine Comedies: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A study of four poetic and/or visionary works written 1300-1400: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy, John of Morigny's Book of Flowers, Julian of Norwich's Revelation of Love, and William Langland's Piers Plowman. We consider the inter-relationship between the poetic and the visionary in light of the categories of "orthodoxy" and "discretion of spirits" during a period when both were fiercely contested.

title: Authorship, Genre, and Culture, 1603-1640: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores various concepts of authorship and the multiple genres emerging within institutions promoting Jacobean and Caroline culture (e.g., court, church, theater, city of London, patronage and coterie circles). Focus on Donne, Johnson, Herbert, Bacon, Wroth, and others.

title: Authorship, Genre, and Culture in Early Modern England
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar will explore various concepts of authorship in several genres of poetry and prose in the Early Modern period. We will consider how and why certain kinds of works emerge within or are prompted by various institutions and circumstances, giving special attention to how authors themselves represented authorship and their own roles as authors. Primary attention to Sidney, Donne, Johnson, Herbert, Wroth, and Milton.

title: Authorship, Genre, and Culture in Early Modern England
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar will explore various concepts of authorship in several genres of poetry and prose in the Early Modern period. We will consider how and why certain kinds of works emerge within or are prompted by various institutions and circumstances, giving special attention to how authors themselves represented authorship and their own roles as authors. Primary attention to Sidney, Donne, Johnson, Herbert, Wroth, and Milton.

title: Authorship, Genre, and Culture, 1603-1640: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores various concepts of authorship and the multiple genres emerging within institutions promoting Jacobean and Caroline culture (e.g., court, church, theater, city of London, patronage and coterie circles). Focus on Donne, Johnson, Herbert, Bacon, Wroth, and others.

title: Metaphysical Poetry: The Seventeenth-Century Lyric and Beyond
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: In an age of scientific and political revolution, how do poets respond when common beliefs about God, humans, cosmic and social order, consciousness, and gender have been taken away? Modern poetry starts in the seventeenth century when poets, notably women poets, sought new grounds for poetic expression.

title: Authorship and the Sites of Literary Production, 1603-40: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Reading several male and female authors including Donne, Jonson, Wroth, and Herbert, we explore what ideas of authorship and audience and what genres arise at specific sites--court, church, City of London, landed estates, coteries, domestic household.

title: Authorship and the Sites of Literary Production, 1603-40: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Reading several male and female authors including Donne, Jonson, Wroth, and Herbert, we will explore what ideas of authorship and audience and what genres arise at specific sites--court, church, City of London, landed estates, coteries, domestic household.

title: Literary Kinds and Cultural Forces, 1603-1640: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: With primary focus on Donne, Jonson, Herbert and Mary Wroth, and attention to other male and female writers in a wide range of literary and popular genres, this seminar will examine how and why these works and kinds emerge within certain important sites of cultural production: the court, the church, the city of London, the landed estate, the household, patronage circles, coteries. A central issue is, how such genres and texts are affected by, and how they affect, cultural norms and institutions in Jacobean and Caroline England.

title: Literary Kinds and Cultural Forces, 1603-1640: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

A central issue is, how such genres and texts are affected by, and how they affect, cultural norms and institutions in Jacobean and Caroline England.

title: The Jacobean Era: Literary Kinds and Cultural Forces: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the interplay between generic norms and cultural forces during the Jacobean era (1603-1625). Special attention to court masque, verse epistle, love lyric, and occasional poetry, among other genres; to the oeuvre of Ben Jonson and John Donne; and to several noncanonical texts by Jacobean women.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: With primary focus on Donne, Jonson, Herbert and Mary Wroth, and attention to other male and female writers in a wide range of literary and popular genres, this seminar will examine how and why these works and kinds emerge within certain important sites of cultural production: the court, the church, the city of London, the landed estate, the household, patronage circles, coteries. A central issue is, how such genres and texts are affected by, and how they affect, cultural norms and institutions in Jacobean and Caroline England.

title: Trans-Reformation English Writing: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: English literary history shies away from one of cultural history's most momentous revolutions: the Reformation. This course looks to a series of discursive areas (e.g. literature, theology, politics) to shape that literary history. We will look to both canonical and non-canonical texts, from Chaucer to Shakespeare; each session will be grounded in a Houghton-possessed book.

title: The Poetry of W.B. Yeats: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the complete lyric poetry of W.B. Yeats. Emphasis on generic and formal innovation, within the context of inventing an Irish national literature.

title: Yeats: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will focus on the poetry of Yeats. Emphasis will be on a careful, sequential study of the poems, attending to questions of form, tradition, ``modernism,'' as well as to the historical and biographical forces at work throughout the career. Two papers and an oral presentation required.

title: The Poetry of W.B. Yeats: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: The Poetry of W.B. Yeats: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: 19th-Century Poetry and Modernity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will consider the way 19th-century poetry defined its own "modernity", pairing such writers as Browning and Felicia Hemans, Tennyson and Jean Ingelow, Swinburne and Michael Field. Analyses of modernity by prose writers of the time - Arnold, Ruskin, Pater - will be related to 20th-century theories of urban culture - Simmel, Benjamin, Adorno.

title: Seeing Things in the Enlightenment: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar on eighteenth-century novels and their philosophical surrounds situates itself at a crossroads where the histories of epistemology, the senses, and belief (both in God and in fictions) intersect. The Enlightenment described itself as the moment when an educated populace, weaned from superstition, would begin to see the world in its true colors: knowledge was to replace credulity. Our task will be to investigate its writers' investment in replaying the benighted, "Gothic" delusions they were meant to have put behind them. Our readings will encompass novels by Defoe, Lennox, Walpole, Radcliffe, and others, which we'll read alongside eighteenth-century philosophy of mind, philosophy of religion, and twenty-first-century discussions of magic and secularism.

title: 19th-Century Poetry and Modernity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will consider the way 19th-century poetry defined its own "modernity", pairing such writers as Browning and Felicia Hemans, Tennyson and Jean Ingelow, Swinburne and Michael Field. title: English Literature in the Continental Renaissance: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of English writers of the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries in relation to the international cultural movement of the European Renaissance, with an emphasis on changing attitudes towards the Renaissance project of reviving the classical past.

title: Romanticism and the Problem of History: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This proseminar will pair major Romantic texts with important critical work around the influential question of ``history'' in Romantic literature and criticism.

title: The Invention of Privacy in Early Modern Europe: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on a core of early modern texts from a range of European cultures, along with selected works of art. Topics include confession, piety and spiritual discipline, public ritual and private feeling, techniques of inquisition, dissimulation and coding, the gendering of privacy, theories of mind, the U.S. legal concept of "invasion of privacy,'' and the "post-totalitarian'' regimes of Eastern Europe.

title: Poetry, Politics, and Prophecy: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Key texts and authors during the time when English poetry and politics were most closely and publicly linked. Party politics, cultural politics, and the connection of the two. Political satire. Sexual politics and women writers. Religion and the prophetic theme. Includes some prose. Dryden, Pope, Montagu, Swift, Johnson, Burke, Wollstonecraft, Blake, and others. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: The 18th-Century Novel: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Novels by Defoe, Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Laclos, Walpole, Godwin, and Austen. Issues include genre (what was new about novels?), the representation of subjectivity, the paradoxes of "realism," didacticism and its subversion, and the significance of gender and class. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: The 18th-Century Novel

title: Swift
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The prose and poetry of Jonathan Swift. Attention to intellectual, literary, and political contexts, and theoretical implications. Selected readings of important precursors and influences, contemporaries (Pope, Gay, etc.), and followers and critics (Sterne to the present).

title: The 18th-Century Novel
subject: ENGLISH

title: Objects and Subjects in 18th-Century Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Collectibles, fetishes, fashionable commodities, and curious specimens often claim center-stage in 18th-century literary culture, where they challenge persons' sense of themselves and their properties and privileges. Drawing on writings by Defoe, Swift, Pope, Barbauld, Burney, Equiano, and others, and histories of science, shopping, and property and slave law, this course investigates that upstaging.

title: English Enlightenment: Foundations of the Modern
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Dryden, Pope, Swift, Johnson, Burke, Gibbon, Montagu, and others; the lyric, periodical literature, satire, biography, and drama; relations of engaged literature with politics, religion, history; issues of audience, gender, class, genre, and canon.

title: Restoration and 18th-Century Writers
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Dryden, Pope, Swift, Johnson, Burke, Gibbon, and others; the lyric, periodical literature, satire, biography; relations of engaged literature with politics, religion, history; issues of audience, gender, class, and canon. An intensive introduction to 18th-century literature at the graduate level. Members of the class are encouraged to develop and pursue special interests.

title: Studies in the Enlightenment: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Autobiographical, fictional, and philosophical texts that inaugurate modern interpretations of self and society. Writers to be read include Mme. de Lafayette, Hume, Voltaire, Boswell, Gibbon, Diderot, Rousseau, Laclos, Franklin, and Blake.

subject: ENGLISH

classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Repetition and Revenge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The dynamic of repetition is the dynamic of revenge: the ghost, the clue, the trace, the compulsion to repeat. Drawing on selected works of Freud, Lacan, and the contemporary literary and cultural theory, this course examines Elizabethan and Jacobean revenge tragedies and the plays of Shakespeare together with relevant modern works of drama, fiction, history, film, and video.

title: Enlightenment Selves
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The theorizing and narration of the modern self in 18th-century Britain and France, with emphasis on works by Hume, Boswell, Sterne, Rousseau, Diderot, Laclos, Wollstonecraft, Godwin, and Blake. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Enlightenment Selves
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The theorizing and narration of the modern self in 18th-century Britain and France, with emphasis on works by Hume, Sterne, Rousseau, Diderot, Laclos, Wollstonecraft, Godwin, and Blake. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Rousseau and Blake
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores some of the imaginative roots of the modern world, placing two seminal thinkers, Jean-Jacques Rousseau and William Blake, in dialogue with each other and with their contemporaries (e.g., Diderot, Wollstonecraft, Wordsworth). Focuses on the effort to ground social experience in the depths of the self rather than in external norms. Open to qualified undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Enlightenment Selves
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The theorizing and narration of the modern self in 18th-century Britain and France, with emphasis on works by Hume, Boswell, Sterne, Rousseau, Diderot, Laclos, Wollstonecraft, Godwin, and Blake. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Johnson and Rousseau: The Rhetoric of Wisdom: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close study of two major writers, one "conservative" and one "radical," who became celebrity personalities, and who employed a wide range of genres to address the challenges of the emerging modern world.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the lyric poetry and some prose by Robert Lowell, emphasizing intellectual, thematic, and generic change.

title: Late Romantic Poetry: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: This course reads two Second-Generation Romantics, Byron & Shelley. Other writers will likely include Wordsworth & Coleridge, Burke & Wollstonecraft, de Quincey, the Schlegels, and Letitia Elizabeth Landon (L.E.L.).

title: Kaleidoscopic Romanticism: Critical Approaches
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Beginning with "pre-Romantic" work such as Sterne's Tristram Shandy, this course covers many of the Romantic age's big players: Wordsworth's Prelude; Coleridge's conversation poems and the Biographia; W&C's Lyrical Ballads; Byron's Don Juan; Shelley's Adonais, Cenci and Prometheus Unbound; Keats's Lamia volume, including the great odes; and the Romantic Scottish novel.The kaleidoscope, said one commenter in 1817, the year of its invention, “presents to the view an endless variety of forms.”  The same might be said of Romanticism, which has been reframing and reorganizing itself for the last two hundred years. This course uses Romantic-era texts to introduce critical and theoretical methodologies such as Formalism and Close Reading, New Historicism, Narrative Theory, Psychoanalysis, Deconstruction and Queer Theory.  Works include: Sterne’s Tristram Shandy and Rousseau’s Confessions; de Quincey’s Confessions of an English Opium Eater and Suspiria de Profundis; Mary Shelley’s The Last Man; and poetry by Wordsworth, Blake, Shelley, and Keats.

title: The Poetry of Keats: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Topics include Keats's genres, the nature of Keatsian narrative, Keatsian mythology, the Keatsian ode, forms of heroism in Keats, and the relation of morality to the Keatsian aesthetic. Some attention to Keats's relation to Shakespeare, Milton, Wordsworth, and Dryden.

title: Late Romantic Poetry: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course reads two Second-Generation Romantics, Byron & Shelley. Other writers will likely include Wordsworth & Coleridge, Burke & Wollstonecraft, de Quincey, the Schlegels, and Letitia Elizabeth Landon (L.E.L.).

title: Romantic Literature and Politics
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Poetry, prose, and criticism linked with political theory, practice, and events.  From Burke to First Reform Act (1832) and Abolition of Slavery (1834).  Blake, Wollstonecraft, Shelley, Coleridge, Bentham, Austen, Godwin, Wordsworth, Byron, More, and others.  Ancillary reading in history and political documents.  Recent scholarship.  Common materials plus individual research and reports.  Possibility of American authors, e.g., Wheatley, Brown, Irving, Cooper, B. Alcott, Hawthorne.  General topics:   enfranchisement, empire, the poor, revolutions and war, corruption, the nature of freedom, slavery, church and state.

title: Comparative Romantic Theory: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Key romantic topics that remain relevant to literature and art e.g., symbol, language, aesthetics, nature (``green'' romanticism), history, irony, gender. Coleridge, Wordsworth, Shelley, Kant, Schelling, Schiller, Emerson, possibly Fuller, and Poe; others and recent critics as well.

title: The Representation of Work in the 19th-Century Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Narrative accommodates and expresses the nature of human labor. This is explored in a study of three 19th-century British writers_Dickens, Eliot, and Hardy_as well as novels and short stories by Turgenev, Zola, Tolstoy, Stowe, Melville. Background readings on the social and philosophic theory of work.

title: The Prehistory of Literature: Rhetoric in Early Modern England
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In this course we will attempt to give an account of rhetoric's immense cultural importance in the early modern period, as well as its subsequent decline and displacement by categories of the aesthetic and the literary in the 18th century. The ultimate aim of our study will be to reconstruct the conditions for the emergence of the modern discourse of literary criticism. Readings from Erasmus, Rainold, Wilson, Sidney, Puttenham, Bacon, Hobbes, Sprat, Locke, Hutcheson, Smith, Blair and others.

title: The Representation of Labor in the 19th-Century Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The ability of narrative to represent the nature of human labor is explored in three 19th-century British writers: Dickens, Eliot, and Hardy, as well as in novels and short stories by Turgenev, Zola, Tolstoy, Stowe, and Melville. Background readings on the social and philosophic theory of work.

title: Women's Poetry: Late Romantic to Late Victorian
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Considers three groups of poets and the intertextual relations between them: the late Romantics, Felicia Hemans and Letitia Elizabeth Landon (L.E.L.); the mid-Victorians, Christina Rossetti, Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Adelaide Anne Proctor, Dora Greenwell, Jean Ingelow, and Lisa Wilson; and later, 'New Woman' poets, Augusta Webster and Amy Levy. We consider how far these poets developed a gendered aesthetic and language, and what kinds of questions they explored - marriage and sexuality, education and work, social and political structures, war, nation, and colonial power. The working hypothesis of the course is that women poets had a sophisticated understanding that issues of gender have political and cultural repercussions beyond the immediate question of gender. We work through the close reading of texts.

title: Comparative Romanticism: Practice and Theory
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Relevance of Enlightenment texts for perennial issues faced today.  Aphra Behn on race and slavery; John Locke on religious (in)tolerance; Jonathan Swift on corruptions of religion, learning, and bureaucracy; Alexander Pope on pernicious influence of money and political chicanery; Samuel Johnson on marriage, choice of career, problem of evil, and arrogance of colonial power; Edmund Burke on imperial overreach, human rights, and religious oppression; Mary Wollstonecraft on gender, sex, and unjust treatment of women.  Some texts paired with contemporary writing.

title: The Bloomsbury Group
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: The Bloomsbury Group was an extraordinary creative collaboration in the early years of the 20th century. We tend to think of such collaborative work today, in think tanks, Silicon Valley incubators, literary movements and artists' colonies, as a fairly recent phenomenon, but it was in fact powerfully modeled a century ago. "Bloomsbury" included novelists Virginia Woolf and E.M. Forster, both of whom are also literary critics; biographer and essayist Lytton Strachey; economist John Maynard Keynes; socialist and publisher Leonard Woolf; philosophers G.E.Moore and Bertrand Russell; artists Vanessa Bell, Dora Carrington, and Duncan Grant; art critics Clive Bell and Roger Fry; and the English translators of Sigmund Freud, James and Alix Strachey--- each of whom had an enormous effect on the form of the genre, or genres, in which they worked. Not to mention other friends, lovers and rivals: Vita Sackville-West, David Garnett, Aldous Huxley, Katherine Mansfield, just to name a few. This course will look at the interdisciplinary effect of brilliant and talented people from across the spectrum of the arts and social sciences influencing each other’s work and participating in its creation and publication. Readings to include the major novels and essays of Virginia Woolf, the biographies and essays of Lytton Strachey, and substantial selections from other theorists, artists, critics and practitioners, together with relevant films, letters, and elements of design and home décor. In addition to our scrutiny of these works, in printed texts and in rare book libraries and museums, the members of the seminar will work to design and develop an undergraduate General Education course on the Bloomsbury Group.

title: Joyce/Beckett: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar offers an in-depth study of Ulysses and of Beckett's dramatic oeuvre. It doubles as an introduction to scholarly methods, including biography, history of the book, genre, geography, theater history, media studies, and philosophy.

title: Joyce/Beckett: Graduate Seminar

courseDescriptionLong: The seminar offers an in-depth study of Ulysses and of Beckett's dramatic oeuvre. It doubles as an introduction to scholarly methods, including biography, history of the book, genre, geography, theater history, media studies, and philosophy.

title: Joyce/Beckett: Graduate Seminar

title: Literature and Confinement
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Our concern is with freedom, specifically freedom conceived from the position of the confined subject. The notion of confinement is taken broadly: readings are drawn from so-called prison literature but also from the literature of retreat from the world (pastoral). Thus the paradox of solitude as both confinement and liberation is considered.

title: Social Marginality and Postmodern Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the parallels between the generalized fragmentation and decenteredness of the postmodern human subject and the psychic fragmentation experienced by socially marginalized populations even before the late 20th century. Readings: Habermas, Lyotard, Jameson; West, Ellison, Barnes, Nin, Brooks, Bowles; postmodernist novels by Coover, Barthelme, Nabokov, Barth, and Pynchon.

title: Social Marginality and Postmodern Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the parallels between the generalized fragmentation and decenteredness of the postmodern human subject and the psychic fragmentation experienced by socially marginalized populations even before the late 20th century. Works by Jürgen Habermas, Jean-François Lyotard, and Frederic Jameson; fiction by Nathanael West, Ralph Ellison, Djuna Barnes, Anais Nin, Gwendolyn Brooks, and Jane Bowles; postmodernist novels by John Coover, Donald Barthelme, Vladimir Nabokov, John Barth, and Thomas Pynchon.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Hopkins' works, primarily the poems, but with selections from the letters, journals, and sermons. Some reading in the poems of Keats, Tennyson, and the Rossettis, for purposes of influence and comparison.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Through reading selected works of Barthes's criticism, some relations between poststructuralist modes of thought and questions of (homo-/hetero-) sexuality are addressed.

title: 'Broken English': English Language Literature in a Postmodern, Postcolonial Frame
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of a range of experimental writings in the English Language predicated on the varieties of englishes spoken and used as idioms of writing and performance around the world. Special attention will be paid to theoretical and critical attempts to both assimilate these currents of expression into recognizable patterns and to create new categories of analysis, appropriation and legitimation.

title: Austen, Eliot, Hardy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The social and philosophical frame of Realism with its account of the order, intelligibility, and resonance of the ordinary. Social and temporal totalities within narrative; the role of analysis and consciousness in the materialistic account of descriptive realism. The role of binary and multiplied structures in the 19th-century novel.
