title: Studies in African Mythology: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The nature of Africa's oral narrative traditions and why they continue to influence the work of contemporary African writers. Readings embrace relevant samples of myth scholarship as well as primary texts from the oral and modern literatures. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Literatures of Immigration: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Reading accounts of transatlantic immigrants to America, including Vikings, Puritans, Huguenots, African slaves, and Jews, we will consider terminology (disapora, modernity) and methodology (performance). Authors include Crevevoeur, Cather, di Donato, and Mengestu.

title: Vladimir Nabokov: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine the depth and breadth of the works of Vladimir Nabokov. Special attention paid to those works written directly into English. Special consideration will be accorded to Nabokov's irreverent and idiosyncratic opinions on the task of the critic, and his criticism of other writers from Pushkin and Flaubert to Proust and Joyce.

title: Vladimir Nabokov: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine the depth and breadth of the works of Vladimir Nabokov. Special attention paid to those works written directly into English. Special consideration will be accorded to Nabokov's irreverent and idiosyncratic opinions on the task of the critic, and his criticism of other writers from Pushkin and Flaubert to Proust and Joyce.

title: The Poetry of W. B. Yeats
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Yeats' non-dramatic poetry. Topics include Yeats as English, Irish, and European poet; the breaking of genre and style; sources and influences; the Yeatsian volume; Yeatsian modernism, etc.

title: Hawthorne, Dickinson and Henry James
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will concern itself with some definitions and implications of ^'^'experience'' in the work of three major authors _ Hawthorne, Dickinson and Henry James. Texts will include Hawthorne's major tales, The Blithedale Romance, several Dickinson fascicles, and The Portrait of a Lady and The Spoils of Poynton.

title: Hawthorne, Dickinson and Henry James
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will concern itself with some definitions and implications of ^'^'experience'' in the work of three major authors _ Hawthorne, Dickinson and Henry James. Texts will include Hawthorne's major tales, The Blithedale Romance, several Dickinson fascicles, and The Portrait of a Lady and The Spoils of Poynton.

title: Virginia Woolf: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Woolf as a feminist thinker and cultural critic as well as a novelist.

title: Virginia Woolf: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Woolf as a feminist thinker and cultural critic as well as a novelist.

title: The Literature of the American Revolution and the Early Republic
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Focus on the contending (and evolving) notions of "American" and "literature" in the debates between Loyalists and patriots, Federalists and Anti-Federalists, Federalists and Republicans, and in the poetry, fiction, drama, biographies, and histories of the period.

title: Puritans and Planters: The Colonial Literatures of New England and the Chesapeake: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveying the literature of the Chesapeake--including texts of contact and exploration, of the Revolution, nation building, and the early Republic --and the literature of early New England--including sermonic literature, history, devotional and homiletic verse. This course introduces students to the earliest American literature in its transatlantic context.

title: American Civil War (Graduate Seminar in General Education)
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This interdisciplinary seminar explores the literature, history, and art of the Civil War, from letters, speeches, poetry, and photography to novels, stories, memoirs, and films from the 1850s to World War II. We examine how the war shaped writers and artists and how they shaped the legacies of the war. Authors include Melville, Whitman, Twain, Stowe, Alcott, Dickinson, Douglass, Lincoln, Chesnutt, Bierce, Faulkner, and others. The seminar will design and develop a General Education course on these themes for undergraduates.

title: Transcendentalism and its Discontents
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive examination of writings by Emerson, Thoreau, Fuller, others; responses and reactions to the movement in major works by Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Melville, others.

title: American Civil War (Graduate Seminar in General Education)
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This interdisciplinary seminar explores the literature, history, and art of the Civil War, from letters, speeches, poetry, and photography to novels, stories, memoirs, and films from the 1850s to World War II. We examine how the war shaped writers and artists and how they shaped the legacies of the war. Authors include Melville, Whitman, Twain, Stowe, Alcott, Dickinson, Douglass, Lincoln, Chesnutt, Bierce, Faulkner, and others. The seminar will design and develop a General Education course on these themes for undergraduates.

title: Puritans and Planters: The Colonial Literatures of New England and the Chesapeake: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveying the literature of the Chesapeake--including texts of contact and exploration, of the Revolution, nation building, and the early Republic --and the literature of early New England--including sermonic literature, history, devotional and homiletic verse. This course introduces students to the earliest American literature in its transatlantic context.

title: Early Atlantic World: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings from Britain, America, and the Caribbean focusing on ideas of race, revolution, and sentiment from the late 17th to early 19th century. Authors include Behn (Oroonoko), Equiano, Addison, Jefferson, Wheatley, and Rowson.

title: American Literature in the 17th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: May be taken by graduate students for seminar credit by arrangement with the instructor. English 70 or its equivalent.

title: Jonathan Edwards: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Open with permission of instructor to undergraduates who have taken English 70 or its equivalent.

title: Utopias and Dystopias: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This interdisciplinary and transnational course examines the rich tradition of utopian and dystopian societies and literature from the Bible and classical antiquity to the present, with a particular focus on the United States.  We explore a wide variety of utopian societies, especially those inspired by religious belief, from communal and aesthetic experiments to conceptions of America as a utopia.  Readings range from scripture and fiction to philosophy, history, sociology, political documents, letters, autobiography, and film.

title: Poetry in America: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Exploring the relationship between poems and their contexts, we survey a range of historical, cultural and critical contexts fruitfully engaged by critics of the American poem as well as some critical and ideological implications.

title: Poetry in America: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Exploring the relationship between poems and their contexts, we survey a range of historical, cultural and critical contexts fruitfully engaged by critics of the American poem as well as some critical and ideological implications.

title: New England -- Classic Texts and Critical Approaches: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces graduate students to classic and current debates by means of the country's most "exceptional region," New England. Readings include texts by Winthrop, Bradford, Mather, Franklin, Hawthorne, Melville, Dickinson, Jewett, Bishop and Lowell as well as critical readings treating such topics as autobiography and authorship, exceptionalism, history and historicism, romance, canon, regionalism, power, and pragmatism.

title: New England -- Classic Texts and Critical Approaches: Graduate Seminar

classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: American Literature: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course offers close readings of selected novels, short fiction, poetry, and drama in the context of American cultural history and of international literary developments. Topics include colonial writing, sentimental, gothic, and historical fiction, the rise of the short story, the American Renaissance, realism and local color writing, melodrama and the literature of slavery and the Civil War, with some focus on writers from John Winthrop to Gertrude Stein.

title: Humanities Online Practicum
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong:
The Humanities Online Practicum (HOP) at the Bok Center will introduce a mixed cohort of Harvard graduate students to new skills and methods, as well as to classic modes of humanistic inquiry and pedagogy. With Bok support, and working in a lab-studio format, teams of students will create digital educational content suitable for a wide range of learners—secondary school teachers and lifelong learners; public television viewers and medical professionals; college students at Harvard and at institutions of higher education worldwide. Students will see the assumptions of their disciplines challenged and expanded. They will learn to match pedagogies to the needs of diverse audiences, and to adapt content to a range of formats: lecture, discussion, syllabus and rubric; pair-and-share and exit ticket; edX module and television segment; podcast, blog post and more. Class projects will put new pressure on, and give new scope to, the role of the educator in the 21st century.

title: Melville
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Melville's major fiction and poetry from Typee through Billy Budd considered both in respect to its internal trajectories and in light of such critical discourses as new historicism, reflexive anthropology, post/colonial theory, whiteness studies, queer theory, ecocriticism, and print culture studies.

title: 19th-Century American Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The nineteenth century American literary career, with attention to the development of fictional modes (sketch, tale, romance, novel), exigencies of publication (the periodical press, transatlantic distribution networks) and evolving notions of fiction's place in American culture. Emphasis on Hawthorne, Melville and James but some attention to other authors.

title: American Genres through Hawthorne: Sermon, Meditation, Oration, Sketch, Romance. Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Why does the romance (rather than the realist novel) emerge as major 19th century American genre? Reading sermons, lyric meditations, travel narratives, sketches, orations and tales 1640-1840s, we will ask: what's romance made of?

title: Melville
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: American Genres through Hawthorne: Sermon, Meditation, Oration, Sketch, Romance. Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Why does the romance (rather than the realist novel) emerge as major 19th century American genre? Reading sermons, lyric meditations, travel narratives, sketches, orations and tales 1640-1840s, we will ask: what's romance made of?

title: Major U.S. Authors: Faulkner
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive reading of major works from the 1920s to the 1950s against the background of pertinent criticism and theory and the ``renaissance'' of southern literature and culture in Faulkner's day.

title: Major U.S. Authors: Faulkner
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive reading of major works from the 1920s to the 1950s against the background of pertinent criticism and theory and the ``renaissance'' of southern literature and culture in Faulkner's day.

title: The Literary Marketplace in America: Poe, Hawthorne, and Stowe: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines representative authorial careers within the context of the highly volatile publishing climate of the 1830s-1850s. Seminar is project-oriented, involving hands-on work with newspapers, magazines, gift books, publisher's records, and trade circulars. Topics include the instability of genre, the interpenetration of high and low forms of culture, literary property, and the history of authorship.

title: The Age of Howells: The Literature and Art of Cultural Transformation in Postbellum America
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the aesthetic, political, economic, and social transformation of the United States after the Civil War built around the wide-ranging influence of William Dean Howells. Framing the course will be Howells' role as novelist, editor, critic, correspondent, and booster for American realism. We will concentrate on the works of several writers who influenced Howells and, in turn, accepted his guidance: James, Twain, DeForrest, Adams, Crane, and Norris. We will extend our study of the realist bloodline through Harper, Chesnutt, Wharton, Garland and Bellamy. Matters of politics, economics, region, and race will be discussed as they relate to Howells' tenures at the Atlantic and Harper's, his relationship to the Republican party, his falling out with the Mugwumps, and his leaning toward socialism after Haymarket. Thinkers ranging from Henry George to Thornstein Veblen will help us chart the cultural transitions that led from sentimentalism to the challenges to Howells raised by Sinclair Lewis and Gertrude Stein. Focusing on literary and visual aesthetics, this course nevertheless takes an interdisciplinary approach to research in a range of primary documents.

title: American Literary Emergence and Transatlantic Imagination: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Works by Emerson, Hawthorne, Melville, Stowe, Whitman, and Dickinson read in conversation with such Victorian models and counterparts as Dickens, Tennyson, Eliot, and Stevenson, along with newer criticism/theory of literary/cultural transnationalism.

title: American Literary Emergence and Transatlantic Imagination: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Works by Emerson, Hawthorne, Melville, Stowe, Whitman, and Dickinson read in conversation with such Victorian models and counterparts as Dickens, Tennyson, Eliot, and Stevenson, along with newer criticism/theory of literary/cultural transnationalism.

title: Permutations of Literary Regionalism: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Significant works (mostly fiction) and critical readings from/about regionalism's 19th century Anglo-American beginnings to the present. Special emphasis on U. S. writers but also on selected writers from the U. K. and the Anglophone diaspora.

title: The "Great American Novel"
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Traces the rise, persistence, and complication of the vision of a "great national novel,'' with reference to a selected number of works from Uncle Tom's Cabin to Beloved. Themes to be stressed include the significance of multiculturalism and regionalism, the changing literary marketplace, and the so-called "national longing for form'' manifested in postcolonial literary cultures generally.

title: Asian American Women Writers
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We shall seek to answer the following: Why have Asian American women writers been more prolific than their male counterparts? How does writing by Asian American women differ from that by Euro-American and African American women? Are there common gender themes and intercultural concerns? Prose, poetry, and drama are supplemented by theoretical texts.

title: American History / American Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of American historical fiction. Readings include historical narratives and fictive reinventions, with some attention to contemporaneous historiography. Emphasis is on fiction and history as rival narrative forms and concepts of national identity. Authors include Hawthorne, Melville, Douglass, Twain, James, Dreiser, Cather, Dos Passos, Faulkner, Doctorow, Morrison.

title: American History / American Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of American historical fiction. Readings include historical narratives and fictive reinventions, with some attention to contemporaneous historiography. Emphasis is on fiction and history as rival narrative forms and concepts of national identity. Authors include Hawthorne, Melville, Douglass, Twain, James, Dreiser, Cather, Dos Passos, Faulkner, Doctorow, Morrison.

title: Studies in American Poetry: Walt Whitman and New World Poetics
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of Whitman's poetic development through the various editions of Leaves of Grass (1855-92), leading to the attempt to situate Whitmanian poetics within such interlocking frames as Romanticism, Transcendentalism, postcolonialism, nationalism, and poetic modernism, with considerable attention to Whitman's precursors and successors both in the U. S, and throughout the world (e.g. Wordsworth, Blake, Thomas Paine, Emerson; Pound, Hughes, Pessoa, Neruda, Walcott, Ginsberg, Maxine Hong Kingston).

title: Harlem Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the period of unprecedented African-American literary flowering during the 1920s and 1930s. Special attention will be given to the following: Harlem and other cultural centers; dialect in poetry and prose; the impact of women authors, editors, and critics; and the central positioning of the Harlem Renaissance in the African American literary tradition.

title: Harlem Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the period of unprecedented African-American literary flowering during the 1920s and 1930s. Special attention will be given to the following: Harlem and other cultural centers; dialect in poetry and prose; the impact of women authors, editors, and critics; and the central positioning of the Harlem Renaissance in the African American literary tradition.

title: Harlem Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Black Women and their Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intends to define the precise shape and contours of the tradition of black women's writing in English. How do black women use language to represent their experiences? How does their writing resemble or diverge from the black male tradition? How does black feminist theory differ from white feminist theory?

title: Black Women and their Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intends to define the precise shape and contours of the tradition of black women's writing in English. How do black women use language to represent their experiences? How does their writing resemble or diverge from the black male tradition? How does black feminist theory differ from white feminist theory?

title: Black Women and their Fiction
subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: Intends to define the precise shape and contours of the tradition of black women's writing in English. How do black women use language to represent their experiences? title: Studies in American Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive examination of pivotal works in the light of changing theories of American literature. Special attention to how they have served or might serve as exemplary texts in the conception or reconception of the field. Assigns major (re)interpretations of American literature as issues such as genre, canonicity, ethnic semiosis, gender, regionalism, and ideology are considered. Appropriate as a first graduate course in American literature.

title: 19th Century American Writers: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A graduate level seminar on 19th century American writers.

title: The Making of the American Renaissance Canon: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the changing bases in terms of which selected period authors have become canonized (or decanonized), to be considered both for what they reveal about those individual figures and for what they imply about the assumptions that shape our understanding of the structure of literary history and the nature of canonicity. Open to qualified undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: The Making of the American Renaissance Canon: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the changing bases in terms of which selected period authors have become canonized (or decanonized), to be considered both for what they reveal about those individual figures and for what they imply about the assumptions that shape our understanding of the structure of literary history and the nature of canonicity. Open to qualified undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Civil War and American Poetics: Melville, Whitman, and Others
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive examination of the Civil War as a phenomenon of the American imagination, with special attention to the writings of Herman Melville and Walt Whitman, but taking also into account selected 19th-century precursors, contemporaries, and successors from the Transcendentalists to Mark Twain.

title: Mark Twain and His World
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: The Natural History of American Naturalism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the American naturalist novel, from its 18th century antecedents to its early 20th century forms. Focuses on the influence of contemporary bio-medical, evolutionary, and behavioral sciences both on the naturalists' representations of embodied selves and on the formal features of the evolving genre. Authors include Charles Brockden Brown, Emerson, Zola, Norris, London, Wharton, Chopin, Dreiser, Glasgow, James, Farrell, Petry, and Wright. Secondary readings feature works by Cabanis, Condorcet, Lamarck, Bernard, Taine, Darwin, Spencer, Le Conte, and James. We also examine the critical history of naturalism (through the 1990s) to see if our findings challenge critics' accounts of the genre's depiction of human agency and its peculiar gender alignments.

title: Emerson
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close readings of central Emerson texts from variant cultural and philosophical perspectives.

title: Emerson
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close readings of central Emerson texts from variant cultural and philosophical perspectives.

title: Melville and Hawthorne: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relation of these authors to each other and to antebellum American culture, focusing on such issues as the possibility of dissent, the meaning of labor, and the representation of sexuality.

title: Puritanism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the foundations of American Puritanism (historical, theological, and aesthetic), and of the influence of Puritainism on classic American literature.

title: Douglass and Melville: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major writings of Frederick Douglass and Herman Melville, with particular attention to dilemmas of race, freedom, and equality. We look at their works from both historical and aesthetic perspectives.

title: Douglass and Melville: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major writings of Frederick Douglass and Herman Melville, with particular attention to dilemmas of race, freedom, and equality. We look at their works from both historical and aesthetic perspectives.

title: Douglass and Melville: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major writings of Frederick Douglass and Herman Melville, with particular attention to dilemmas of race, freedom, and equality. We look at their works from both historical and aesthetic perspectives.

title: Reinventing American Memory: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Novels by Cather, Faulkner, Ellison, Pynchon, others considered as reinventions of prior "masterplots" arising from such cultural discourses as immigration/diaspora, success/failure, wilderness romance.

title: Reinventing American Memory: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Novels by Cather, Faulkner, Ellison, Pynchon, others considered as reinventions of prior "masterplots" arising from such cultural discourses as immigration/diaspora, success/failure, wilderness romance.

title: American Literary Emergence as a Postcolonial Phenomenon
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Selected works by American authors from Irving and Emerson to Henry James read in connection with authors throughout the English-speaking world and pertinent works of postcolonial theory and criticism, to the end of arriving at a comparatist understanding of American literary development and a theory of literary emergence. Appropriate as a first graduate course in American literature.

title: American Literary Emergence as a Postcolonial Phenomenon
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Selected works by American authors from Irving and Emerson to Henry James read in connection with authors throughout the English-speaking world and pertinent works of postcolonial theory and criticism, to the end of arriving at a comparatist understanding of American literary development and a theory of literary emergence.

title: American Postcolonialism and the Anglophone Diaspora
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines what "postcolonialism'' means and the usefulness of this formulation for American literature of the formative period (Revolution through Civil War). Selected modern classics from the Anglophone authors of Nigeria, the West Indies, and Australia, selected American Renaissance texts, and some pertinent works of theory and criticism.

title: The Long Renaissance: The New Negro and Harlem, 1895-1934
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: The “new birth of freedom” that Abraham Lincoln hoped to see rise out of the death and destruction of the Civil War manifested itself during the twelve years that followed it. Reconstruction (1865 - 1877) ushered in a “Second Founding” of the nation through the ratification of the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments to the Constitution, abolishing slavery, establishing birthright citizenship, due process and equal protection of the laws, and the right to vote for black male citizens. As revolutionary as Reconstruction was, it was also short-lived, and the long, violent roll-back against it, curiously known as the “Redemption,” witnessed the curtailing of these rights and the rise and institutionalization of Jim Crow segregation in what one newspaper editor coined the “New South.”  A key aspect of Redemption was a propaganda war designed to debase the image of African Americans, and thereby justify the deprivation of their rights. Resisting it, African Americans, starting in the mid-1890s, employed the concept of a “New Negro” to combat racist images of an “Old Negro” fabricated by apologists for Jim Crow. Thus began what we might call America’s first “social media” race war.  The trope of a New Negro underwent several revisions between the 1890’s and 1920’s, when—in the midst of the Great Migration of African Americans from the South to the North—the Harvard-trained philosopher, Alain Locke, revised and appropriated the term  to describe a remarkable flowering of art and literature that he named “The New Negro Renaissance.”  Later commentators would label the period “The Harlem Renaissance.”  Locke and his contemporaries thought that “armed with culture,” as W.E.B. Du Bois wrote much later, they could efficaciously wage the struggle against anti-black racism through what an historian of the period cleverly called “civil rights by copyright.”   This course traces the history of the metaphor of a “New Negro” from its inception at the dawn of Jim Crow to the end of The New Negro Renaissance in the Great Depression.

title: The African-American Literary Tradition
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the emergence and formal development of the Afro-American literary "tradition," from the 18th to the 20th century. Stresses reading of the canonical texts in the tradition and their structural relationships, as well as the idea of "tradition" itself. Authors include Wheatley, Douglass, Jacobs, Washington, Ellison, Morrison, Walker, Naylor, Baraka, Brooks.

title: Black Women and Their Fiction: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intends to define the precise shape and contours of the tradition of black women's writing in English. How do black women use language to represent their experiences? How does their writing resemble or diverge from the black male tradition? How does black feminist theory differ from white feminist theory?

subject: ENGLISH

title: American Literature Now: Classic Texts/New Approaches, Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Major works by Emerson, Hawthorne, Melville, James, Cather, Faulkner, and Ellison, read vis-a-vis such important emphases in recent Americanist criticism as critical race studies, postnationalism, pragmatism, queer theory, book history, and ecocriticism.

title: Religion and American Film: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Religion has proven a profitable, controversial subject in American cinema. This course introduces students to the topic by combining narrative analysis, film history, and religious study. Areas of inquiry include: how has the cinema's illusionism enhanced the revivalistic power of traditional iconography? How have films shaped Americans' perceptions of religious nationalism and empire or supported the belief in a civil religion or reinforced the ideology of a Judeo-Christian consensus?

title: Issues in Study of Ethnicity and Literature: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in American ethnic literature, in recent critical and theoretical work and in classical ethnic theory, with special attention to concepts of nationalism, ethnicity, and race, and their relation to literature.

title: Contemporary African American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of African American novels, plays and poetry produced since the 1960s. Among other topics, we will discuss the Black Arts Movement, the renaissance of black women authors in the 1970s, the rise of the neo-slave narrative, and black postmodern texts. Major authors will include but not be limited to Ishmael Reed, Charles Johnson, Toni Morrison, Samuel Delaney, Adrienne Kennedy, Gwendolyn Brooks, Rita Dove, Suzan-Lori Parks, and Colson Whitehead.

title: Kinship and Literature: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The construction of kinship in literature: affinity and consanguinity as themes, and their constitution through texts. Focus on mother right, incest, generations, and the functions of races and species in kinship symbolism. Readings include studies by Lewis Henry Morgan, Bachofen, Engels, Freud, Mannheim, and David Schneider, as well as literary texts from Aeschylus to Faulkner.

title: NAFTA Literature: Language Diversity and Nationhood: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Traces the linguistic diversity of what is now the U.S. Topics include the political history of legal bilingualism; the role of anglophone American literature in excluding non-English languages; enforced loss of language and emphasis on dialect; the intellectual place of Native American languages in American linguistics; the literature of minority language groups; and contemporary issues involving statehood and free trade. Knowledge of languages other than English is recommended.

title: Multilingual Literatures of the United States: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Non-English literature of what is now the US: The historiographic and critical treatment of non-Anglophone texts, general theoretical problems of an ongoing multilingual American tradition, and recuperation and presentation of texts. Focus is on work with original source materials, on new research possibilities, and on translation theory. Visiting scholars will attend several sessions

title: The Fourth Longfellow Institute Seminar: Literatures of the United States
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Multilingual literature of what is now the United States. Special focus on the historiographic and critical treatment of non-Anglophone texts, on general theoretical problems of an ongoing multiligual American tradition, and on the recuperation and presentation of texts. Original source materials in Spanish, French, Portuguese, Welsh, Norwegian, German, Swedish, Yiddish, Russian, Chinese, Arabic, and other non-English texts will be provided in bilingual versions. Some attention to wampum and drum language. Visiting scholars will attend several sessions.

title: Describing the Lyric
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong:
Each change in period style presents a problem of description to the critic. We consider a wide range of poetic styles, from the court styles of Elizabethan poetry through the aleatory styles of such contemporary poets as Ammons, Ashbery, and Graham, inquiring in each case which avenues of description prove productive.

Each change in period style presents a problem of description to the critic. We consider a wide range of poetic styles, from the court styles of Elizabethan poetry through the verse of W.B. Yeats, inquiring in each case which avenues of description prove productive.

title: Sentimentalism, Naturalism, Spiritualism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Reading in a variety of classic and noncanonical sentimental and naturalist novels. Topics include the gendering of the genres; their critical reception; the influence of African-American spiritism, modern spiritualism, and early psychology on both genres. Authors include Jacobs, Stowe, Phelps, Child, Henry James, William James, Howells, London, Crane, Hopkins, Chesnutt, and Dunbar-Nelson.

The course draws from an array of mostly American and Chinese sources: nineteenth century travelogues, early twentieth century journalism, Christian conversion narratives, classics of the American canon, middlebrow bestsellers and modern Asian American writings.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Postmodernism: Theories and Fictions
subject: ENGLISH

title: Recent American Poetry, Theory and Practice: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Promising, profound, controversial, or otherwise notable new American poems, and ideas about them, from the last twenty years: verse or prose by, among others, Armantrout, Graham, Grossman, Merrill, Waldner, and C.D. Wright.

title: Drama, Theory, and Performance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Drama is at once the most canonical and the most transgressive of genres, yet until recently it has been scanted in literary-theoretical discussions. This course aims to resituate drama at the center and the margins of the literary enterprise and to explore the reasons for its spectral and spectacular return. We will consider 20th-century dramatic literature and theory (from Brecht, Artaud, Beckett and Genet to Albee, Mamet, Churchill and Anna Deveare Smith) in the context of literary and cultural theory, politics, ritual and social drama, psychoanalysis, gender theory, performativity, and style.

title: Studies in the Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The theory of the novel, read in conjunction with pivotal primary texts. Critical works include: early contributions (such as James, Lukács); general studies (Watt, Armstrong, Booth); essays in fields including narratology, phenomenology, reception-theory, and feminism (Prince, Genette, Iser, DuPlessis); and studies of questions of periodization, genre, structure, and political context.

title: The New Economic Criticism: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on issues of monetary and linguistic representation and exchange, with special attention to metaphorization, to historical introductions of new monetary economic and literary media, and to various kinds of connections between economic and aesthetic production. Readings include Heraclitus, Herodotus, Aristotle, Sophocles, medieval tales of the Holy Grail, Shakespeare, Rousseau, Goethe, Marx, Melville, Heidegger, and many theorists of digital representation and exchange in the twenty-first century.

title: Language and Money in English Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar investigates interrelationships between money and language as means of representation and exchange. Literary works include Charles Johnstone’s Chrysal, Elizabeth’s Inchbald’s Nature and Art, Ezra Pound’s Cantos, Martin Amis’ Money, Thomas Love Peacock’s Paper Money Lyrics, and William Shakespeare’s The Merchant of Venice. Economic works include Aristotle’s Economics and Poetics, Jacques Derrida’s early essays, and Marx’s economic manuscripts and interpretations of literary works.  Two or three meetings will consider that printed money has been the most widespread literature in the world and will thus focus on medieval coinage in England, Native American wampum at Harvard in colonial times, paper money in revolutionary America, and nowadays electronic money around the world.  The seminar will conclude with attention to theories of meaning as value, notions of metaphorization as retaliation, and consideration of changing monetary form and literary format.

title: The Novel in the History of Media
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the rise of the novel in conjunction with the rise of modern communications networks and information technologies.  It investigates this literary genre’s accounts of people’s interconnectedness alongside those projected by the postal system, the telegraph, and the radio. We’ll read widely in the history of English-language fiction-- from Daniel Defoe to Jennifer Egan, by way of Sterne, Gaskell, James, and others--and in recent works of media archaeology.

title: Conrad, Naipaul, Coetzee: Genealogies of the Global Imagination: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: The novels of Conrad, Naipaul, and Coetzee have a particular value to contemporary discourses on global culture. For these writers, the experience of Empire was as much an ethical and aesthetic project as it was an economic or political venture. Our study will focus on their reflections on the problematic project of joining diverse cultures and distant territories in a global network and on the role of figurative language and fictional forms in imagining community and communication on a global scale.

title: Conrad, Naipaul, Coetzee: Genealogies of the Global Imagination: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

title: Cinematic Adaptation: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys history and theory of adaptation. Emphasis on industrial and craft practice, notions of adaptability, and debates over medium specificity in both modern and postmodern contexts.

title: Genealogies of Queer Theory
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Instead of asking what queer theory is, this course traces queer theory's relations to its intellectual precursors: lesbian and gay studies; feminist theories; post-colonial studies; psychoanalysis; post-marxisms; and postmodernisms. Readings include Freud, Foucault, Althusser, Butler, Halperin, Bersani, Anzaldúa, Spivak, Sedgwick, Fanon. Course open to graduate students and advanced undergraduates. English 197 or equivalent.

title: Conrad, Naipaul, Coetzee: Genealogies of the Global Imagination: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The novels of Conrad, Naipaul, and Coetzee have a particular value to contemporary discourses on global culture. For these writers, the experience of Empire was as much an ethical and aesthetic project as it was an economic or political venture. Our study will focus on their reflections on the problematic project of joining diverse cultures and distant territories in a global network and on the role of figurative language and fictional forms in imagining community and communication on a global scale.

title: Cinematic Adaptation: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys history and theory of adaptation. Emphasis on industrial and craft practice, notions of adaptability, and debates over medium specificity in both modern and postmodern contexts.

title: Genealogies of Queer Theory
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Instead of asking what queer theory is, this course traces queer theory's relations to its intellectual precursors: lesbian and gay studies; feminist theories; post-colonial studies; psychoanalysis; post-marxisms; and postmodernisms. Readings include Freud, Foucault, Althusser, Butler, Halperin, Bersani, Anzaldúa, Spivak, Sedgwick, Fanon. Course open to graduate students and advanced undergraduates. English 197 or equivalent.

title: Versions of Moses
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Centered around the five Books of Moses in the Bible and their rewritings by Sigmund Freud and Zora Neale Hurston. Will include readings in political theory, Biblical interpretation, cinema, comparative literature, psychoanalysis, and anthropology. Course will explore fictions and theories of law, monotheism, patriarchy, nationalism, and the intersections of Judaism and Afrocentrism.

title: Describing the Lyric: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Each change in period style presents a problem of description to the critic. We consider a wide range of poetic styles, from the court styles of Elizabethan poetry through the aleatory styles of such contemporary poets as Ammons, Ashbery, and Graham, inquiring in each case which avenues of description prove productive.

title: Describing the Lyric: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Each change in period style presents a problem of description to the critic. We consider a wide range of poetic styles, from the court styles of Elizabethan poetry through the aleatory styles of such contemporary poets as Ammons, Ashbery, and Graham, inquiring in each case which avenues of description prove productive.

title: Poetry in the Digital Environment: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course allows graduate students preparing themselves for careers in secondary and college teaching and associated fields to explore, and to make their own contributions to, the emerging digital pedagogy in American poetry.  Study of such canonical American poets as Wheatley, Whitman, Dickinson, Frost, Hughes, Brooks, Williams, O’Hara, Rich, and Howe as well as of the folk and popular poetries of particular historical moments (from Yankee Doodle to Tin Pan Alley and hip hop) will be complemented by practical training in lesson planning and content development, classroom and on-camera presentation. Other topics include platform design and video editing, live and remote discussion and annotation, blended learning and the importance of libraries. Some attention will be given to the theory, economics and politics of classic liberal education in the age of the internet.

title: Postmodern Narrative: Theories, Fictions, and Films
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of novels published after World War II and film interpretations. Texts to be considered will include Lolita, A Clockwork Orange, Kiss of the Spiderwoman, The Tin Drum, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, and The English Patient.

title: Postmodernism: Fiction and Theories
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings from Beckett and Borges to Pynchon and DeLillo in conjunction with selections from Foucault, Derrida, Lyotard, Jameson and others.

title: Postmodern Narrative: Theories, Fictions, and Films
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of novels published after World War II and film interpretations. Texts to be considered will include Lolita, A Clockwork Orange, Kiss of the Spiderwoman, The Tin Drum, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, and The English Patient.

title: Ideas in Literature: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The persistence of the novel of ideas and the drama of ideas demands a new understanding of literature and its relation to philosophy. Readings include Shaw, Stoppard, Pynchon, Coetzee, Stephenson, Bergson, and McCarthy.

title: Postmodernism: Fiction and Theories
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings from Beckett and Borges to Pynchon and DeLillo in conjunction with selections from Foucault, Derrida, Lyotard, Jameson and others.

title: Ideas in Literature: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The persistence of the novel of ideas and the drama of ideas demands a new understanding of literature and its relation to philosophy. Readings include Shaw, Stoppard, Pynchon, Coetzee, Stephenson, Bergson, and McCarthy.

title: Who Cares about Modernism?: Literary Studies and the Problem of Periodization
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong:
This graduate seminar uses modernism as a test case for debates regarding the merits and limits of literary periodization. Though our focus is modernism, we will be engaging with examples of similar debates from other periods, such as challenges to the medieval/ Renaissance divide, calls for “presentist Shakespeare,” the manifesto of the Victorian v21 collective, and discussions regarding the utility of labelling contemporary literature as “post-45.” We will examine the contingencies and controversies of modernism’s fraught self-formation, reading detractors including Wyndham Lewis, Laura Riding, and Edith Wharton, as well as figureheads such as Woolf, Lawrence, and Joyce. 

 

Primary texts are designed to partly overlap with the generals list and may include: Joyce’s Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, Woolf’s To the Lighthouse, Wharton’s The House of Mirth, and more. Secondary readings to include: Eric Hayot, Rita Felski, Paul Saint-Amour, Fredric Jameson, Kenneth Burke, Susan Stanford Friedman, René Wellek, Gerald Graff, Ted Underwood, David James and Urmila Seshagiri, Wai Chee Dimock.

title: Postcolonial Discourse
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Where, what, when, and who is the postcolonial? An introduction to the major questions in the field of postcolonial studies with an emphasis on texts from Africa, the Caribbean, and South Asia.

title: 9/11: A Moment in Culture and Theory
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine a cluster of disciplinary responses to 9/11. We will start by considering various philosophical frameworks that have laid out a range of political, ethical, and psychological issues implicated in the event. We will move on to consider the "culture" of 9/11 by examining a range of discourses and genres -- novels, blogs, artworks, journalistic accounts, film -- that have contributed to the narrative of 9/11 and its aftermath.

title: Literary Theory and Cultural Criticism: Reading 9/11
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores "9/11"-event, history, myth-as a site of cultural and critical intervention in the arts and humanities. We will engage with a range of philosophical reflections on "9/11" and its impact on our understanding of historical temporality, the phenomenology of shock and anxiety, human security, and the politics of terror. A wide range of literary genres, artistic practices, journalistic narratives, and cinematic sources will be used to illustrate the cultural myths and realities provoked by the constellation of ideas and experiences we associate with "9/11."

title: Literary Theory and Cultural Criticism: Reading 9/11: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Literature and the Philosophy of Mind: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will consider the mind's artifacts (principally lyric poems) alongside recent philosophical and scientific accounts of the mind itself. Topics will include: private and universal languages, the rationality of emotions, collective identity, intelligence (artificial and real), ``other minds.''

title: Literature and the Philosophy of Mind: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will consider the mind's artifacts (principally lyric poems) alongside recent philosophical and scientific accounts of the mind itself. Topics will include: private and universal languages, the rationality of emotions, collective identity, intelligence (artificial and real), ``other minds.''

title: The Senses, Emotion, and the Ethics of Reception: Theories of Drama, Theatre, Performance, and Media
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Dramatic theory as a window on the central concerns of literary and media theory (ancient to contemporary): the senses, emotion, character, identity, medium, verisimilitude, the body, the ethics of reception.

title: The Senses, Emotion, and the Ethics of Reception: Theories of Drama, Theatre, Performance, and Media
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Dramatic theory as a window on the central concerns of literary and media theory (ancient to contemporary): the senses, emotion, character, identity, medium, verisimilitude, the body, the ethics of reception.

title: Postcolonial Literature and Anthropology
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Is postcolonial literature a surrogate anthropology? Do postcolonial writers/writings represent their cultures, or are they made to represent them? What are the problems involved in transcribing non-European ("oral'') cultures into European (written) languages? These and other questions are addressed by reading selected postcolonial texts against their European anthropological counterparts. No previous knowledge of postcolonial literature, or of anthropology, is required. Students from departments other than English welcome. Specially qualified undergraduates may be admitted.

title: Postcolonial Literature and Anthropology
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Is postcolonial literature a surrogate anthropology? Do postcolonial writers/writings represent their cultures, or are they made to represent them? What are the problems involved in transcribing non-European ("oral'') cultures into European (written) languages? These and other questions are addressed by reading selected postcolonial texts against their European anthropological counterparts. Focus on four cultural regions: Africa, the Caribbean/Latin America, the South Pacific, indigenous Canada/Australia. No previous knowledge of postcolonial literature, or of anthropology, is required. Students from departments other than English welcome. Specially qualified undergraduates may be admitted.

title: Postcolonial Literature and Anthropology
subject: ENGLISH

title: Poetry, Suicide, Biography: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: While poststructuralists have spoken of "the death of the author" as a way of separating a poet's life and intentions from the meaning of the text, readers of "confessional poetry" seem to have an infinite appetite for the details of the lives of authors, particularly authors who have committed suicide. Focus on poetry and biography of Plath, Sexton, and Berryman.

title: The Theory of the Metaphor: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Topic to be announced.

title: Migration and the Humanities
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: By focusing on literary narratives, cultural representations, and critical theories, this course explores ways in which issues related to migration create rich and complex interdisciplinary conversations. How do humanistic disciplines address these issues — human rights, cultural translation, global justice, security, citizenship, social discrimination, biopolitics — and what contributions do they make to the “home” disciplines of migration studies such as law, political science, and sociology? How do migration narratives compel us to revise our concepts of culture, polity, neighborliness, and community? We will explore diverse aspects of migration from existential, ethical, and philosophical perspectives while engaging with specific regional and political histories. Includes regular participation in the Mahindra Humanities Center Mellon Seminar on migration and the humanities.

title: Migration and the Humanities

title: Theater and Philosophy: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course focuses on philosophical reflections on the theater, as well as dramatic dialogues, the theater of ideas, and theatricality in philosophical works. Readings include Plato, Aristotle, Kierkegaard, Shaw, Burke, Stoppard, Murdoch, Badiou.

title: Theater and Philosophy: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course focuses on philosophical reflections on the theater, as well as dramatic dialogues, the theater of ideas, and theatricality in philosophical works. Readings include Plato, Aristotle, Kierkegaard, Shaw, Burke, Stoppard, Murdoch, Badiou.

title: Cross-dressing and Cultural Anxiety: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A theoretical consideration of transvestism in literature, history, film, and popular culture from Shakespeare to Peter Pan to contemporary cinema and the pop-rock scene.

title: Violence and Nonviolence
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Examines representations of violence and related issues of discrimination, minority subjectivity, colonialism and racism, in the work of Morrison, Gordimer, Baldwin, Rushdie, Rich, Naipaul, Coetzee and Rankine. A key aim of the course is to create conversations between the literary, aesthetic and ethical dimensions of representations of violence and the histories and theories of violence as articulated by such thinkers as DuBois, Gramsci, Foucault, Fanon, Kristeva, Coates, and Said, among others. The course will include regular participation in the Mellon Seminar on violence and nonviolence.

title: Theories of Pedagogy: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Pedagogy considered as an intellectual, political, discursive, and erotic strategy in texts drawn from literature, philosophy, social politics, and film. Topics include "English Studies'' as a discipline and "Shakespeare'' as an institution; canon formation; an the pedagogical questions raised by poststructuralism, identity politics, gender studies, and technology.

title: Weird English: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What difference does language difference make? What is a language disorder? Who defines it? Topics include punning and perseveration (Shakespeare) and dyslexia (Yeats). Seminar meetings focus on stuttering (Billy Budd), accent (Pygmalion), semi-lingualism (Power of Silence), mixed languages (Finnegans Wake), speechlessness (Johnny's Got His Gun), and animal talk (Roger Rabbit). Secondary reading includes philology, neurology, and historical accounts of such defining characteristics of the English language itself as a blaut reduplication (shilly shally).

title: Fictions of Kin and Kind
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The literature and rhetoric of kinship. Special attention to the incest taboo, orphanhood, the human-animal distinction, and social fictions of nationhood. Readings include texts by modern theorists as well as Sophocles, Marguerite of Navarre, Elizabeth Tudor, Cervantes, Shakespeare, Racine, Schiller, Goethe, Melville, and Nabokov.

title: Fictions of Kin and Kind
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The literature and rhetoric of kinship. Special attention to the incest taboo, orphanhood, the human-animal distinction, and social fictions of nationhood. Readings include texts by modern theorists as well as Sophocles, Marguerite of Navarre, Elizabeth Tudor, Cervantes, Shakespeare, Racine, Schiller, Goethe, Melville, and Nabokov.

title: Freud, Pyschoanalysis and Literary Study: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The major writings of Sigmund Freud in English translation, together with relevant works of literature and culture. Additional readings from Lacan, Derrida, Kristeva, Irigaray, Butler, Zizek, and Edelman, among others. Psychoanalysis will be considered as a reading practice, a master narrative, an allegorical structure, a theatrical and cinematic mode, and a political intervention. Students will develop their own approach to Freud and psychoanalysis in a final seminar paper.

title: Black "Epics" of the Americas: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A cross-cultural, transnational readings of Black-authored epic poems, would-be epic poems, and book-length verse-narratives-from Canada, the Caribbean, and the United States: We will note the ways in which different historical experiences mandate divergent readings of the Transatlantic Slave Trade and the African Diaspora.

title: Language Disorders and the Literary Tradition: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What is a language disorder? Who defines it? Is it a disability? We study stuttering (Moses, Billy Budd), accent (Pygmalion), perseveration (Shakespeare), semi-lingualism (Power of Silence), mixed languages (Finnegans Wake), speechlessness (Johnny's Got His Gun), dyslexia (Yeats), and American Sign Language as well as theoretical texts.

title: Language Disorders and the Literary Tradition: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What is a language disorder? Who defines it? Is it a disability? We study stuttering (Moses, Billy Budd), accent (Pygmalion), perseveration (Shakespeare), semi-lingualism (Power of Silence), mixed languages (Finnegans Wake), speechlessness (Johnny's Got His Gun), dyslexia (Yeats), and American Sign Language as well as theoretical texts.

title: Literature and the Circulation of Knowledge: The 18th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A course about how literature participates in the dissemination of new knowledge. We will be concerned centrally with two broad issues: the cultural foundations upon which the Enlightenment instituted a public sphere, and the methods of literary encapsulation and remediation authors used to make their ideas have broad cultural impact. The aim is to explore the invention and naturalization of some of the most fundamental institutions of the Enlightenment: the public, the private, the market, and public opinion. Authors will include Addison, Richardson, Diderot, Sterne, Smith, Wollstonecraft, Blake. Substantial theoretical readings in intellectual history, book history, and media studies.

title: Literature and the Circulation of Knowledge: The 18th Century
subject: ENGLISH

Authors will include Addison, Richardson, Diderot, Sterne, Smith, Wollstonecraft, Blake. Substantial theoretical readings in intellectual history, book history, and media studies.

title: Disfluency and Style
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar focuses on works, including Hamlet and Billy Budd, where an inability to speak provides a motivating formal element as well as a substantial theme. The seminar considers such literary authors as Henry James and Lewis Carroll for whom their own more or less involuntary ways of stuttering becomes a style of writing or a larger philosophy.  Theoretical issues include the historical link between the terminology of linguistic neurology and classical rhetoric; aesthetic issues involve problems of rhythm, metrics, and silence in poetry.

title: Introduction to Scholarly Writing
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Through a careful reading of the most influential recent scholarship, students will explore a range of argumentative modes and evidentiary practices; through workshops of their own writing, they will experiment with rhetoric, voice, and style. Students will leave the course with an article ready for submission.

title: Methods of Approaching American Literature; Hemingway and Beyond: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Issue-oriented approaches to modern literature, using Hemingway as a point of departure; close reading, in different contexts, of an exemplary classic whose current stock seems to be low; archival research in the Hemingway papers. Please read or reread Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises for the first meeting.

title: Issues in the Study of American Literature: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Comparative readings in literature of the United States in an international context, discussions of critical and theoretical work, and an examination of pioneering and more recent literary history.

title: Methods of Literary Study: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: What constitutes method in literary studies? Over the past decade, this question has attained new urgency, with scholars of literature debating fundamental assumptions about what, how, and even whether to read. This seminar will engage such debates by surveying recent monographs, edited collections, and journal articles that address topics such as historicism and periodization, textual materialism and book history, “new sociologies of literature,” “surface reading,” digital humanities and “distant reading,” and so on. Seminar participants will think broadly about method as they pursue more limited research topics. Assignments will include a conference abstract, a book review, and an article-length seminar paper.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The theory and practice of Modernism from Baudelire to Nabakov, focusing on Modernism's early twentieth-century critical manifestos and the most recent efforts to define modernist culture.

title: Magic: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Magic, often described as a precursor to science or an alternative to religion, is above all the essential property of the arts. From the visual illusion to the power of the magic word, from Merlin and Archimago to Doctor Faustus and Prospero, from John Dee to Houdini to Teller, this course will trace-- and evoke-the transformative power of magic and magicians in literature, theater, film and performance. Topics to include automata from the Renaissance to Freud's "Uncanny'; art forms from the court masque to the magic show; films from Edison and Méliès to The Prestige and Ricky Jay; genres from magic realism to magical thinking.

title: Modernism: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The theory and practice of Modernism from Baudelire to Nabakov, focusing on Modernism's early twentieth-century critical manifestos and the most recent efforts to define modernist culture.

title: Public Humanities Workshop
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Public humanities are becoming increasingly central for careers both inside and outside of academia. This workshop, which is open to beginning and advanced graduate students, introduces participants to the tools they need to address audiences other than specialists in their own field. These tools range from writing op-eds based on dissertation research to writing general interest books, and also include book reviews, podcasts, social media strategies and more. While we will discuss some historical context, the emphasis is on practice and skills. Our work will be supplemented by visits from editors and literary agents. Because the course is a workshop, enrollment is limited to 12.

title: New Critical Approaches to the Chicano Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the Chicano novel in the light of contemporary critical theory. Dual focus: reading of definitive Chicano fiction since 1959 and the discussion of ethnic discourse. Students examine the novels from a variety of recent theoretical models.

title: Solitary Reading and the Theory of the Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: By studying the openings of novels along with theoretical and historical works on reading culture, we examine the novel and the act of reading in middle-class culture. Solitude, intimacy and nonreciprocal intimacy, intrusion, mutual and observational interpretation, the everyday and the exotic, self-identity, occupied consciousness, and withdrawal from society.

title: Solitary Reading: Prolonged Attention in Novels and Paintings: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A phenomenological study of novels and paintings; reading and seeing as aesthetic modes; segmented and prolonged attention; solitary and social experiences of works of art; intimacy and non-reciprocal intimacy; superimposition, enchantment, occupied consciousness. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Philosophy, Psychiatry and Literature: Seminar (Graduate Seminar in General Education)
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of issues at stake in contemporary psychiatry, including changing concepts of personality and identity; the medicalization of personality differences; mind/brain distinctions; genetic versus social-constructionist accounts of behavior; and the role of emotion and the unconscious in cognition and decision-making. Specifically, the course will explore how philosophy and literature can contribute to an understanding of these questions. The seminar will design and develop a General Education course on these themes for undergraduates.

title: A Theoretical History of Theatre
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines theatre as a "history of ideas'' produced in the plays and theories of performance from Aristotle to the present.

title: The Gay Nineties: Genealogies of Gender
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the development of gender studies from 1978 to the present. Authors include: Foucault, De Lauretis, Butler, Halperin, Sedgwick, Edelman, Bersani. Topics: issues in gay and lesbian representation, the politics of sexuality, queer theory.

title: Realism and Naturalism: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the defining instances of realism and naturalism (Balzac, Eliot, Howells; Zola, Gissing, Dreiser), as well as the landmark works of criticism on the two modes.

title: The Gay Nineties: Genealogies of Gender
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the development of gender studies from 1978 to the present. Authors include: Foucault, De Lauretis, Butler, Halperin, Sedgwick, Edelman, Bersani. Topics: issues in gay and lesbian representation, the politics of sexuality, queer theory.

title: Realism and Naturalism: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the defining instances of realism and naturalism (Balzac, Eliot, Howells; Zola, Gissing, Dreiser), as well as the landmark works of criticism on the two modes.

title: Literary History and Cultural Memory: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Graduate seminar on theories of memory and history (from Aristotle to Vico to Hulburachs, Benjamin and Derrida) and on the place of literature in such theories.

title: Literary History and Cultural Memory: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Graduate seminar on theories of memory and history (from Aristotle to Vico to Hulburachs, Benjamin and Derrida) and on the place of literature in such theories.

title: Poetics and Politics of Mourning: 20th-Century Women's Fiction: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of contemporary psychoanalytic theories of mourning in connection with fiction by Chopin, Hurston, Kingston, Morrison, Rhys, Wharton, Woolf. Also appropriate for qualified undergraduates.

title: On Beauty: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Philosophic and literary accounts of beauty from Greek through modern, including Plato, Aquinas, Dante, Kant, Keats, and Rilke. In addition, the major arguments against beauty; and its stability across four objects (God, gardens, persons, and poems).

title: On Beauty: Graduate Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Philosophic and literary accounts of beauty from Greek through modern, including Plato, Aquinas, Dante, Castiglione, Addison, Kant, Keats, Rilke. The central descriptions of beauty; the major arguments against it (e.g., the view that it disables critical judgment, hence is politically suspect); and an examination of four objects taken to be sites of beauty (God, gardens, persons, and poems).
