title: Reading Paradise Lost
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A book-by-book reading of Milton's great epic, attending to the representations of God, Satan, Adam and Eve, heaven, hell, Eden, and Chaos; to the problematics of heroism, love, work, gender relations, innocence and sin; and to matters of style and versification. Some other works will provide context, among them Virgil's Aeneid and parts of the Bible, Ovid's Metamorphoses, and Spenser's Faerie Queene.

title: Reading Paradise Lost
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A book-by-book reading of Milton's great epic, attending to the representations of God, Satan, Adam and Eve, heaven, hell, Eden, and Chaos; to the problematics of heroism, love, work, gender relations, innocence and sin; and to matters of style and versification. Some other works will provide context, among them Virgil's Aeneid and parts of the Bible, Ovid's Metamorphoses, and Spenser's Faerie Queene.

title: Gender Difference and Sexual Relations in Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: From courtly love poetry to saints' lives, from scientific treatises to TheCanterbury Tales, the imaginative writings of the Middle Ages are full ofgender identities that surprise in their strangeness but are closely linked totoday's sexual norms and fantasies. Course readings include medieval chivalric,religious, scientific, and literary writings and reflect how sexuality andsubjectivity are shaped in tandem as well as how sexuality can disrupt andtransform stable selves.

title: The Age of Johnson: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: will examine the works of Samuel Johnson, James Boswell (Johnson's biographer), Edmund Burke, Mary Wollstonecraft, Edward Gibbon, Oliver Goldsmith, Frances Burney, Robert Burns, and others. Essays, biography, political and historical writing, poetry, and the novel.

title: The Age of Johnson: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: will examine the works of Samuel Johnson, James Boswell (Johnson's biographer), Edmund Burke, Mary Wollstonecraft, Edward Gibbon, Oliver Goldsmith, Frances Burney, Robert Burns, and others. Essays, biography, political and historical writing, poetry, and the novel.

title: Milton and his Contemporaries: Literature and Politics in the Era of Revolution (1629-1674)
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Milton's works, poetry and prose, examined in relation to various texts - literary and political - which refract the experience and culture of the revolutionary era in England. Contemporary texts include the poetry of the Cavalier poets, Herrick, and Marvell, as well as some essays, sermons, political tracts, histories, letters, and biographies, by contemporary men and women.

title: Milton and his Contemporaries: Literature and Politics in the Era of Revolution (1629-1674)
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Milton's works, poetry and prose, examined in relation to various texts - literary and political - which refract the experience and culture of the revolutionary era in England. Contemporary texts include the poetry of the Cavalier poets, Herrick, and Marvell, as well as some essays, sermons, political tracts, histories, letters, and biographies, by contemporary men and women.

title: The Pre-novel Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of pre-18th-century narratives exhibiting novelistic traits ranging from philosophical treatises, historical chronicles, and autobiography to saga and romance. Plato, Apuleius, Augustine, Geoffrey of Monmouth, Beroul, Vasari, Sir Thomas Browne, Bunyan, Vico (among others), with reference to Benjamin, Derrida, Foucault, and contemporary narrative theory.

title: Aesthetics of Industry, 1660-1830
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Literary depictions of agriculture, commerce, imperialism, the division of labor, and the author's "proper" place in that division. The politics of beauty and the beauty of political economy. Social diversity, organization, and literary authority. Readings include Dryden, Pope, Defoe, Lillo, Adam Smith, working-class poetry, Wordsworth, Hazlitt, others.

title: Saga and the Historical Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Auden's Generation
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: There is no quintessential poet of the 20th century, but what would we learn by imagining W.H. Auden in this role? In this course, we will undertake intensive study of a poet rendered both distinctive and emblematic by his effort to make a place for poetry in a violent world_a world not to be excused by poetic rituals or myths. We will also devote some time to poets who influenced Auden, such as Yeats and Eliot, and to Auden's impact on the writers of his own generation and after.

title: Shakespeare's Master Orators
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Reading of Shakespeare plays that represent improbable feats of persuasion performed by masterful, and often less than ideal, orators. By reading the plays alongside the rhetorical works that informed Shakespeare's age, we will develop an account of how persuasion happens--how spoken words change beliefs and move listeners to action.

title: Hardy, Eliot, Auden
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Poetry written in England from roughly the beginning of the century until the outbreak of the Second World War, as reflected in the work of a pre-modernist, a modernist, and a post-modernist. Special emphasis on the changing representations of England and of the poet.

title: American Dissent
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the mainstream American tradition of dissent through close readings of representative texts, from the Puritan dissenters through the Revolution, and the major writers of the antebellum period.

title: Henry James: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course surveys Henry James's career from the 1860s through his death. Readings will include short fiction and novels from all three major periods (novels to include Washington Square, The Portrait of a Lady, The Bostonians, The Spoils of Poynton, The Turn of the Screw, The Ambassadors, The Golden Bowl ) as well as selected journalism, theoretical essays, prefaces and letters. Some attention will also be given to the James family, especially William James, and to trends in transatlantic literary culture.

title: Henry James: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course surveys Henry James's career from the 1860s through his death. Readings will include short fiction and novels from all three major periods (novels to include Washington Square, The Portrait of a Lady, The Bostonians, The Spoils of Poynton, The Turn of the Screw, The Ambassadors, The Golden Bowl ) as well as selected journalism, theoretical essays, prefaces and letters. Some attention will also be given to the James family, especially William James, and to trends in transatlantic literary culture.

title: How to Live: When Literature Meets Self-Help
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Can literature teach us how to live? We will read some lauded contemporary narratives that strive to answer this question, such as Junot Diaz’s This is How You Lose Her (1996), Nick Hornby’s How to be Good (2001), Mohsin Hamid’s How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia (2013), and Eleanor Davis’s How to Be Happy (2014). We will investigate the role and uses of literary guidance in our advice-saturated culture. Can novels offer correctives to the materialist pursuit of success? Is self-invention possible, according to these authors, or are we determined by our origins?

title: How to Live: When Literature Meets Self-Help
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Can literature teach us how to live? We will investigate the role and uses of literary guidance in our advice-saturated culture.

title: The Harvard Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong:
This course addresses the genre of the “Harvard novel,” from Faulkner’s Absalom, Absalom! to Elif Batuman’s The Idiot and Zadie Smith’s On Beauty, in order to examine Harvard’s status and signification within the cultural imaginary. It brings together novels (and some films) where Harvard offers the narrative setting, supplies a character’s backstory, or even serves as a character in its own right. We will address themes of tradition, access, privilege, race, anxiety, competition, and canonicity. 

 

In addition to serving as an introduction to 20th-21st century Anglo-American literature, this seminar is designed to offer students an opportunity to slow down and engage more reflectively with the meaning and substance of their time on campus. Lectures will explore narrative depictions of how Harvard experiences extend into broader society, and also thelarger trajectory of the individual’s post-collegiate life.

title: How to Read a Book: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Historical and literary narratives of reading; texts by Cervantes, Richardson, Franklin, Sterne, Flaubert, Ellison, and Bradbury, together with research exercises in Harvard library and museum collections.

title: Politics and Poetics of Augustan and Modern Satire
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: What are the formal characteristics of satire? Is satire a moral mode of writing, as satirists often claim? Does satire have a political bias: is it conservative or radical in its relation to society and tradition? Why did satire flourish in England during the early eighteenth century and then again in the early twentieth century? Authors include: Rochester, Pope, Swift, Gay, Johnson, T.S. Eliot, Huxley, Orwell, and Waugh.

title: When Harlem Was in Vogue: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine the aesthetics and politics of the first Modern African American cultural movement, known today as the Harlem Renaissance. In our readings of key literary texts by authors such as Alain Locke, Jessie Fauset, Zora Neale Hurston, Eric Walrond, Langston Hughes, Claude McKay, Nella Larsen, and Jean Toomer, we will discuss both the national and global contexts of so-called "New Negro Writing" and focus on debates surrounding representation, "respectability" and racial authenticity.

title: Sex and Gender in Victorian Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How did Victorian literature shape gender roles, both exotic and familiar? And how did nineteenth-century ideas about sex shape a modern system of literary genres? Course considers sex and money, work and marriage, reading and shopping, domestic realism and utopian fantasy, feminism and anti-feminism, in fiction (Bronte, Dickens, Collins, Eliot, Conan Doyle, James), essays (Ruskin, Mill, Nightingale) and more ephemeral genres including pornography, cookbooks, and legal tracts.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Sex and money, reading and shopping, work and marriage, domestic realism and imperial fantasy, unsexed women and unmanned men, feminism and anti-feminism, single-sex communities and same-sex desire. Short stories and long novels by Austen, Brontë, Gaskell, Dickens, Collins, Eliot, Oliphant, and Conan Doyle, as well as essays by Ruskin, Mill, Trollope, and others.

title: Wordsworth and Coleridge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An in-depth look at the celebrated friendship_and falling out_of these two foundational figures of Romanticism, emphasizing the collaboration on Lyrical Ballads. Topics to include: literary friendship and rivalry; the writer's relationship to different readerships; the poetry theory of the "Lake School." We will consider writers in the poets' immediate circle, e.g. Dorothy Wordsworth and Charles Lamb, and the poets' influence on a younger generation of Romantics, including De Quincey, Hazlitt, Shelley, and Keats.

title: Mental Flight: The Poetry of Blake, Wordsworth, and Coleridge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close study of three Romantic poets. Some emphasis will be placed on their special interest in formal and thematic experiment and their active reevaluation of the poet/audience relationship. In addition to Wordsworth and Coleridge's Lyrical Ballads and Blake's Songs of Innocence and of Experience, primary texts will include a range of post-1800 verse by all three writers and extensive selections from Wordsworth's The Prelude and Blake's Jerusalem.

title: Mental Flight: The Poetry of Blake, Wordsworth, and Coleridge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Close study of three Romantic poets. Some emphasis will be placed on their special interest in formal and thematic experiment and their active reevaluation of the poet/audience relationship. In addition to Wordsworth and Coleridge's Lyrical Ballads and Blake's Songs of Innocence and of Experience, primary texts will include a range of post-1800 verse by all three writers and extensive selections from Wordsworth's The Prelude and Blake's Jerusalem.

title: Interracial Lit: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines a wide variety of literary texts on black-white couples, interracial families, and biracial identity, from classical antiquity to the present. Works studied include romances, novellas, plays, novels, short stories, poems, and non-fiction, as well as some films and examples from the visual arts. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding. This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engages substantially with Study of the Past.

title: Coetzee and Ishiguro
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: J. M. Coetzee and Kazuo Ishiguro, contemporary masters of the novel in English, struggle with the most pressing problems of form, including the return of realism, the relation between novels and ideas, and meta-fiction. At the same time, they examine central ethical challenges, such as the rights of animals, cloning, and the representation of war. The seminar combines minute literary analysis with a discussion of how literary style confronts the contemporary world.

title: Coetzee and Ishiguro
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: J. M. Coetzee and Kazuo Ishiguro, contemporary masters of the novel in English, struggle with the most pressing problems of form, including the return of realism, the relation between novels and ideas, and meta-fiction. At the same time, they examine central ethical challenges, such as the rights of animals, cloning, and the representation of war. title: 19th-Century Fiction and the Meaning of Space
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We explore how space is represented in eight major novels from Frankenstein to Dracula. Space, social and `inner' psychological space, domestic and colonial, rural and urban, public and private, masculine and feminine, shapes the form of fiction and generates urgent questions about the world we live in. We look at the way space has been conceptualized in different ways by philosophers, geographers, planners, and theorists, from Kant to Bachelard. One long paper required.

title: 19th-Century Fiction and the Meaning of Space
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We explore how space is represented in eight major novels from Frankenstein to Dracula. Space, social and `inner' psychological space, domestic and colonial, rural and urban, public and private, masculine and feminine, shapes the form of fiction and generates urgent questions about the world we live in. We look at the way space has been conceptualized in different ways by philosophers, geographers, planners, and theorists, from Kant to Bachelard. One long paper required.

title: Going Underground in 19th-Century Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: New theories and discoveries in geology, biology, economics, and psychology fueled the 19th-century subterranean imagination. The underground became a space where writers encountered the distant past and future as well as the social underworld of their present. We will consider the ways Victorian novelists, poets, scientists, and journalists explored and exposed ``the buried life.'' Some likely authors: Dickens, Carroll, Bulwer-Lytton, Lyell, Arnold, Gissing, Haggard, Hardy, Wells, and Conrad, with sideways glances at Poe, Verne, and Doestoevsky.

title: Going Underground in 19th-Century Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: New theories and discoveries in geology, biology, economics, and psychology fueled the 19th-century subterranean imagination. title: The Gothic Revival and 19th-Century British Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the influence of the Gothic Revival on 19th-century poetry. Topics of discussion will include the relationship of poetry to history, the nationalist and internationalist implications of 19th-century medievalism, and the poetic reconstruction of a chivalrous ethic - with its mingling of love, honor, and violence - in an industrial age. Writers will include Coleridge, Keats, Scott, Tennyson, Browning, Morris, Swinburne, Yeats.

title: The Gothic Revival and 19th-Century British Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the influence of the Gothic Revival on 19th-century poetry. Topics of discussion will include the relationship of poetry to history, the nationalist and internationalist implications of 19th-century medievalism, and the poetic reconstruction of a chivalrous ethic - with its mingling of love, honor, and violence - in an industrial age. Writers will include Coleridge, Keats, Scott, Tennyson, Browning, Morris, Swinburne, Yeats.

title: Rebels and Conformists in Victorian Fiction and Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores Victorian texts which take rebellion against convention as their theme. The rebel is most often a woman, sometimes a child. In the first group of texts, dissidence takes several forms - resistance to education, social taboos and political norms: Charlotte Bronte's Jane Eyre, Anne Bronte's Agnes Grey, and some of Emily Bronte's poems, Dickens's Dombey and Son, Rossetti's Goblin Market and Jean IngeIow's poem Gladys and her Island. The second group of texts explores transgression through the 'sensation' novel: Collins's The Woman in White and Braddon's Lady Audley's Secret - and through tales of the 'fallen woman': Mrs. Gaskell's Ruth and Elizabeth Barrett Browning's Aurora Leigh (extracts). Third, 'new woman' texts of the late century make a vigorous critique of sexual and political convention. We will look at poems by Augusta Webster and some short stories, in order to see how the conventions of Victorian writing stretched to consider convention itself. Photocopies of the poetry will be provided. You will be expected to buy the fiction. The course alternates shorter poems with fiction so you will have time to read the novels.

title: Becoming Samuel Johnson
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A careful examination of the writings and thought of Samuel Johnson; and an investigation into the construction of Johnson: "Great Bear,'' "literary hero,'' "cultural dictator,'' "Tory Anglican,'' "radical anti-monarchist.'' Attention given to theories of history, biography, and culture, with readings in Boswell and other contemporaries, as well as modern critics, theorists, and biographers.

title: Mary Shelley and Her Circle
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of works by Mary Shelley, William Godwin, Mary Wollstonecraft, Percy Bysshe Shelley, and others.

title: Swift, Pope and the Boys
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Exploring representations of masculine wit, this seminar will examine issues of gender and authority in writings by the Scriblerus Club members and their contemporaries.

title: 19th-Century Fiction: Space and Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: It is customary to link time and narrative, but this course will explore the different ways in which space is represented in 19th-century novels - through landscape, the humanly made and gendered spaces of the house and the city, the body and its gestures. Beginning with Mary Shelley's Frankenstein and ending with Bram Stoker's Dracula, we will consider how social space, "inner" psychological space, domestic, rural, urban and colonial space, are constructed through language and how they shape the form of fiction and disclose concerns about society and the individual subject. We shall also look at the way space has been conceptualised by a number of thinkers, philosophers, planners and theorists, from Kant to Lefebvre.

title: 19th-Century Fiction: Space and Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: It is customary to link time and narrative, but this course will explore the different ways in which space is represented in 19th-century novels - through landscape, the humanly made and gendered spaces of the house and the city, the body and its gestures. Beginning with Mary Shelley's Frankenstein and ending with Bram Stoker's Dracula, we will consider how social space, "inner" psychological space, domestic, rural, urban and colonial space, are constructed through language and how they shape the form of fiction and disclose concerns about society and the individual subject. We shall also look at the way space has been conceptualised by a number of thinkers, philosophers, planners and theorists, from Kant to Lefebvre.

title: 19th-Century Fiction: Space and Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In a series of novels and stories from Mary Shelley's Frankenstein to Bram Stoker's Dracula, including Jane Austen's Mansfield Park, Emily Brontë's Wuthering Heights, Charlotte Brontë's Villette, George Eliot's The Mill on the Floss, Charles Dickens' Bleak House, William Makepeace Thackeray's Vanity Fair, Rudyard Kipling's Beyond the Pale, and Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, we explore the different ways in which space is represented in the 19th- and early 20th-century novel. Social space, "inner" psychological space, domestic space, rural, urban, and colonial space, all shape the form of fiction and disclose concerns about society and the individual subject's relation to it.

title: Literature and Science in the 19th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: From the unstoppable force of Frankenstein's monster to the ``unsinkable'' Titanic, the literary imagination over the 19th century found in science and technology not only new sources of inspiration but also new reasons for dread. We examine the ways science challenged literature and the notion of artistic truth at the same time that it offered new directions for artistic exploration. Topics: technology and/of the body, Darwinism and the Victorian crisis of faith, the interrelation of science and imperialism, the cultural impact of new communications technologies, and the emergence of science fiction as a literary genre. Authors: Mary Shelley, Dickens, Darwin, Stevenson, Hardy, Stoker, and Wells.

title: The Poet in the Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The most private, ``difficult'' and unpopular of the arts makes occasional but important appearances in the most public and popular, bringing with it questions about the social function of the imagination, kinds of literature and kinds of knowledge, the relation between high and mass culture. This course studies 20th-century novels (and films) in which poets and poetry appear as central characters and concerns: James's The Aspern Papers, Joyce's Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, Nabokov's Pale Fire, Bellow's Humboldt's Gift, Cocteau's Orphée, Hal Hartley's Henry Fool and others.

title: India in English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How is India represented in English? We shall look at the staging of a Mughal court for Charles II, a parliamentary speech, a set of colonial lithographs, an Anglo-Indian dictionary, and a series of European-style palaces built by Indian princes. Alongside these, we shall read authors such as Forster, Kipling, Narayan, Rushdie, Desai, Ghosh, Naipaul, Ezekiel, and Lahiri.

title: The American Transcendentalists
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of the principal works of Emerson and Thoreau in broader cultural, especially religious, context. Some attention also to such figures as Alcott, Fuller, Parker, Ripley, and Very.

title: The Poetry of Walt Whitman
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Walt Whitman, considering his exemplary function in American literature. Some topics: colonial poetry; nationalist poetry; the organic volume; perception into language; genres in Whitman; the poetry of geography; erotics of writing; the poetry of war.

title: Reforming America
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the impact of antebellum reform movements on American literature and culture. The challenge to authority, control of the body, and problem of national renewal in the overlapping of discourses on temperance, antislavery, feminism, hydropathy, phrenology, spiritualism, nativism, and educational reform. Readings in Alcott, Emerson, Fuller, Hawthorne, James, Lippard, Stowe, Whitman, and others.

title: Charles Dickens and Herman Melville
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys the careers of Dickens and Melville, from their early popular works to their difficult late style. Readings range across a number of genres, but the encyclopedic major novels (Bleak House, Moby-Dick, and Our Mutual Friend) are at the center of the course.

title: Charles Dickens and Herman Melville
subject: ENGLISH

subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: An extensive study of Dickinson's poetry throughout her writing life. Topics: inflexibility of form; enigma of content; idiosyncrasy of expression; landscape; grief and ecstasy; seeing "New Englandly."

title: The Poetry of Emily Dickinson

courseDescriptionLong: An extensive study of Dickinson's poetry throughout her writing life. Topics: inflexibility of form; enigma of content; idiosyncrasy of expression; landscape; grief and ecstasy; seeing "New Englandly."

title: Whitman and Dickinson
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive study of two major American poets. Particular attention paid to the development of Whitman's and Dickinson's poetic careers and to the establishment of their reputations. Uses textual history to illuminate both these poets' 19th-century contexts, and their 20th-century legacy.

title: Poems of Seamus Heaney and Thomas Hardy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Written a century apart, the poems of Seamus Heaney and Thomas Hardy create an urgent call and response between earth and under-earth. The poets share metrical virtuosity, compressed lyric forms, the unfolding of personal history within public crisis and transformation, and the recognition that the acuity of sentience - the daily practice of exquisitely precise perceptual acts - is the ethical center of our brief stay above ground.

title: American Heirs: History, Tradition, and Possession in 19th-Century American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Works by such authors as Hawthorne, Howells, James, Jewett, Hopkins, Crane, and Cahan raise questions about the substance of a national identity and the trajectory of a cherished narrative of millennial fulfillment in the second half of the 19th century. This course charts the careers of several of the most prominent heirs in American literature against contemporary movements in courts and financial markets intended to bring inheritance practices in line with the nation's altered historical circumstances. Changing conceptions of wealth will be explored, as well as the interactions between social legislation, material transactions, and aesthetic movements.

title: Fictions of Kinship
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Special attention to the politics of the incest taboo, the ideal of universal siblinghood, confusions of kin with kind, and notions of national identity. Works include Mark Twain's Pudd'nhead Wilson, Jean Racine's Britannicus, Shakespeare's Hamlet, H.G. Wells' War of the Worlds, Coleridge's ^'^' To an Ass'', Sophocles' Oedipus the King, Mirror of the Sinful Soul by Queen Elizabeth I, Melville's Pierre, and Nabokov's Ada.

title: Fictions of Kinship
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Lyric Poetry from Greek Antiquity to European Romanticism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Are there distinctive features to lyric poetry that transcend differences of language, geography, and historical period? Can we speak of the lyric (the word is from the Greek lyra, a stringed instrument used to accompany a song) as a genre, or literary ``kind'' that allows us to classify and analyze together texts by poets as different as Pindar and Collins, or Coleridge, or Baudelaire? We will investigate such questions while reading great lyric poets from antiquity to the late romantic period. Major figures include Sappho, Pindar, Horace, Arnaut Daniel, Petrarch, Ronsard, Wyatt, Spenser, Donne, Jonson, Marvell, Collins, Gray, Wordsworth, Keats, Hugo, Baudelaire, Mallarmé, Holderlin, and Rilke.

title: Late 19th-Century English Culture: End of the Century, End of the World
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the work of the English fin de siècle, attempting to locate the concerns behind such movements as Decadence and Aestheticism, and to consider how they may play a part in the rise of Modernism. Topics include the importance of art, the sense of fear, the problem of knowledge, and the ramifications of empire. Authors include Pater, Wilde, Hardy, Stoker, Stevenson, Kipling, James, Hopkins, Yeats.

title: The American Civil War: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Studies in the literature of the American Civil War, from letters, speeches, poetry, and photography to diaries, stories, and novels. We consider aesthetic, historical, and intellectual dimensions and focus in particular on national and section identities; the shift from romanticism to realism; and dilemmas of slavery, race, and freedom. Authors include Melville, Whitman, Douglass, Lincoln, Stowe, Alcott, Twain, Crane, Mary Chesnut, Bierce, and others.

title: The American Civil War

title: Chicano Narrative Genres
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Chicano narrative forms with a focus on the interrelations among literature, politics, and history. Chicano examples of novel, romance, satire, autobiography, short-story cycle, semblanza, and chronicle will be examined within their own geographic, cultural, and historical contexts as well as within Anglo-American, Spanish, Mexican and Latin American literary traditions. Writers include Oscar Zeta Acosta, Rudolfo Anaya, Ron Arias, Sandra Cisneros, Rolando Hinojosa, and Tomás Rivera.

title: Chicano Narrative Genres

title: Letters of Business and the Business of Letters: The American Literary Enterprise
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The literary men and women of American business, from Bartleby to Babbit, Cotton Mather and Franklin to Dreiser. We will investigate pronouncements like T.S. Eliot's that Americans, "like to be told that they are a race of commercial buccaneers," as well as doubts such as Teddy Roosevelt's, that the national type might be the "glorified huckster or glorified pawnbroker." Issues to be discussed include the advent of the professional writer and the cultural construction of the entrepreneur. The novels, stories, and criticism of Hawthorne, Fanny Fern, Norris, and Wharton will be supplemented by the works of writers such as Veblen, Bellamy, Clark and James Truslow Adams.

title: Jane Austen
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: There can be nothing trivial about Jane Austen's stories of marriage in a liberal culture that retains the marriage obligation by naturalizing it, via a myth of romantic love, as the individual's own willed choice of her best moral (and not just practical) good. The better to grasp Austen's project, we shall consider it against other culturally "starred'' narratives of romance, passion, and lust, including those like Barbara Pym's that take place in a postconjugal world.

courseDescriptionLong: Austen's novels with special attention to the political, historical, literary, and critical contexts in which Austen wrote and is now consumed. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: American Landscapes: Discovery to the Present
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines perspectives on American landscapes available from the voyages of discovery through the later half of the 20th century, focusing on how writers and painters situated the self within protean environments. Novels, travelogues, and other writings by Hamilton, Sarah Knight, de Crevecoeur, Howells, Dreiser, Cather, and Updike, among others, will be read in conjunction with early tourism documents and dime novels. Landscape designs by F.L. Olmsted and paintings by Smibert, Church, and Fitz-Hugh Lane will supplement written texts.

title: Introduction to LGBTQ Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar looks at the expanding range of genres, forms and strategies pursued by modern and contemporary authors who want to represent LGBTQ+- lives, communities, bodies and selves; poems and performances, novels and stories, YA and SFF books, memoirs and essays, comics and graphic novels, will all be represented, along with a light frame of what's usually called queer theory and some points of comparison, or contrast, from earlier centuries. Bechdel, Audre Lorde, O'Hara, Russ, Sedgwick, White, Whitman, and many others.

title: The Idea of Ireland
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Literary representations of Ireland and ``the Irish'' in the English language. Emphasis will be on 19th- and 20th-century authors, including Synge, AE, Lady Gregory, Yeats, Joyce, Heaney, and Friel.

title: The Idea of Italy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of 19th- and early 20th-century English and American representations of Italy in fiction, narrative poetry, and nonfictional prose. Authors include Byron, Ruskin, Browning, George Eliot, Hawthorne, Longfellow, James, and Forster. Special attention paid to art, religion, and conceptions of Italian character.

title: Literature, Justice, and Rights in the Age of Revolution
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: In the wake of the American and French Revolutions and amidst growing calls for social and legal change, British writers began exploring political questions with new urgency. In this course, we read a range of texts published between 1780 and 1820, examining the ways that they both participated in and were shaped by debates about freedom, equality, justice, authority, toleration, cruelty, and pain. Likely authors include Burke, Wollstonecraft, Equiano, More, Barbauld, Edgeworth, Godwin, Austen, Wordsworth, and Mary Shelley. Secondary readings by historians, philosophers, and literary critics including Gary Kelly, Thomas Haskell, Lynn Hunt, and Martha Nussbaum.

title: Law and Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course will explore the complex relationship between literature and law, focusing on how each represents and responds to violence and its aftermath. As we survey a series of twentieth-century juridical paradigms (trials, rights, reparations, and reconciliation), our goal will not be to judge the efficacy of literary and legal projects, but rather to study how they imagine issues of guilt, responsibility, testimony, commemoration, apology and forgiveness. Our readings will include novels, short stories, poetry, legal theory, documentaries, and key documents of international law: authors will most likely include Hannah Arendt, J.M. Coetzee, Jacques Derrida, Franz Kafka, Michael Ondaatje, Julie Otsuka, and M. NourbeSe Philip.

title: Literature of Mourning: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How do you write about what doesn't exist (anymore)? The course considers texts that were prompted by personal or professional grief, looking at how loss both structures and prevents expression. Issues of temporality, permanence, and immortality are central concerns. Students are invited to contribute readings and undertake analyses of mourning, broadly conceived. Texts include Milton's Lycidas, Shakespeare's King Lear, poems by Wordsworth and Keats, Kieslowski's Blue, Didion's Year of Magical Thinking, and Morrison's A Mercy.

title: Postmodernism: Theories and Fictions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An inquiry into some of the headaches caused by postmodernism. Jameson and Lyotard encounter Beckett and Maxine Hong Kingston, among others.

subject: ENGLISH

title: Poets: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

title: The Landscape of Contemporary Native American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Combining poetry and fiction with recent literary criticism, this course will offer an immersion in the landscape of contemporary Native American literature. Topics will include the intertwined and sometimes contested interplay between native oral traditions, the representation of Indian images, and the role of writer as witness to colonization. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: The Landscape of Contemporary Native American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Combining poetry and fiction with recent literary criticism, this course will offer an immersion in the landscape of contemporary Native American literature. Topics will include the intertwined and sometimes contested interplay between native oral traditions, the representation of Indian images, and the role of writer as witness to colonization. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Literature and the Philosophy of Mind
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Literature and the philosophy of mind share a number of concerns. Both attempt to create artificial representations of ``intelligence'' and to explore the limits of consciousness. Both are interested in the role that emotions play in reasoning about the world. Both explore the possibility that there might be such things as private or universal languages; both dwell upon the difficulties of knowing and understanding other minds. This course will consider what is to be learned when we consider literary texts (principally lyric poems) in conjunction with some of our best recent philosophical and scientific accounts of how the mind is made.

title: Consciousness from Austen to Woolf: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A look at the complex ways in which writers represent their characters' thought in texts by Austen, Flaubert, James, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Giovanni Verga, and Woolf. More broadly, traces the development of stream-of-consciousness, from Austen's incipient mastery of free indirect style, through Flaubert's more sophisticated use of it, to Woolf's full-blown inner monologues, seeing this development as not merely a fact of English and American literature, but as a phenomenon of world literature and an element of our modernity.

title: Consciousness from Austen to Woolf: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A look at the complex ways in which writers represent their characters' thought in texts by Austen, Flaubert, James, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Giovanni Verga, and Woolf. More broadly, traces the development of stream-of-consciousness, from Austen's incipient mastery of free indirect style, through Flaubert's more sophisticated use of it, to Woolf's full-blown inner monologues, seeing this development as not merely a fact of English and American literature, but as a phenomenon of world literature and an element of our modernity.

title: Literature and War
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This interdisciplinary course explores how war has been represented from antiquity to the present, with particular focus on the 19th century to yesterday.  We explore how the literature of war shaped armed conflict and memories of it, and how war affected forms of representation.  Readings range from "classic" literature to photography, print and broadcast journalism, cinema, and music.

title: American Fictions of Animal Organizations
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Concerned with entities as distinct as Jefferson's mastadon, Melville's whale, and sculptor Nancy Grave's camels, this course examines aesthetic representations of what Emerson called "Animal Organization" in works by Jefferson, Emerson, Cooper, Thoreau, Melville, Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr., James, Chopin, Wharton, London, Norris, Bellow, Hemingway, Bishop and Morrison. Selections from Jung and Freud will be included, as will some works of painting and sculpture.

title: Spenser's Faerie Queene and the Renaissance Imagination: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the works of the Edmund Spenser, with an emphasis on his masterpiece The Faerie Queene. The course will give particular attention to Spenser's roots in the Bible and classical literature, his use of allegory, and his engagement with the politics and writing of his own day.

title: Spenser's Faerie Queene and the Renaissance Imagination: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the works of the Edmund Spenser, with an emphasis on his masterpiece The Faerie Queene. The course will give particular attention to Spenser's roots in the Bible and classical literature, his use of allegory, and his engagement with the politics and writing of his own day.

title: Jameses and Jameseans
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The first half of this course will focus on the literary and intellectual careers of Henry, William and Alice James; the second half will take up some of their most interesting students and heirs including Edith Wharton, Robert Frost, W.E.B. Du Bois, Gertrude Stein, Cynthia Ozick and Richard Rorty. Matters under discussion will be the uses of art, the problem of evil, the nature of experience, the meaning ofcitizenship, the disappointment of America.

title: Renaissance Metamorphoses: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will trace the reception of Ovid's Metamorphoses through the diverse responses of Marlowe, Shakespeare, Spenser, Milton and Dryden, exploring how English Renaissance writers fashioned their own poetry in response to the generative power of Ovid's work.

title: Henry James
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major works of the author, with some emphasis on his late period. Placing James between Victorianism and Modernism, this course considers his texts for such typical concerns as secrets, fear, desire, and the relation between American and European culture.

title: The Rhetoric of Belief
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the literature of religious, political, or ethical commitment. Readings from Paul, Augustine, Luther, Lincoln, Gandhi, Martin Luther King, Jr., Hannah Arendt, and Dorothy Day.

title: Henry James
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major works of the author, with some emphasis on his late period. Placing James between Victorianism and Modernism, this course considers his texts for such typical concerns as secrets, fear, desire, and the relation between American and European culture.

title: Renaissance Metamorphoses: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will trace the reception of Ovid's Metamorphoses through the diverse responses of Marlowe, Shakespeare, Spenser, Milton and Dryden, exploring how English Renaissance writers fashioned their own poetry in response to the generative power of Ovid's work.

title: Renaissance Metamorphoses: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will trace the reception of Ovid's Metamorphoses through the diverse responses of Marlowe, Shakespeare, Spenser, Milton and Dryden, exploring how English Renaissance writers fashioned their own poetry in response to the generative power of Ovid's work.

title: The Other Middle Ages
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of non-Chaucerian, non-Arthurian and non-Trojan works in Middle English, divided into threeinterlocking sections: first, poets of the fifteenth century, including Hoccleve, Lydgate, Charles d'Orleansand King James I of Scotland, James I will serve as an introduction to a section on vernacular writing in Scotland, including selections from historiography (John Barbour's The Bruce, Andrew Wyntoun's Croykils)short poems by Henryson and Dunbar, and extracts from Gavin Douglas's translation of the Aenied; finallythe course will conclude with and overview of the important tradition of Alexandar the Great romances, focusing on the oriental fantasy Alexander and Dindimus.

title: The Other Middle Ages
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Modern American Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Machine Dreams
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: In 1920, Czech playwright Karel Čapek coined the term "robot" in his play R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) and transformed societal conceptions of mechanical beings. This course investigates how machines, robots, and codes are represented in, and shaped by literary texts. With a focus on contemporary literature and digital theory, books include Douglas Kearny's The Black Automaton (2009), How We Became Posthuman (1999) by N. Katherine Hales, and The Automaton Biographies (2009) by Larissa Lai, as well as android music videos by Janelle Monae (among other media). In addition to critical reading and writing, students will explore robots, technology, and science fiction through critical, creative, and digital praxis.

title: Medieval Drama
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines dramatic texts and performance from the early Middle Ages up to and including the sixteenth century. Investigating ritual performance and the liturgy; carnival games and mummers' plays; civic drama and staging the Passion; court pageantry and spectacle; commercial theater, its reforming opponents, and the medieval stage of Marlowe and Shakespeare - we'll consider the limits of performance (in drama, ritual, magic), the implications of playing God, and suffering as spectacle. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: American Dissent
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the mainstream American tradition of dissent through close readings of representative texts, from the Puritan dissenters through the Revolution, to the central writers of the antebellum period.

title: American Dissent
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the mainstream American tradition of dissent through close readings of representative texts, from the Puritan dissenters through the Revolution, to the central writers of the antebellum period.

title: American Dissent
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of the mainstream American tradition of dissent through close readings of representative texts, from the Puritan dissenters through the Revolution, and the major writers of the antebellum period.

title: Medieval Drama
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines dramatic texts and performance from the early Middle Ages up to and including the sixteenth century. Investigating ritual performance and the liturgy; carnival games and mummers' plays; civic drama and staging the Passion; court pageantry and spectacle; commercial theater, its reforming opponents, and the medieval stage of Marlowe and Shakespeare - we'll consider the limits of performance (in drama, ritual, magic), the implications of playing God, and suffering as spectacle. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Medieval English Drama: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The drama of medieval England provided entertainment and education in a variety of forms. The massive "cycle" dramas recreated the entirety of Biblical history on a number of carts which processed through the streets of cities, while morality plays such as Everyman provided an intimate look at a soul's response to the approach of death. The course will culminate in a performance of a play to be chosen in the first weeks of class.

title: Medieval English Drama: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: The Rise of the Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The course examines the rise of the novel as a genre in England through a close reading of major works by Bunyan, Defoe, Richardson, and Fielding (Pilgrim's Progress, Robinson Crusoe, Moll Flanders, Pamela, Clarissa, Joseph Andrews, and Tom Jones). Expected to be given in 2009-10.

title: Studies in Defoe, Richardson, and Fielding
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of major novels by these early masters of fiction: Robinson Crusoe, Moll Flanders, Roxana, Pamela, Clarissa, Joseph Andrews, Tom Jones.

title: Melville
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Melville, with Moby-Dick as the centerpiece.  The focus is on Melville’s aesthetics and its resonance in his era and ours.  We also read Melville’s shorter fiction and nonfiction, including Typee, Benito Cereno, and Billy Budd; his Civil War poetry; some criticism and contemporaneous writings; and visual art that his work inspired.

title: Alice, Henry, and William James
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The writings of the Jameses as a window on the social, intellectual, and literary worlds of their time. Readings include: Henry James, The Portrait of a Lady, The Bostonians, The Wings of the Dove and short stories; William James, selections from The Principles of Psychology, The Varieties of Religious Experience, and Pragmatism; Alice James, diaries.

title: Medieval Women and the Problem of Knowledge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: From Eve to Mary and from Lady Philosophy to Chaucer’s Wife of Bath, medieval women are associated with knowing, good and bad, philosophical and experiential.  We seek our own knowledge of them through allegories and visions, autobiographies and visions, philosophical studies and gynecological treatises.  Works by Robert Grosseteste, Catherine of Siena, Christine de Pizan, Julian of Norwich and Margery Kempe.

title: Medieval Women and the Problem of Knowledge
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: From Eve to Mary and from Lady Philosophy to Chaucer’s Wife of Bath, medieval women are associated with knowing, good and bad, philosophical and experiential.  We seek our own knowledge of them through allegories and visions, autobiographies and visions, philosophical studies and gynecological treatises.  Works by Robert Grosseteste, Catherine of Siena, Christine de Pizan, Julian of Norwich and Margery Kempe.

title: Money and Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Money and language as means of representation, exchange, and production. Principal literary texts include works by Shakespeare, Melville, Poe, Thoreau, Ruskin, Joyce, and Martineau as well as attention to novels where a coin is the narrator and to coins inscribed with poetic epigrams. Special consideration of the economics of literature from Aristotle to Heidegger, the relationship between monetary and aesthetic form in visual arts and cinema, and various theories of money as social fiction. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Money and Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Money and language as means of representation, exchange, and production. Principal literary texts include works by Shakespeare, Melville, Poe, Thoreau, Ruskin, Joyce, and Martineau as well as attention to novels where a coin is the narrator and to coins inscribed with poetic epigrams. Special consideration of the economics of literature from Aristotle to Heidegger, the relationship between monetary and aesthetic form in visual arts and cinema, and various theories of money as social fiction. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: 1850s: The Making of Modernity in Western Culture: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This transnational course explores the emergence of modern life in the west, reflected by the canonical texts published (or translated into English) from 1850 to 1861. Points of focus include the aesthetics of freedom and bondage; the rise of realism and liberalism; the intersection between consciousness and material conditions; conceptions of progress, history, and desire. Authors include Marx, Darwin, Mill, Lincoln and Douglas; Tennyzon, Whitman, Dickenson; Douglass, Jacobs, Melville, Hawthorne, Thoreau, Emerson; Balzac, Flaubert, Turgenev, Dickens, Eliot.

title: 1850s: The Making of Modernity in Western Culture: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This transnational course explores the emergence of modern life in the west, reflected by the canonical texts published (or translated into English) from 1850 to 1861. Points of focus include the aesthetics of freedom and bondage; the rise of realism and liberalism; the intersection between consciousness and material conditions; conceptions of progress, history, and desire. Authors include Marx, Darwin, Mill, Lincoln and Douglas; Tennyzon, Whitman, Dickenson; Douglass, Jacobs, Melville, Hawthorne, Thoreau, Emerson; Balzac, Flaubert, Turgenev, Dickens, Eliot.

title: Monsters and Marvels
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: A chain of medieval trade and pilgrimage routes stretched from Iceland to Indonesia, and distant lands were a subject of powerful fascination to medieval readers. How did medieval English writers and readers imagine the world? How did narratives of travel, conquest, pilgrimage, and exploration wrestle with questions of religious, ethnic, and cultural diversity, racial and national identity, and the limits of human knowledge? We examine medieval illuminations, illustrations, and maps alongside texts including the Crusade romance The King of Tars, the pilgrimage account of Margery Kempe, and the incredibly popular Book of John Mandeville.

title: The 1880's, An American Renaissance: Methods Toward a Critical Literary History
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The burgeoning of American literature during this decade will be examined by juxtaposing a few crucial careers such as James' and Howell's with important works by such of their contemporaries as George Washington Cable, Henry Adams, and Sarah Orne Jewett. Also to be discussed: the challenge of regionalism to cosmopolitanism; the tension between romance and realism; the magazine trade; and the emergence of a critical tradition.

title: The 1880's, An American Renaissance: Methods Toward a Critical Literary History
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The burgeoning of American literature during this decade will be examined by juxtaposing a few crucial careers such as James' and Howell's with important works by such of their contemporaries as George Washington Cable, Henry Adams, and Sarah Orne Jewett. Also to be discussed: the challenge of regionalism to cosmopolitanism; the tension between romance and realism; the magazine trade; and the emergence of a critical tradition.

title: Mark Twain and His World
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Twain's major works along with contemporary influences. Open to advanced undergraduates as well as graduate students. Readings include Roughing It; Gilded Age; Tom Sawyer; Prince and the Pauper; Life on the Mississippi; Adventures of Huckleberry Finn; Connecticut Yankee; Pudd'nhead Wilson; Mysterious Stranger; as well as works from Stowe, Davis, Chesnutt, Douglass, Whitman, Du Bois, Howells, London, Cable. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Mark Twain and His World
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Twain's major works along with contemporary influences. Open to advanced undergraduates as well as graduate students. Readings include Roughing It; Gilded Age; Tom Sawyer; Prince and the Pauper; Life on the Mississippi; Adventures of Huckleberry Finn; Connecticut Yankee; Pudd'nhead Wilson; Mysterious Stranger; as well as works from Stowe, Davis, Chesnutt, Douglass, Whitman, Du Bois, Howells, London, Cable. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: 19th-Century Visual Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the rise of visual culture in America from 1839 to the early twentieth century, with some comparative dimension from England and France. The course explores the intersection of literary modes with photography, print culture, and religious belief. Authors and image-makers include Whitman, Hawthorne, Spiritualists, Oscar Wilde, Lewis Carroll, Oliver Wendell Holmes, Henry James, Stephen Crane, Hart Crane, Southworth and Hawes, Brady, Barnard, Gardner, Stieglitz, Strand, Hine, Sarony, Nadar, and others.

title: Words and Music: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: How does music speak? How do words sing? Each student will formulate and develop a thesis for a single long paper. Note: Some background in music is necessary.

title: Why Poetry Matters When the Century Ends: Wordsworth, Hardy, Heaney
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Dante wrote New Life in the 1290's; Chaucer wrote the Canterbury Tales in the 1390's; Shakespeare (as well as Spenser and Denne) wrote extensively in the 1590's. This seminar will draw materials from the final decade of a range of centuries but will concentrate on Wordsworth (1790's), Hardy (novels and poems of the 1890's), and Heaney (1990's).

title: Why Poetry Matters When the Century Ends: Wordsworth, Hardy, Heaney
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Dante wrote New Life in the 1290's; Chaucer wrote the Canterbury Tales in the 1390's; Shakespeare (as well as Spenser and Denne) wrote extensively in the 1590's. This seminar will draw materials from the final decade of a range of centuries but will concentrate on Wordsworth (1790's), Hardy (novels and poems of the 1890's), and Heaney (1990's).

title: Gender, Sex, and Marriage in the Age of Enlightenment: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of changing representations of gender roles and sexual relations in literature of the long eighteenth century. We examine questions concerning love and marriage, seduction and consent; property and self-ownership, female friendship, gender and politics, and cross-racial ties. Authors include Behn, Finch, Astell, Congreve, Pope, Defoe, Hawyood, Sarah Scott, Burney, Sheridan, Wollstonecraft, Amelia Opie, and Austen.

title: Gender, Sex, and Marriage in the Age of Enlightenment: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of changing representations of gender roles and sexual relations in literature of the long eighteenth century. We examine questions concerning love and marriage, seduction and consent; property and self-ownership, female friendship, gender and politics, and cross-racial ties. Authors include Behn, Finch, Astell, Congreve, Pope, Defoe, Hawyood, Sarah Scott, Burney, Sheridan, Wollstonecraft, Amelia Opie, and Austen.

title: Eliot and Hardy
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Selected works by George Eliot and Thomas Hardy. Discussion focusing on, but not limited to, representations of history and materiality in relation to the texts' narrative technique.

title: The Thought of Theatre
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Designed to introduce students to the history of theatre in the West. Begins with Aeschylus, Kyd, Etherege, Molière, and Büchner, and ends with the contemporary scene of performance art, installation, and dance.

title: Native American Novels
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will concentrate on the ways nineteenth- and twentieth-century Native American writers have adapted the novel to imagine 1) the syncretism of literate and oral cultures and 2) the construction of ethnic identity in America. While asking whether these fictions constitute a distinct genre, ``the Native American novel,'' we will consider how the writers' projects challenge the assumptions of post-modern literature, raise issues central to post-colonial theory, and exploit the polyvocality of novelistic form. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Nabokov Novels in English: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores Nabokov's vision of art, testing its limits and possibilities through the novels that he wrote in English from The Real Life of Sebastian Knight (1941) through Ada or Ardor: A Family Chronicle (1969) and selected criticism.

title: Nabokov Novels in English: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: This course explores Nabokov's vision of art, testing its limits and possibilities through the novels that he wrote in English from The Real Life of Sebastian Knight (1941) through Ada or Ardor: A Family Chronicle (1969) and selected criticism.

title: Fraternity, Sorority, Celibacy: Singlehood in the Fin de Siecle
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Literary representations of the bachelor, bachelor-woman, spinster, New Woman, and male or female group at the turn of the century as well as accounts of singlehood in late Victorian anthropology, psychology, sexology, journalism. Texts include works by Norris, London, Gilman, Hopkins, James, and the papers of the all-male Tavern Club of Boston and the all-female Heterodites of Greenwich Village.

title: Rhetoric of Belief
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the literature of religious, political, or ethical committment. Readings from Luther, Thoreau, Lincoln, Harriet Jacobs, Gandhi, Martin Luther King, Jr., Hannah Arendt, Primo Levi, Dorothy Day, and Thomas Merton.

title: Rhetoric of Belief
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the literature of religious, political, or ethical commitment. Readings from Thoreau, Lincoln, Gandhi, Martin Luther King, Jr., Hannah Arendt, Gary Snyder, Rachel Carson, Primo Levi, Dorothy Day, Thomas Merton, and others. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: 18th-Century Narrative and the Law
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Law as both narrative principle and recurrent theme in 18th-century fiction. Readings drawn from Defoe, Gay, Fielding, Smollett, Burney. Areas of inquiry include: patriarchy, family, and the law; legal and novelistic ideas of the self; crime and the normative; punishment and correction in relation to narrative form.

title: 18th-Century Narrative and the Law
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Law as both narrative principle and recurrent theme in 18th-century fiction. Readings drawn from Defoe, Gay, Fielding, Smollett, Burney. Areas of inquiry include: patriarchy, family, and the law; legal and novelistic ideas of the self; crime and the normative; punishment and correction in relation to narrative form.

title: Nonfiction Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines seemingly inevitable suspensions of disbelief from Defoe to Eggers. How is it possible to confuse a novel with its external world? What happens when journalism and fiction merge? Course plays close attention to the institutions of veracity (medical, historical, journalistic, legal) and their usual documents (the case history, the cache, the eyewitness account, testimony). Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Nonfiction Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines seemingly inevitable suspensions of disbelief from Defoe to Janet Malcolm. How is it possible to confuse a novel with its external world? What happens when journalism and fiction merge? Course plays close attention to the institutions of veracity (medical, historical, journalistic, legal) and their usual documents (the case history, the cache, the eyewitness account, testimony).

title: Modernist Women Writers and Their Milieu
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Expands and complicates conventional delineations of modernism by studying numerous women modernists, analyzing the diversity of their concerns and techniques, and reconfiguring the social environment that prompted and resisted their work. Works by H. D., Stein, Larsen, Barnes, Woolf, Rhys, Colette, Yezierska, and others.

title: Narrative Poetry: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Proust
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Proust's Recherche in the entirety of its English translation.

title: On Reading Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores what work poems undertake and what work they therefore ask of the reader. We examine one primary poem (by a different poet) each week. Two short papers and some supplementary reading required. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: On Reading Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores what work poems undertake and what work they therefore ask of the reader. We examine one primary poem (by a different poet) each week. Two short papers and some supplementary reading required. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: On Reading Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores what work poems undertake and what work they therefore ask of the reader. We examine one primary poem (by a different poet) each week. Two short papers and some supplementary reading required. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Poems of the Pearl Manuscript
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course considers the four alliterative poems of the Pearl manuscript, Pearl, Cleanness, Patience, and Sir Gawain and the Green Knight. Discussion will focus on the relationship between aesthetic concerns and moral/religious claims. All reading is in Middle English.

title: The Contemporary Novel and the Politics of Difference
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines recent English-language novels for the ways they thematize social difference in terms of race, gender, class, sexual orientation. Readings include works by Margaret Atwood, Louise Erdrich, Nadine Gordimer, Alan Hollinghurst, Kazuo Ishiguro, Jamaica Kincaid, Toni Morrison, Bharati Mukherjee, Salman Rushdie, Leslie Marmon Silko, John Edgar Wideman, and Jeannette Winterson.

title: On Reading Poetry: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores what work poems undertake and what work they therefore ask of the reader. We examine one primary poem (by a different poet) each week. Two short papers and some supplementary reading required. Preference given to English concentrators. Freshmen and sophomores are encouraged to take this seminar. It is not open to students who have taken (or are taking) a creative writing workshop with Professor Graham.

title: Oscar Wilde: Artist, Martyr, Celebrity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: I have nothing to declare," Wilde reputedly informed a U.S. customs agent in 1882, "except my genius." So began his famous tour of America. We will examine the plays, philosophical writings, poetry, journalism, literary criticism, and fiction of the nineteenth century's most flamboyant and playful writer. We also explore Wilde's life and legend, his literary influences, critics, and his rebirth in the twentieth century as a modern "gay martyr.

title: Oscar Wilde: Artist, Martyr, Celebrity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the plays, philosophical writings, poetry and fiction of one of the nineteenth century's most intriguing writers. Explores Wilde's life, legend, influences and his rebirth in the twentieth century as a "gay martyr." In order to understand how literary celebrities are made, and how the literary canon is shaped and expanded, we will investigate theoretical and critical responses to Wilde, as well as cinematic and literary representations of his life and art. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Short Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A cross-cultural approach to short fiction, featuring works by Hoffmann, Poe, Flaubert, Kipling, Joyce, Mansfield, Mann, Kafka, Borges, Cortázar, and others. All texts studied in English.

title: Short Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Cross-cultural approach to short fiction, featuring works by Hoffmann, Poe, Flaubert, Chekhov, Kipling, Joyce, Mansfield, Mann, Kafka, Borges, Cortázar, and others. All texts studied in English.

title: Short Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Cross-cultural approach to short fiction, featuring works by Hoffmann, Poe, Flaubert, Chekhov, Kipling, Joyce, Mansfield, Mann, Kafka, Borges, Cortázar, and others. All texts studied in English.

title: Poets of New England
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intense study of two poets_Dickinson and Frost_with particular attention to the role of New England as a shaping force. Touching upon other New England poets (Taylor, Robinson, Lowell) and surveying extra-poetic discourses (the sermon, vernacular speech, folkways, statecraft, natural history), our discussions will center on the most private (Dickinson) and most public (Frost) of New England's poets, as we trace both eccentricity and representativeness within an evolving American literature, and, within the tradition of English verse. Preference given to English concentrators.
