title: Seminar: Dramatic Structure and Analysis
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Dramatic Structure and Analysis: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces the Plot-Bead technique for analyzing and/or constructing artistic forms that are performance events. Several artworks, most of them plays, but some poems and one musical composition, are studied in detail in the light of depth action analysis and codification of the artifact's time-form in a plot-bead diagram. The roots of these analytical techniques (which have practical utility for artists) are Aristotelian, but are reflected in 21st-century practice.

title: Dramatic Structure and Analysis
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces the Plot-Bead technique for analyzing and/or constructing artistic forms that are performance events. Ten artworks, most of them plays, but some of them poems and one of them a musical composition, will be studied in detail in the light of depth action analysis and codification of the artifact's time-form in a plot-bead diagram. The roots of these analytical techniques (which have practical utility for artists) are Aristotelian, but reflected in 20th-century practice.

title: Post-Colonial Rewritings
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Contemporary and postcolonial revisions of major literary works, beginning with Shakespeare's The Tempest and New World texts that have reworked or adapted it. We will also consider the fiction of Daniel Defoe, J.M. Coetzee, Charlotte Brontë, Jean Rhys, Joseph Conrad, V.S. Naipaul, Alejo Carpentier and Tayeb Salih.

title: Postcolonial Epidemics: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar investigates how cultural obsessions with disease and contagion get coded within postcolonial contexts. A broad range of Anglophone fiction will provide us with a multifaceted picture that ranges from destructive social phobias to positive collective responses. These novels explore how the tragic experience of epidemics such as yellow fever, malaria, and AIDS might lead communities to better understand themselves. Authors include John Edgar Wideman, Mary Okurut, Amitav Ghosh, Kazuo Ishiguro, and Jamaica Kincaid.

title: Postcolonial Epidemics: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

title: Poets: Ballads, Sonnets, Literary History, and Poetic Form: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will study a range of ballads and sonnets from the Fourteenth to the Twenty-First Century. We will explore questions of poetic form and literary history within two of the most enduring yet continuously evolving kinds of poetry in English and in other languages.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Plato referred to "the old quarrel between philosophy and poetry." If poets will show us that poetry is not only "pleasant" but "good for us, "we will gladly admit them." If not, he says, we must "warn its hearers to fear its effects on the constitution of their inner selves." This course will examine more and less quarrelling poets and philosophers. Readings may include Plato, Aristotle, Spenser, Milton, Kant, Coleridge, Stein, William James, Eliot, Bergson, Adorno, Beckett, Heidegger, and Celan. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Psychoanalysis and the Lyric Poem
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An investigation into the relation (historical, theoretical, ontological) between lyric poetry and psychoanalysis. Particular attention given to: questions of form, content, structure, freedom, constraint, metaphor, and resistance; the rhetoric of credible human presence; claims and critiques of selfhood derived from and/or directed against psychoanalytic practice. Readings from Shakespeare, Herbert, Whitman, Hardy, Lowell, Plath, Hecht, Bidart, Gluck, William James, Freud, Wittgenstein, Lacan, Winnicott, Kristeva, Vendler, Johnson, Crews, Zizek, Bass, Grossman, Lear.

title: Psychoanalysis and the Lyric Poem
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An investigation into the relation (historical, theoretical, ontological) between lyric poetry and psychoanalysis. Particular attention given to: questions of form, content, structure, freedom, constraint, metaphor, and resistance; the rhetoric of credible human presence; claims and critiques of selfhood derived from and/or directed against psychoanalytic practice. title: An English Theatrical Revolution, 1833-1914: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A lecture course on British theater in the Victorian and Edwardian periods, with a focus on the intersection of commercial and artistic innovations. Topics include melodrama, Gilbert & Sullivan, Ibsenism, the New Woman, censorship, copyright, and the rise of Modern Drama.

title: Poets of New England: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intense study of two poets-Dickinson and Frost-with particular attention to the role of New England as a shaping force. Touching upon other New England poets (Taylor, Robinson, Lowell) and surveying extra-poetic discourses, our discussions will center on the most private (Dickinson) and most public (Frost) of New England's poets, as we trace both eccentricity and representativeness within an evolving American literature, and, within the tradition of English verse.

title: Poets of New England: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Puritans and Planters: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveying the literature of the Chesapeake--including texts of contact and exploration, of the Revolution, nation building, and the early Republic --and the literature of early New England--including sermonic literature, history, devotional and homiletic verse. This course introduces students to the earliest American literature in its transatlantic context.

title: Victorian Poetry and Nonfiction Prose
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of poetry and nonfiction prose by Victorian writers. Authors include Carlyle, Mill, Tennyson, Robert Browning, Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Martineau, Ruskin, Arnold, Meredith, D. G. Rossetti, Christina Rossetti, Swinburne, Pater, Michael Field, Mona Caird, and Hopkins. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Subjects in Literature and Psychoanalysis
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Love, labor, and loss in literature and psychoanalytic theory: topics include theories of gender and sexuality, identity, fetishism, the uncanny, trauma, and mourning and melancholia. Texts: Freud, Lacan, Shakespeare, Hitchcock, among others. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Subjects in Literature and Psychoanalysis
subject: ENGLISH

courseDescriptionLong: Love, labor, and loss in literature and psychoanalytic theory: topics include theories of gender and sexuality, identity, fetishism, the uncanny, trauma, and mourning and melancholia. Texts: Freud, Lacan, Shakespeare, Hitchcock, among others.

title: The Prophetic Tradition in America
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the literature of prophecy belief in American from the colonial era to the present. Authors include Anne Hutchinson, Joseph Smith, Nat Turner, John Brown, Melville, Charles Brockden Brown, Whitman, Twain, Hal Lindsey

title: The Prophetic Tradition in America
subject: ENGLISH

title: Modernism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Modernism considered as a movement in intellectual culture. Following some examination of important 19th-century antecedents, the focus is on central texts of the early 20th century by Yeats, Conrad, Joyce, and Woolf. Topics include the sources and challenges of a self-conscious modernity; the problem of the past; personality and impersonality; art as engagement and as avoidance; the representation of women; the effect of imperialism; and the uses of popular culture.

title: The Poetry of W.B. Yeats: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major poems of W.B. Yeats, emphasizing genre and development.

title: The Poetry of W.B. Yeats: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major poems of W.B. Yeats, emphasizing genre and development.

title: Joyce
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Beginning with Dubliners and concluding with extensive study in Ulysses, attempts to consider the relations among myth, freedom, history, politics, and art in the works of James Joyce. Issues include the question of difficulty and the packaging of the modern artist.

title: Joyce's Ulysses
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close reading of Ulysses in literary and historical context.

title: Modern American Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Wisdom, delight, invention, and some cultural contexts, too; major poets and poems from T.S. Eliot, Marianne Moore and Robert Frost almost to the present day: we will also read William Carlos Williams, Wallace Stevens, Elizabeth Bishop, Robert Lowell, Larine Niedecker, James MErrill, and John Ashbery, among others.

title: 20th-Century American Theater
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines American playwrights of the 20th century, considering their formal innovations and artistic influences in relation to a changing American historical context. Explores how naturalist, expressionist, realist, and experimental genres broach recurring themes such as the quest for a bounded "American" identity; the effects of industrialization and American capitalism; regional experiences of the South, the city, and the Western frontier; the United States at war; the constitution of the American family; the paradoxes of American diversity. Incorporating classroom performance and critical analysis, includes works by O'Neill, Rice, Zangwill, Hughes, Odets, Miller, Hellman, Williams, Henley, Baraka, Mamet, Shepard, Albee, Mann, Kennedy, Shange, Gomez-Peña, Smith, Wilson, Kushner, and others.

title: Beckett, Pinter, Genet, Churchill
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive investigation of four major European playwrights of the 20th century. Compares and contrasts a range of theatrical techniques that dramatizes the limits of speakability, the relentless materiality of the body, the constituitive relation of self and other, the impulse toward narrative enactment, the dilemma of repetition, the incorporation and/or deflection of "the political", the power of language to entrap and to enable.

title: Contemporary Anglophone Drama
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The course will explore 20th-century Anglophone drama in diverse areas of the English-speaking world. Through works of Irish, African, Caribbean and U.S. playwrights like Friel, Soyinka, Fugard, Walcott and Shange, the seminar will be organized around two principal issues: the use of folk, ritual, vernacular and carnivalesque performance idioms to transform the received genre of Western literary drama; themes of empire, colony and postcolony in the making of the modern world. Some knowledge of classical and avant-garde theories of drama and performance would be useful, but it is not a prerequisite for this course.

title: Austen, James

title: Celebrated Plays: Award Winning British and American Drama 1993-2003
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will read the most celebrated plays of the last ten years as measured by their selection for major theater awards. We will also study the culture of awards to uncover patterns and biases (if any) in individual competitions. Final projects may be critical or creative. At the end of the class, we will have our awards ceremony, and vote on plays in each category which we, as victims of our own biases, most admire.

title: Ibsen, Shaw, and Chekhov
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An in-depth look at the three most influential voices in dramatic literature at the birth of "The New Drama." Our focus will be on the plays themselves_their literary and dramatic innovations, their philosophical and cultural preoccupations, and the new stylistic and interpretative challenges they posed. By reading generously from varied moments in each artist's corpus, we'll deepen our understanding of the impact and rupture created by these giants of the modern stage.

title: Women and Speech in Contemporary Drama
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of contemporary drama with a focus on woman as theatrical construct. Questions the ways theatrical conventions of representation facilitate the staging of gender. Special attention to the division between female body and voice; gender and racial "cross-dressing"; the feminist avant-garde; women in multicultural works; and the postmodern aesthetics of silence and nonspeech. Playwrights include Beckett, Pinter, Hare, Bond, Shepard, Fugard, Churchill, Shange, Cha, Kennedy, Feinstein, and Fornes.

title: Campus Plays
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Anchored by the American Repertory Theatre and enriched by diverse student and community organizations, Harvard is a vibrant site of theatrical activity. In this course we will study, attend, and critique plays produced on campus during the term. Selected readings will contextualize works and enrich our understanding of their significance from disparate perspectives_as members of a literary genre, as expressions of culture, as scripts for performance, and as irreproducible live events. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Philip Larkin unless John Ashbery: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Recent events within "air's other side" (Rilke). Poetic and counter-poetic language; syntax and its alternatives; form and the varieties of inform; sense and reticence; voice, personhood and their absence; poems, prose and intermediate possibilities. Major and representative works by both authors will be given close, imaginative, analytic attention.

title: Pinter Churchill Stoppard Frayn: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An in-depth look at the four most influential British playwrights of the late twentieth century. Readings include generous selections of each author's plays, as well as novels, screenplays, journalism, and essays. Emphasis is on recurring themes that haunt these authors' works, and the innovative techniques they develop to convey them.

title: Gender and Contemporary Theater
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates how gender underwrites the politics and aesthetics of contemporary theater and performance. Incorporating classroom performance and critical analysis, considers how different performance techniques reproduce or disrupt constructions of masculinity and femininity and the ways differences of race, class, nation, age, and sexuality inflect those constructions. Works by international male and female writers including Fornes, Kennedy, Rama, Split Britches, Hughes, Duras, Churchill, Spiderwoman Theatre, Miller, Finley, Moraga, Sistren, Mamet, Mnouchkine, Shange, and other playwrights and contemporary theorists.

title: Stevens and Pound: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The American poets Wallace Stevens and Ezra Pound have come to represent separate and distincty ides of poetry. The aim of this seminar is to arrive at a richer understanding of Modernist poetry through these singular exemplars.

title: Stevens and Pound: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The American poets Wallace Stevens and Ezra Pound have come to represent separate and distincty ides of poetry. The aim of this seminar is to arrive at a richer understanding of Modernist poetry through these singular exemplars.

title: Exotica in Renaissance Drama
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Literally meaning "from the outside," the word "exotic" generally suggests Otherness_the outlandish and the socially marginal as well the alien. Our pursuit of Renaissance exotica will follow three major thematic veins: representations of the culturally foreign, madness, and the supernatural. We will contextualize our analyses of Renaissance plays with historical readings and culturally critical texts. Texts for this course will include work by Shakespeare, Marlowe, Webster, Montaigne, Freud, Said, Fanon, and Foucault.

title: 20th-Century Irish Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of plays, poetry, essays and fiction written from the beginning of the Irish Revival to the time of the Troubles in Northern Ireland. Authors include Synge, Yeats, Lady Gregory, Joyce, Beckett, O'Casey, Flann O'Brien, Friel, Trevor, and Heaney. Readings will focus on the preoccupation of these writers with Irish history, myth, and the literary construction of a national identity.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of plays, poetry, essays and fiction written from the beginning of the Irish Revival to the time of the Troubles in Northern Ireland. Authors include Synge, Yeats, Lady Gregory, Joyce, Beckett, O'Casey, Flann O'Brien, Friel, Trevor, and Heaney. Readings will focus on the preoccupation of these writers with Irish history, myth, and the literary construction of a national identity.

title: Metaphysical Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A course on the major lyric poets of the 17th century, Donne, Jonson, Herbert, and Marvell. What is the relation between poetry and philosophy, between lyric expression and permanent order? In the seventeenth century, medieval notions of order gave way before the rise of science and of early modern philosophy.

title: Navigating Ulysses
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: James Joyce's modernist epic supplemented by readings of significant intertexts (The Odyssey, Hamlet) along with works of secondary criticism. Attention directed to formal aspects of this difficult work as well as to its thematic engagement with important issues of its time, including: Irish nationalism and British colonialism, feminism, the advent of advertising, and the rise of consumer culture. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: The Poetics of Error
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A new look at American Modernism as an enactment of the Poetics of Error, and a general investigation of the poetic, philosophical, cultural, and historical dimensions of what is commonly called an error. Readings include Henry James, Ezra Pound, Gertrude Stein, T.S. Eliot, Wallace Stevens, W.C. Williams, and Laura Riding

title: American Decadence: the 1890s
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The literature of a decade labeled decadent, and that literature's contribution to popular interest in imperialism, bohemianism, sexology, "boyology," voodoo, degeneration, adolescence, the New Woman, the new immigration, impressionism, and the Museum Movement. Works include a boy's book, a novel of sensation, a "dangerous novel," and an occult biography. Authors include Whitman, Dunbar-Nelson, Chopin, James, Hopkins, Norris, Gilman, and Frederic.

title: English Poetry: 1914+
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: English poetry written after 1914. ``English'' here means poets who are originally from England, not simply poets writing in the English language. Authors include Wilfred Owen, Edward Thomas, W.H. Auden, Philip Larkin, Thom Gunn, Geoffrey Hill, Stevie Smith, and others.

title: English Poetry: 1914+
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: English poetry written after 1914. ``English'' here means poets who are originally from England, not simply poets writing in the English language. Authors include Wilfred Owen, Edward Thomas, W.H. Auden, Philip Larkin, Thom Gunn, Geoffrey Hill, Stevie Smith, and others.

title: Early 20th-Century British Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will be devoted to the poetry of four English poets from the early twentieth century. Thomas Hardy, Wilfred Owen, Edward Thomas, and D.H. Lawrence will be the particular authors. We shall read their work with close attention to individual poems as well as to the historical and literary background. In the cases of Owen and Thomas, we shall necessarily explore the relation of poetry to the First World War. Other poets may be read for comparison  Rosenberg, Housman, Kipling, Sassoon, Riding, Stevie Smith.

title: Women on the Verge: 20th-Century American Women Playwrights
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: From Gertrude Stein to Suzan-Lori Parks, American women have been at the forefront of 20th-century efforts to relate form to content in dramatic literature. We'll read a sampling of texts by ``women on the verge'' whose brilliant solutions to form-content issues have had a profound impact (many acknowledged only decades later) on the lives and work of those of us who come after. Research and creative projects related to individual interests encouraged.

title: Women on the Verge: 20th-Century American Women Playwrights
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: From Gertrude Stein to Suzan-Lori Parks, American women have been at the forefront of 20th-century efforts to relate form to content in dramatic literature. We'll read a sampling of play texts and manifestos by ``women on the verge'' whose brilliant solutions to form-content issues have had a profound impact (often acknowledged only decades later) on the lives and work of those of us who come after. Research and creative projects related to individual interests encouraged.

title: Contemporary Theater
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course focuses on the process of adaptation, how contemporary directors adapt dramatic and non-dramatic texts for the stage and how contemporary dramatists appropriate and explode classical models, such as Greek and Elizabethan drama. The seminar, a joint venture between Dramatic Arts and English, is also fully integrated with the spring season at the ART. Productions by Peter Brook, Richard Schechner, the Wooster Group; plays by Mee, Kane, Greig, Wellman, among others.

title: Contemporary Theater

title: Puritanism in America
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: New England Puritanism in its social, religious, historical, and ethical contexts, with emphasis on literary and aesthetic questions, and in particular on literary and cultural continuities.

title: Recognitions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: What if originality were not what strikes us most forcefully in art? What, instead, if recognition of what and whom we have known already is the most emotionally forceful, illuminating experience of art? This course will test the force of these propositions, by looking to both visual art (painting and movies) and literature. We will look to rhetoric, cognitive psychology and philosophy in order to understand the artistic experience of recognition.  Texts will be drawn anywhere from Homer to Shakespeare in Love.

title: Recognitions

title: Renaissance Theatricality: Shakespeare and his Contemporaries
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: English Renaissance drama is filled with meta-theatrical moments: disguises and dissimulation, confidence tricks, ceremonies, masques, and plays-within-the-play. Reading Shakespeare alongside his rivals and peers (Kyd, Marlowe, and Jonson, among others), this seminar examines how early modern theater meditates on the idea of theatricality. We will explore how questions of performance impinge on representations of decorum, desire, revenge, evil, power, and ideology. Plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Richard II, Hamlet, Othello, and others. This course, when taken for letter grade, meets the Department of English Shakespeares Common Ground requirement.

title: Radical Poetics
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive study of the texts and contexts of a few 20th-century literary movements or "scenes" - the Celtic Revival, Objectivism, the San Francisco Renaissance, the New York School, and the "Language" poets - in which poets have aspired both to be a social group (whether understood as a local or universal "movement," a publishing collective, a band of friends or lovers) and to use poetry to reconstruct social formations in crisis.

title: Poetry and Politics in the 20th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive study of the texts and contexts of a few 20th-century literary cases - the Gaelic Revival, the San Francisco Renaissance, the New York School, and the ``Language'' poets - in which poets have aspired both to be a social group (whether understood as a ``movement,'' a ``scene,'' a ``magic workshop,'' a band of friends or lovers) and to use poetry to reconstruct social formations in crisis.

title: The Poetry of Wallace Stevens
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the major poems of Wallace Stevens. Topics: the conceptual poem; the sequence; the American poem; the philosophic poem; ``skepticism and animal faith''; poetry and the social order; minimalism and maximalism.

title: Sylvia Plath and Anne Sexton
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The poetry of Plath and Sexton will be read and discussed along with letters, journals, and biographies. Topics to be discussed: What are the relations between an author's life and an author's poetry? How does biography affect criticism? Do we read the work of these poets backwards through their suicides? How do they represent the problems of being a woman, a poet, a daughter, a mother, a wife, and a ``case''? How do they think about, and practice, poetic invention? How do they combine pain and wit, and rewrite existing traditions of poetic morbidity, madness, and mania?

title: Sylvia Plath and Anne Sexton
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the poetry of Sylvia Plath and Anne Sexton, with reference to questions of biography, suicide, and gender.

title: Puritanism and American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Study of selected major American writers in the context of the Puritan New England legacy. The writers for 1991-92: Hawthorne and Melville. A lecture-discussion class.

title: Walt Whitman: Texts and Contexts
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive study of Whitman's poetry with particular reference to its manifold relationships and its turbulent and colorful times. Emerson called Whitman "Half songthrush, half alligator" and referred to his style as "a singular blend of the Bhagavad Gita and the New York Herald." Explores the outrageously mixed historical character of Leaves of Grass.

title: Virginia Woolf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Woolf's major novels and selections from her essays, short stories, reminiscences, letters and diaries, in order to understand the range of Woolf's concerns, their interrelations, and the modernist, feminist, postmodernist aspects of her work. Issues include nationalism, war, women and the professions, patriarchy and capitalism, phenomenology, childhood, satire, and the politics of narration.

title: Ethnic-American Autobiography
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of ethnic-American autobiographical writings in the 19th and 20th centuries, with a particular emphasis on African-American, Native-American, and Jewish-American authors. We explore historical and aesthetic dimensions, and focus on the relation between self-fashioning and social protest; integration versus separatism; and religious, gendered, and other components of ethnic identities.

title: Virginia Woolf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Woolf's major novels and selections from her essays, short stories, reminiscences, letters and diaries, in order to understand the range of Woolf's concerns, their interrelations, and the modernist, feminist, postmodernist aspects of her work. Issues include nationalism, war, women and the professions, patriarchy and capitalism, phenomenology, childhood, satire, and the politics of narration.

title: Virginia Woolf

courseDescriptionLong: Examines Woolf's major novels and selections from her essays, short stories, reminiscences, letters and diaries, in order to understand the range of Woolf's concerns, their interrelations, and the modernist, feminist, postmodernist aspects of her work. Issues include nationalism, war, women and the professions, patriarchy and capitalism, phenomenology, childhood, satire, and the politics of narration.

title: Ethnic-American Autobiography
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of ethnic-American autobiographical writings in the 19th and 20th centuries, with a particular emphasis on African-American, Native-American, and Jewish-American authors. We explore historical and aesthetic dimensions, and focus on the relation between self-fashioning and social protest; integration versus separatism; and religious, gendered, and other components of ethnic identities.

title: Virginia Woolf
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys Woolf's major novels, essays, selections from her letters and diaries, and a variety of Woolf's critics, in an attempt to understand the range of Woolf's concerns, their interrelations, and the many ^'^'Virginia Woolfs''_modernist, feminist, postmodernist_in both critical literature and the cultural imagination. Issues include theory of the novel, nationalism, women and writing, patriarchy and capitalism, phenomenology, and the politics of narration.

title: The Idea of a Theatre: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores what theatre has meant, as a medium, throughout history, in any of its many cultural settings. Starting with the ancient Greeks (Oedipus Rex), we will study six major "theatres" and how each represented "the idea of a theatre" in its time and place. Terence's Adelphoe, several cantos from Dante's Purgatorio, Shakespeare's Hamlet, Racine's Bajazet, Wagner's Tristan and Isolde, Ibsen's Rosmersholm, and O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night provide our focal moments.

title: The Idea of a Theatre: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores what theatre has meant, as a medium, throughout history, in any of its many cultural settings. Starting with the ancient Greeks (Oedipus Rex), we will study six major "theatres" and how each represented "the idea of a theatre" in its time and place. Terence's Eunuchus, several cantos from Dante's Purgatorio, Shakespeare's Hamlet, Racine's Andromaque, Wagner's Tristan and Isolde, Ibsen's Rosmersholm, and O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night provide our focal moments.

title: Samuel Beckett's Plays and Prose: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Studies systematically the arc of Samuel Beckett's literary career, with particular emphasis on Beckett's stage and video plays. The course proposes the idea of a "stable habitation for the Self" as one way of understanding both Beckett's thematic matière and his astonishing aesthetic innovations in three media: stage, page, and video screen. Video resources supplement reading and discussion of texts, and local productions of the plays are studied when available.

title: Staging Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: Like any other plays, those by William Shakespeare pose serious challenges for actors, directors, designers, and audiences, problems they must solve in performance. Because Shakespeare’s plays have such a long history in the theater, they offer a unique window into ever-evolving performance aesthetics. In staging Shakespeare, artists always attempt to capture what they perceive as Shakespeare’s universal achievements and to amplify his work’s resonance for a contemporary audience. This seminar examines a history of Shakespeare in the English-speaking theater to illuminate how Shakespeare helps to shape theater and how the theater helps to make Shakespeare. We will read a number of Shakespeare’s works, but will attend not to literary interpretations of the texts, but rather to (a) the problems those texts create in performance and (b) how artists have solved those challenges over the past four centuries. In other words, we will explore both prior approaches to staging Shakespeare and what in Shakespeare’s plays makes them particularly difficult—and exciting—to stage.

title: Southern Folklore and Southern Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Chiefly an introduction to the folk literature of the South_folk tales, ballads, and similar oral and popular genres_and to its cultural contexts. An unsystematic treatment of literary works that show interesting relations to folklore backgrounds. Special emphasis on Zora Neale Hurston, folklorist and writer.

title: Southern Folklore and Southern Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Chiefly an introduction to the folk literature of the South_folk tales, ballads, and similar oral and popular genres_and to its cultural contexts. title: The Poetry of Seamus Heaney
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the poetry of Seamus Heaney, with some attention to his prose. Topics: abstraction and topicality; the ethnic and the national; the erotic; gravity and lightness; the informality of the formal; allegorical, anthropological, and autobiographical forms of voice; the perceptual versus the conceptual.

title: The Poetry of Seamus Heaney: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: With Heaney's death, the canon of his poetry has closed. Using Opened Ground and selections from the later poetry, we will investigate the ways into Heaney's verse, from the political to the autobiographical to the symbolic.

title: Subjectivity and Identity
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will concentrate on 19th-century English explorations of the sense of self, especially among the Romantics (Wordsworth, Byron, Keats) and their successors (Browning, Pater, Wilde). We will also cast a glance backwards (at classical, Renaissance, and Enlightenment models of identity) and conclude with an examination of Modernist fragmentation.

title: The Romance of Scotland
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Scottish literature and the place of Scotland in the British literary imagination of the 18th and 19th centuries. Attention to the myth of the Highlands, the romance of the Jacobite rebellion, the Ossian controversy, and the figure of the bard as well as to the larger question of what role literature has in the production of national identity. Readings in poetry, travel writing, national tales, historical novels, and philosophical prose by writers such as Smith, Hume, Smollett, Johnson, Burns, Scott, and Hogg.

subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

Readings in poetry, travel writing, national tales, historical novels, and intellectual prose by writers such as Defoe, Macpherson, Smith, Smollett, Johnson, Burns, Scott, Ferrier and Hogg.

title: Renaissance Theatricality: Shakespeare and his Contemporaries
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: English Renaissance drama is filled with meta-theatrical moments: disguises and dissimulation, confidence tricks, ceremonies, masques, and plays-within-the-play. Reading Shakespeare alongside his rivals and peers (Kyd, Marlowe, and Jonson, among others), this seminar examines how early modern theater meditates on the idea of theatricality. We will explore how questions of performance impinge on representations of decorum, desire, revenge, evil, power, and ideology. Plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Richard II, Hamlet, Othello, and others. This course, when taken for letter grade, meets the Department of English Shakespeares Common Ground requirement.

title: Engendered Fictions
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Comparative analysis of 19th- and 20th-century American narratives. Works by men and women are paired thematically to reveal significant distinctions in style, attitude, and form that may be attributable to cultural definitions of sexuality and authorship. Also, recent critical speculation on the subject of gender.

title: Place, space and region: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will look at place, space, region and locality in poetry, nonfiction and prose fiction: how does an author, a book, belong to a region? How does geography turn into literature? Likely authors, among others: Willa Cather, William Carlos Williams, John Edgar Wideman and C. D. Wright. We may look at much earlier literature (e.g. John Donne in London) as well.

title: Shakespeare's Rome: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates Shakespeare’s lifelong engagement with the literature, politics, and culture of ancient Rome. It will give careful attention to the three "Roman Plays" - Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, and Coriolanus - but will also consider the larger role of classical antiquity in Shakespeare’s development and achievement as a dramatist.

title: Shakespeare's Rome
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates Shakespeare’s lifelong engagement with the literature, politics, and culture of ancient Rome. It will give careful attention to the three "Roman Plays" - Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, and Coriolanus - but will also consider the larger role of classical antiquity in Shakespeare’s development and achievement as a dramatist.

title: Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intensive readings on slavery, resistance, and abolition in western culture with a focus on America. Authors include Aesop, Aristotle, Aphra Behn, Blake, Equiano, Wheatley, Woolman, David Walker, Douglass, McCune Smith, Child, Stowe, Garrison, John Brown, Fitzhugh, and others including secondary sources.

title: Sonnet Sequences
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The amatory sonnet-sequence in England had a brief and brilliant career in the 1590s (Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, and others), and then was revived in the mid-19th century (Barrett Browning, Christina Rossetti, Meredith). We will study both groups, together with their sonnets along the way, and explore the relations between them.

title: The American Transcendentalists
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of the principal works of Emerson and Thoreau in broader cultural, especially religious, context. Some attention also to such figures as Alcott, Fuller, Parker, Ripley, and Very.

title: The American Transcendentalists
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of the principal works of Emerson and Thoreau in broader cultural, especially religious, context. Some attention also paid to such figures as Alcott, Fuller, Parker, Ripley, and Very.

title: Sonnet Sequences
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The amatory sonnet-sequence in England had a brief and brilliant career in the 1590s (Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, and others), and then was revived in the mid-19th century (Barrett Browning, Christina Rossetti, Meredith). We will study both groups, together with their sonnets along the way, and explore the relations between them.

title: The Short Story as Art and Artifact: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the short story as a literary genre and as a reflection of the conditions in which it was produced. We will read stories from Poe and James to Barthelme and Beattie.

title: British Culture and Society in the 1930's
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Novels, non-fiction, drama and poetry by, amongst others, Auden, Bowen, Eliot, Empson, Greene, Huxley, Isherwood, Orwell, Spender, Waugh and Woolf, are set in the wider context of British culture and history in the 1930s. Topics include 30's debates about language, aesthetics, surrealism, political commitment, literary theory, community, and gender. The course also involves viewings of selected British films of the period.

title: Gay Men and the Spectacle
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Presents the argument that American mass culture makes a considerable spectacle of gay men, their bodies and behaviors. Because the spectacle is a necessary foil to heterosexual male definition, it is abundant, insistent, and also invisible in the verbal surround that captions it. In addition to examples of this paradox in theatre, film, and journalism, the course looks backward to older cultural traditions (Wilde, Coward) and forward to postliberation gay and activist reappropriations (Ludlam, AIDS graphics and videos).

title: British Culture and Society in the 1930's
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Novels, non-fiction, drama and poetry by, amongst others, Auden, Bowen, Eliot, Empson, Greene, Huxley, Isherwood, Orwell, Spender, Waugh and Woolf, are set in the wider context of British culture and history in the 1930s. Topics include 30's debates about language, aesthetics, surrealism, political commitment, literary theory, community, and gender. The course also involves viewings of selected British films of the period.

title: Sexing Victorian Fiction: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Sex and money, reading and shopping, work and marriage, domestic realism and imperial fantasy, unsexed women and unmanned men, feminism and anti-feminism, single-sex communities and same-sex desire. Short stories and long novels by Austen, Brontë, Gaskell, Dickens, Collins, Eliot, Oliphant, and Conan Doyle, as well as essays by Ruskin, Mill, Trollope, and others.

title: Sexing Victorian Fiction: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Ezra Pound
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Gender Difference and Sexual Relation in Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: From courtly love poetry to saints' lives, from scientific treatises to The Canterbury Tales, the imaginative writings of the Middle Ages are full of gender identities that surprise in their strangeness but are closely linked to today's sexual norms and fantasies. Course readings include medieval chivalric, religious, scientific, and literary writings and reflect how sexuality and subjectivity are shaped in tandem as well as how sexuality can disrupt and transform stable selves.

title: Gender Difference and Sexual Relation in Medieval Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: From courtly love poetry to saints' lives, from scientific treatises to The Canterbury Tales, the imaginative writings of the Middle Ages are full of gender identities that surprise in their strangeness but are closely linked to today's sexual norms and fantasies. Course readings include medieval chivalric, religious, scientific, and literary writings and reflect how sexuality and subjectivity are shaped in tandem as well as how sexuality can disrupt and transform stable selves.

title: Literature and the Rise of Public Science: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores the relationship between literary and scientific experiment during the Restoration and the eighteenth century. Our readings, by authors such as Milton, Fontenelle, Pope, Hume, Diderot, and Mary Shelley, will be paired with hands-on activities: while reading Swift’s Gulliver’s Travels, for example, students will have the opportunity to use microscopes and telescopes from the period. Throughout, we will seek to understand how writers of various sorts - scientists, philosophers, poets, novelists, and essayists - were inspired by new accounts of nature, from the simplest experimental observations to the grandest visions of the cosmos.

title: Literature and the Rise of Public Science

title: On Reading Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will explore what work poems undertake and what work they therefore ask of the reader. We will examine one primary poem (by a different poet) each week. Two short papers and some supplementary reading required.

title: The Poetry of Robert Lowell, Elizabeth Bishop, and John Berryman
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will study three aesthetics, three manners; (the hieratic, the discreet, the comic); memory, fantasy, and drama as sources of the lyric; the measured and the free. Lost works (Day by Day, Geography III, late Berryman).

title: The Poetry of Robert Lowell, Elizabeth Bishop, and John Berryman
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: We will study three aesthetics, three manners; (the hieratic, the discreet, the comic); memory, fantasy, and drama as sources of the lyric; the measured and the free. Lost works (Day by Day, Geography III, late Berryman).

title: Twisted Epic: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The Renaissance had a literary dream: the dream of a grand modern epic that would equal the Iliad and the Aeneid. Yet in reality, narrative poetry of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries was anything but a dutiful imitation of classical epic. English poets gave many a creative twist to the ancient genre: they perverted, mocked, curtailed, romanticized, and eroticized it. Authors include Marlowe, Shakespeare, Spenser, and Milton.

courseDescriptionLong: The Renaissance had a literary dream: the dream of a grand modern epic that would equal the Iliad and the Aeneid. Yet in reality, narrative poetry of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries was anything but a dutiful imitation of classical epic. English poets gave many a creative twist to the ancient genre: they perverted, mocked, curtailed, romanticized, and eroticized it. Authors include Marlowe, Shakespeare, Spenser, and Milton.

title: Poets as Critics
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Often one expects a course on poets to be resistant to theory, but we attempt to see to what extent theory has come from poets in the first place. Many prominent poets are also translators: what, then, are the relations among theory, writing, and translating? We focus on the uneasy but necessary relations between the aesthetic and the theoretical.

title: The Harlem Renaissance and the Jazz Age: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of the decade of artistic production known as the "Harlem Renaissance" or the "New Negro Renaissance," or alternatively as the "Jazz Age" -- from roughly 1919 to 1929 -- that explores the controversies of racial representation and identification in the context of American national literature. We will address key interactions on the subject between and among black and white artists of the period, treating their fiction, poetry, and essays.

title: Poetry Beyond Modernism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Beyond the work of Yeats, Pound, and Eliot, what other innovations and developments constituted the "new" in the poetry of the first half of the twentieth century? Readings will include works by these poets, but will focus on poems that do not readily adapt themselves to familiar definitions of the Modern. Special attention will be given to Hardy, Frost, Stevens, Millay, Langston Hughes, Auden, and Larkin. Assignments will include some secondary material.

title: Modernism and Primitivism
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of modernist literature (1890-1940) and primitivism, with readings in Hardy, Synge, Conrad, Lawrence, Lewis, Eliot and Woolf. Explores primitivism in relation to European colonialism, aesthetic dissent, modernist notions of myth and ritual, and contemporary ideas about the folk or masses. Also considers representations of the primitive in the visual arts (Rousseau, Picasso, Gauguin) and human sciences (Darwin, Freud, Frazer, Malinowski) of the period.

title: Modernism and Primitivism

title: Time and Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Studies fiction that experiments with the representation of time, primarily works by Sterne, Proust, Woolf, Faulkner, and Rushdie, with attention to theoretical background in a range of theorists and philosophers.

title: Time and the Novel
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Studies fiction that experiments with the representation of time, primarily Joyce's Ulysses, Woolf's To the Lighthouse, Proust's Remembrance of Things Past, and Ford's The Good Soldier, with comparison to pre-and post-modernist novels including Sterne's Tristram Shandy, Nabokov's Ada, Rushdie's Midnight's Children, and Winterson's Sexing the Cherry, and theoretical background in a range of philosophers and critics.

title: Time and Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Studies fiction that experiments with the representation of time, primarily works by Sterne, Proust, Woolf, Faulkner, and Rushdie, with attention to theoretical background in a range of theorists and philosophers.

title: Adventures with Robert Louis Stevenson: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The author of Treasure Island, Kidnapped, and Dr. Jekyll and Mr Hyde, Scottish novelist Robert Louis Stevenson was a prolific poet, essayist, travel writer, and master of the short story. Cut short by lung disease, his bohemian life was as adventurous and romantic as his fiction. Follow his meandering path from Edinburgh to France, from California to the South Pacific, where his literary interests turned anthropological, and where death was waiting.

title: Transatlantic Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Considers concurrent trends and developments in American and British literary genres across the long 19th century. The focus is on transatlantic hauntings: the development of the gothic phenomenon in texts that pose lingering questions about objectivity and the nature of perception, psychology, gender, race, and cross-cultural influence. Readings include fiction, poetry, and non-fiction by Irving, Poe, Tennyson, the Brownings, Dickens, Hawthorne, James, and others.

title: Transatlantic Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: American Travel Writing
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Travel narratives hover between fact and fiction, description and dream, defying simple classifications of genre. They tell stories about the self and others, about exploration and discovery, race and religion, economics and power. Our ^'^'armchair travels'' in class will take us to Polynesia, Brazil, Yucatan, and Europe, as well as to New York, Florida, and Oregon. The main focus is on texts by 18th- and 19th-century American travelers (Bartram, Knight, Catlin, Parkman, Melville, Stephens, Louis and Elizabeth Agassiz, Fuller, James, Charles Eastman [Ohiyesa], Twain, and Black Elk), but our readings will also include Cook, Darwin, and Humboldt, and we will pay special attention to the role of visual evidence (paintings, drawings, maps, and photographs) in the representation of travel.

title: Transatlantic Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course considers concurrent trends and developments in American and British literary genres across the long 19th century. The focus will be on Transatlantic Hauntings. Readings will include fiction by Washington Irving, Edgar Allan Poe, Charles Dickens, Nathaniel Hawthorne, George Eliot, Henry James, and others, as well as poetry by Poe, Alfred Tennyson, and Robert Browning.

title: Literatures of Travel in the 18th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: 18th-century travel writings, from fictional adventures and scientific voyages to philosophical utopias and fantastical ``true histories.'' Topics include: empire and domesticity; tourism and national identity; narrative continuity and the picaresque; natural history and scientific imperialism. Writings by Defoe, Swift, Boswell, Equiano, Sterne, Mary Wortley Montagu's Turkish Embassy Letters , and Mungo Parks' Travels to the Interior of Africa. This course satisfies the English Department's pre-1800 requirement.

title: Literatures of Travel in the 18th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Eighteenth-century travel writings, from fictional adventures and scientific voyages to philosophical utopias and fantastical ``true histories.'' Topics include: empire and domesticity; tourism and national identity; narrative continuity and the picaresque; natural history and scientific imperialism. Writings by Defoe, Swift, Boswell, Equiano, Sterne, Mary Wortley Montagu's Turkish Embassy Letters, and Mungo Park's Travels to the Interior of Africa. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: The Poet as Essayist
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Beginning with Wordsworth's Preface to Lyrical Ballads, examines some of the prose essays written by poets on the art and craft of poetry and the identity of the poet during the past 200 years. Essays by Wordsworth, Coleridge, Stevens, Cummings, Rich, Rukeyser, Nemerov, Wilbur, Neruda, Berry, Montale, Roethke, Heaney, Jarrell, and others to be read.

title: Literatures of Travel in the 18th Century
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: 18th-century travel writings, from fictional adventures and scientific voyages to philosophical utopias and fantastical ``true histories.'' Topics include: empire and domesticity; tourism and national identity; narrative continuity and the picaresque; natural history and scientific imperialism. Writings by Behn, Defoe, Swift, Boswell, Smollett, Sterne, Cook's Voyages, and Raynal's History of the Two Indies.

title: The Autobiographical Muse: Readings in Contemporary Autobiography
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Through wide reading in 20th-century autobiography, attempts to explore the use of different autobiographical strategies, tones, voices, and details in telling the writer's story. Readings include Gertrude Stein's Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas, Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer, Virginia Woolf's A Room of One's Own, Jean Paul Sartre's The Words, Edward Dahlberg's Because I was Flesh, Tobias Woolf's This Boy's Life, Laura Cunningham's Sleeping Arrangements, Frank Conroy's Stop Time, and Melanie Thernstrom's The Dead Girl, as well as books by Geoffrey Woolf, Jill Kerr Conway, and others.

title: The Novel in the Twenties
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Readings in the fiction of the 1920s in the United States. Authors include Larson, Cather, Wharton, Fauset, Fitzgerald, Glasgow, Dreiser, Dos Passos, Cullen, McKay. Subjects include the representation of sexualities, race, citizenship, urban bohemias, consumerism, entertainment, Freud, and feminism. Additional readings in twenties anthropology, and discussion of cinema in the twenties.

title: Black and White/Male and Female American Selves
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Selected autobiographical writings and current generic and ideological criticism raise issues of nationalism, race, gender, and/or "identity.'' "Autobiographers'' include Benjamin Franklin, Frederick Douglass, Walt Whitman, Henry Adams, Gertrude Stein, Malcolm X, Zora Neale Hurston, W. E. B. DuBois, H. D.

title: American Poetry since 1945
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of several contemporary poets: Bishop, Hughes, Merrill, Ginsberg, Berryman, Lowell, Plath, Ammons, Ashbery, Graham, and Dove.

title: American Poetry since 1945
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of several contemporary poets: Bishop, Hughes, Merrill, Ginsberg, Berryman, Lowell, Plath, Ammons, Ashbery, Graham, and Dove.

title: American Poetry since 1945
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of several contemporary poets: Bishop, Hughes, Merrill, Ginsberg, Berryman, Lowell, Plath, Ammons, Ashbery, Graham, and Dove.

title: Foucault
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the works of Michel Foucault and explores some possible new applications of his ideas.

title: Gender and Popular Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the representations of gender in popular culture and the role gender plays in constructing notions of the popular with particular focus upon contemporary American film, advertising, and rock music. Approaches to the texts are drawn from contemporary theories of popular culture reception and philosophical and psychoanalytic theories of gender.

title: Unsexed Females and Revolutionary Marriage
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: The Indian Novel in English
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The Indian novel in English has been castigated for Babu English, for elite preoccupations, and for purveying spicy postcolonial chic. It also appears with dizzying frequency in bookstore windows, on syllabi, and at the top of literary prize lists. While charting the evolution of the Indian English novel from nineteenth-century ``false starts'' to the late twentieth-century boom period, we shall read such authors as Ali, Chatterjee, Chaudhuri, Desai, Ghosh, Narayan, Roy, Rushdie, and Syal.

title: Jewish Writers of the European and American Diaspora
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course centers on the meaning of Jewishness through a particular literary form: stories by Jews. The story is a major mode of community-formation, and a major theme of the Jewish Story is Diaspora, grounded in a long and varied history. This will be our focus (with a backward glance towards scriptural tradition) in exploring Jewish writers in Europe and America from Sholem Aleikhem and Kafka through Bellow and Ozick, comparing and contrasting their relation to a persisting but shifting sense of identity both as modern writers and representatives of a Diaspora people.

title: Jewish Writers of the European and American Diaspora
subject: ENGLISH

title: Literature, Sexuality, and Artifice
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Nothing is more natural than sex, yes? Or no? In this course, we will examine the long, intricate, and fascinating relationship between the sexual and the artificial in Western literature. Beginning with the Satyricon of Petronius and the Waste Land of T. S. Eliot, we will proceed to readings in Shakespeare, Pope, Baudelaire, Wilde, Freud, Woolf, Genet, Sartre, Baldwin, Beauvoir, Winterson, and others. Special attention to associations among homosexuality, art-making, and imposture.

title: Life Writing
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the challenges and limitations of the first person narrative. We read some classic biographical and autobiographical works and we will also explore related forms such as narratives of confession, travel writing, rapportage, and first person accounts that are written in order to ``bear witness'' at moments of historical or personal crisis. The course is conducted as both seminar and workshop and there will be as much emphasis on writing as on reading.

title: Life Writing
subject: ENGLISH

title: Gender and Nation in 19th-Century British Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the entanglement of gender and nation in 19th-century British poetry and fiction, paying particular attention to literature's role in the production and representation of both. Authors will include Coleridge, Byron, Scott, Charlotte Brontë, Tennyson, Eliot and Stoker.

title: Ethnicity, Violence, and "National" Literatures
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The relation between prose fiction and ethnography, especially the synthesis of ethnographic and orientalist material in major Asian and Middle Eastern writers and thinkers, and the representation of religious and ethnic violence in fictional, autobiographical, journalistic, and ethnographic texts.

title: American Moderns: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines the classic work and intersections between Stein, Hemingway, Cather, Fitzgerald, Dos Passos, and Du Bois.

title: The Slave Narrative
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses narratives written by former slaves (Jacobs, Douglass, Prince, Washington, etc.) and modern rewritings of the slave narrative genre by Toni Morrison, Charles Johnson, Ishmael Reed, Sherley Anne Williams, Octavia Butler, and others.

title: American Moderns: Seminar
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines the classic work and intersections between Stein, Hemingway, Cather, Fitzgerald, Dos Passos, and Du Bois.

title: Black Women and Their Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intends to define the precise shape and contours of the tradition of black women's writing in English. How do black women use language to represent their experiences? How does their writing resemble or diverge from the black male tradition? How does black feminist theory differ from white feminist theory?

title: Black Women and Their Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Intends to define the precise shape and contours of the tradition of black women's writing in English. How do black women use language to represent their experiences? How does their writing resemble or diverge from the black male tradition? How does black feminist theory differ from white feminist theory?

title: Gender and Writing in Victorian Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Competing models of textual work, from The Prelude to Dracula. Readings include autobiographies, biographies, novels, essays, reviews, ghost stories, and obituaries, by Lockhart, Browning, Martineau, Dickens, Mayhew, Gaskell, Ruskin, Trollope, Oliphant, Gissing, Wotton, and others. Issues include: gender, intellectual property, professionalism, anonymity, clerical work, and new writing technologies.

title: Gender and Writing in Victorian Culture
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language

title: Contemporary American Literature by Women of Color
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Fiction, poetry, and autobiography by Afro-American, Asian American, Chicana, and Native American women writers in the context of contemporary cultural and feminist criticism.

title: African-American Literary Tradition
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the emergence and formal development of the Afro-American literary "tradition" from the 18th to the 20th century. Close reading of the canonical texts in the tradition and their structural relationships are stressed, as is the very idea of "tradition" itself. Authors include Phyllis Wheatley, Frederick Douglass, Harriet Jacobs, Booker T. Washington, Ralph Ellison, Toni Morrison, Alice Walker, Gloria Naylor, Amiri Baraka, Gwendolyn Brooks, and others.

title: Asian-American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Works written by Asian Americans, paying particular attention to the shifting role of ^'^'identity politics'' in this newly emerging field of study. Authors include Jade Snow Wang, Frank Chin, John Okada, Hisaye Yamamoto, Maxine Hong Kingston, Amy Tan, and others.

title: Asian American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Critical issues surrounding representations of and by Asian Americans. Readings include works by Hisaye Yamamoto, Maxine Hong Kingston, Frank Chin, Bharati Mukherjee, John Okada, and others.

title: Asian-American Literature
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Works written by Asian Americans, paying particular attention to the shifting role of ^'^'identity politics'' in this newly emerging field of study. Authors include Jade Snow Wang, Frank Chin, John Okada, Hisaye Yamamoto, Maxine Hong Kingston, Amy Tan, and others.

title: American Literature in the Age of Transpacific Imagination
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A rethinking of the multicultural, polyvocal nature of American literature against the palimpsestic backdrop of American history. We envision the Pacific as the new geopolitical center of the world in the 21st century and see the US as a Pacific nation. We explore works that imagine the Pacific in the past 150 years or so, works that represent both canonical American and Asian-American literature (Melville, Twain, Adams, Pound, Kingston, Cha, Mukherjee, Hagedorn).

title: American Literature in the Age of Transpacific Imagination

title: The Material Poem
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A theoretical and historical investigation of the property of materiality or concreteness in canonical and experimental poetry and other lyric texts in prose, music, and video. Topics to be treated include the concrete poem and sacred ritual, material poetics as a subset of both modernism and postmodernism, the politics of the concrete poem (including the intersection of "material'' and "materialist'' readings), sound poetry, the International Concrete movement of the 1960s, and lyric video of the 1980s. Reading knowledge of a foreign language is helpful but not required.

title: The Material Poem
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A theoretical and historical investigation of the property of materiality or concreteness in canonical and experimental poetry and other lyric texts in prose, music, and video. Among the phenomena and topics to be treated: the concrete poem and sacred ritual, material poetics as a subset of both modernism and postmodernism, the politics of the concrete poem (including the intersection of "material'' and "materialist'' readings), sound poetry, the International Concrete movement of the 1960s, and lyric video of the 1980s. Students should have reading knowledge of a foreign language.

title: Victorian Visualities
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This course will explore the visuality of Victorian narrative and lyric in light of aesthetic theory and material culture (e.g., the illustrated book, art exhibition, gothic revivalism and photography). Writers and artists include Tennyson, Brontë, Ruskin, the Rossettis, Morris, Hardy, Pater, Baudelaire, James, Whistler, Cameron and Thomson. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: Models of Value in 18th-Century Fiction
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: A study of theories of human, aesthetic, and market value in 18th-century literature, focusing on how humans and literary works are distinguished from other objects of exchange. Readings drawn from Pope, Defoe, Richardson, Sterne, Burney, as well as Adam Smith, Marx, Benjamin, Zizek.

title: Models of Value in 18th-Century Fiction
subject: ENGLISH

title: Harlem Renaissance
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the period of unprecedented African-American literary flowering during the 1920s and 1930s. Special attention will be given to the following: Harlem and other cultural centers; dialect in poetry and prose; the impact of women authors, editors, and critics; and the central positioning of the Harlem Renaissance in the African-American literary tradition. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: American Nature Writing Before Darwin
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: Faced with the natural environment of the "New World,'' the Puritan John Winthrop exclaimed that he had not seen "the like . . . in England or France, or other parts.'' American natural history became the medium through which such differences could best be articulated - a strange genre of writing that blurred the boundaries between literature and science, autobiography and factual description, and often produced highly complex narratives of bewilderment and wonder. We will read and analyze selections from the writings of Cotton Mather, Jane Colden, Thomas Jefferson, Charles Willson Peale, Lewis and Clark, Alexander Wilson, John James Audubon, Henry David Thoreau, and Herman Melville.

title: Vladimir Nabokov
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine the depth and breadth of the works of Vladimir Nabokov. Special attention paid to those works written directly into English. Special consideration will be accorded to Nabokov's irreverent and idiosyncratic opinions on the task of the critic. Readings will include: Lolita, Speak, Memory, Pale Fire, Pnin, Ada, or Ardor, The Real Life of Sebastian Knight, Bend Sinister, and The Gift. Preference given to English concentrators.

title: The Oral Tradition and Literature in Africa
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will explore the field of oral narrative in Africa and the part which it plays in the life and cultures of African peoples and in giving shape to such classical African works as Sundiata, Things Fall Apart, The Ozidi Saga, and The Marriage of Anansewa. We investigate the world of the oral artist, his personality, and the different genres and stylistic qualities of oral literature in Africa. Attention will be given to the performance techniques adopted by different oral practioners. The student will undertake a project to record and annotate an oral narrative or poem or play, and to present it to the class towards the end of the course.

title: Victorian Poetry
subject: ENGLISH
classAcademicOrgDescription: English and American Literature and Language
courseDescriptionLong: The major poetry of Tennyson, Browning, Barrett Browning, Arnold, D.G. and Christina Rossetti, Swinburne, Hopkins, and Michael Field, as well as criticism by their contemporaries. We will pay particular attention to innovations in poetic form and genre; the significance of Classical, Arthurian, and Renaissance sources; the representation of psychological and emotional states; and the poet's response to social questions. Preference given to English concentrators.
